Yoruba: Ọ̀run ló jẹ́ fún òdọ́, olùbẹ̀rẹ̀ ẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa ẹranko bíi tèmi.

English: But I remember even at that young age that I found the tall electric fences blocking off the game parks quite divisive.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo rantí wí pé kóda ní ọjọ́ orí kékeré yẹn mo rí gbogbo ọgbà oníná gíga tó ń dí gàgá àwọn ẹranko náà gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìpínyà.

English: Sure, they were keeping elephants out of the communities, but they also kept communities out of their wild spaces.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, wọ́n ń lé àwọn erin jáde kúrò ní àwùjọ, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n tún ń lé àwùjọ kúrò ní àye wọn nínú ìgbẹ.

English: It really was quite a challenge to me at that young age.
Yoruba: It really was quite a challenge to me at that young age. Ìdojúkọ ńlá ló jẹ́ fún mi ní ọjọ́ orí kékeré yẹn.

English: It was only when I moved to Kenya at the age of 14, when I got to connect to the vast, wild open spaces of East Africa.
Yoruba: Ìgbà tí mo kó lọ sí orílẹ̀ ède Kenya ní ọmọdún mẹ́rìnlá nìkan, nígbà tí mo ní láti sopọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn àyè ńlá tó ṣí sílẹ̀ ní ìlà oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: And it is here now that I feel truly, instinctively, really at home.
Yoruba: Ibí yìí ni mo ti ní ìmọ̀lára lóòótọ́, pé ilé ni mo wà.

English: I spent many, many happy years studying elephant behavior in a tent, in Samburu National Reserve, under the guideship of professor Fritz Vollrath and Iain Douglas-Hamilton, studying for my PhD and understanding the complexities of elephant societies.
Yoruba: Mo lo àìmọye odún aláyọ̀ tí mò ń kọ́ nípa ìṣesí erin nínú àtíbàbà kan, níbi ìfipamọ́ àpapọ̀ Samburu, lábẹ́ ìtọ́sọ́nà ọ̀jọ̀gbón Fritz Vollrath àti Lain Douglas-Hamilton, tí mò ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ fún oyè òwọ̀we tí mo sì ń mọ àwọn àmúdijú àwùjọ erin.

English: But now, in my role as head of the human-elephant coexistence program for Save the Elephants, we're seeing so much change happening so fast that it's urged a change in some of our research programs.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nísinyìí, nínú ojúṣe mi gẹ́gẹ́ bi olórí ètò ìgbáyépọ̀ ènìyàn àti erin fún Gba Àwọn Erin Là, à ń rí àyípadà púpọ̀ tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ wéré-wéré tí ó ti bẹ̀bẹ àyípadà nínú àwọn ètò ìwádìí wa.

English: No longer can we just sit and understand elephant societies or study just how to stop the ivory trade, which is horrific and still ongoing.
Yoruba: A ò kọ̀ lè jókòó ká wá ní òye àwùjọ erin tàbí ká kọ̀ kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ bí a ṣe lè dá òwo eyín erin dúró, tó jẹ́ ìbẹ̀rù tó sì ń lọ lọ́wọ́.

English: We're having to change our resources more and more to look at this rising problem of human-elephant conflict, as people and pachyderms compete for space and resources.
Yoruba: A ní láti ṣe àyípadà àwọn ohun-èlo wa lọ́pọ̀ láti wo ìsoro rògbòdìyàn ènìyàn àti erin t’ó ń ṣúyọ, bí àwọn ènìyàn àti àwon ẹranko-ńlá ṣe ń jìjà gùdù fún àyè àti ohun-èlò.

English: It was only as recently as the 1970s that we used to have 1.2 million elephants roaming across Africa.
Yoruba: Láìpẹ́ yìí bíi àsìko ọdún 1970 ni a ní ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún kan àti ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà igba àwọn erin tí wọ́n ń káàkiri ilẹ̀ adúláwọ̀.

English: Today, we're edging closer to only having 400,000 left.
Yoruba: Lónì, à ń súmọ́ níní ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà erínwó.

English: And at the same time period, the human population has quadrupled, and the land is being fragmented at such a pace that it's really hard to keep up with.
Yoruba: Ní àsìkò kan náà, iye àpapọ̀ àwọn ènìyàn ti di ìlọ́po mẹ́rin, ìlẹ̀ náà sì ń dínkù ní eré tó nira láti bá dọ́gba.

English: Too often, these migrating elephants end up stuck inside communities, looking for food and water but ending up breaking open water tanks, breaking pipes and, of course, breaking into food stores for food.
Yoruba: Lópọ̀ ìgbà, àwọn erin tí wọ́n ṣí kiri wọ̀nyí máa ń há nígbẹ́yìn sínú àwọn àwùjọ, wọ́n ń wá oúnjẹ àti omi ṣùgbọ́n nígbẹ́yìn wọ́n máa ń fọ́ àwọn kòkòndoro omi, fífọ́ àwọn ọ̀pá àti, bẹ́ẹ̀ni, fífọ́ àwọn ilé ìtàja oúnjẹ fún oúnjẹ.

English: It's really a huge challenge.
Yoruba: Ìdojúkọ tó tóbi gan-an ni.

English: Can you imagine the terror of an elephant literally ripping the roof off your mud hut in the middle of the night and having to hold your children away as the trunk reaches in, looking for food in the pitch dark?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ ẹ lè ronú ìwà ìgbésúmọ̀mi erin tó ń fa òrùle ahéré yín ya láàárín òru tí ẹ ní láti di àwọn ọmọ yín mú kúrò níbi àrọ́wọ́tó eyín erin, tó ń wá oúnjẹ nínú òkùnkùn?

English: These elephants also trample and eat crops, and this is traditionally eroding away that tolerance that people used to have for elephants.
Yoruba: Àwọn erin wọ̀nyí tún máa ń tẹ̀ wọ́n sì máa ń jẹ nǹkan ọ̀gbìn, èyí sì ń ba ìfaradà tí àwọn ènìyàn máa ń ní fún àwọn erin jẹ́.

English: And sadly, we're losing these animals by the day and, in some countries, by the hour -- to not only ivory poaching but this rapid rise in human-elephant conflict as they compete for space and resources.
Yoruba: Ó bani nínú jẹ́, à ń ṣe àfẹ́kù àwọn ẹranko wọ̀nyí lójoojúmọ́, ní àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè kọ̀ọ̀kan, ní wákátì wákátì -- kìí ṣe sí àwọn tó ń pa ẹranko lọ́nà àìtọ́ nìkan ṣùgbọ́n ìṣúyọ rògbòdìyàn láàárín ènìyàn àti erin bí wọ́n ṣe ń jìjà-gùdù fún àyè àti ohun-èlò.

English: It's a massive challenge.
Yoruba: Ìdojúkọ tó tóbi ni.

English: I mean, how do you keep seven-ton pachyderms, that often come in groups of 10 or 12, out of these very small rural farms when you're dealing with people who are living on the very edge of poverty?
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, báwo lẹ ṣe lè tọ́jú tọ́ọ́nù méje àwọn ẹranko ńlá, tí wọ́n máa wá ní ikọ̀ ẹlẹ́ni mẹ́wà tàbí méjìlá ní gbogbo ìgbà, nínú àwọn oko agègbè kékèké wọ̀nyí nígbà tí ẹ bá ń lájọṣe pẹ̀lú àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń gbé ní ìkọ́gun òṣì?

English: They don't have big budgets.
Yoruba: Wọn ò ní ìṣúná tó tóbi.

English: How do you resolve this issue?
Yoruba: Báwo lẹ ṣelè yanjú ọ̀rọ̀ yìí?

English: Well, one issue is, you can just start to build electric fences, and this is happening across Africa, we're seeing this more and more.
Yoruba: Ó dáa, ìṣòro kan ni wí pé, ẹ lè bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní kọ́ àwọn ọgbà oníná, èyí sì ń ṣẹlẹ̀ káàkiri ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, à ń rí èyí lọ́pọ̀lọpọ̀.

English: But they are dividing up areas and blocking corridors.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n ń pín àwọn agbègbè wọ́n sì ń dí àwọn ẹnu ọ̀nà.

English: And I'm telling you, these elephants don't think much of it either, particularly if they're blocking a really special water hole where they need water, or if there's a very attractive female on the other side.
Yoruba: Mo sì ń sọ fún yín, àwọn erin wọ̀nyí ò ronú púpọ̀ nípa rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú, pàápàá jùlọ tí wọ́n bá ń dí ihò omi tó yátọ̀ níbi tí wọ́n ti nílò omi, tàbí tí abo tó wọjú gidi gan-an bá wà lódì kejì.

English: It doesn't take long to knock down one of these poles.
Yoruba: Kìí pẹ́ tí wọn ó fi ń wó ọ̀kan nínú àwọn òpó wọ̀nyí lulẹ̀.

English: And as soon as there's a gap in the fence, they go back, talk to their mates and suddenly they're all through, and now you have 12 elephants on the community side of the fence.
Yoruba: Ní kété tí àlàfo bá ti wà nínú ọgbà náà, wọ́n yóò padà, láti bá àwọn akẹgbẹ́ wọn sọ̀rọ̀ lójijì gbogbo wọ́n ki kọjá, báyìí a ní erin méjìlá ní òdì kejì ọgbà àwùjọ.

English: And now you're really in trouble.
Yoruba: Báyìí e ti wọ wàhálà.

English: People keep trying to come up with new designs for electric fences.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn túbọ̀ ń gbìyànjú láti wá àpẹrẹ tuntun fún ọgbà onínọ́.

English: Well, these elephants don't think much of those either.
Yoruba: Ó dáa, àwọn erin wọ̀nyí ò ronu púpọ̀ nípa àwọn wọ̀nyẹn pẹ̀lú.

English: So rather than having these hard-line, straight, electric, really divisive migratory-blocking fences, there must be other ways to look at this challenge.
Yoruba: Dípò níní àwọn ọgbà gbọọrọ, onínọ́, tó ń ṣe ìpínyà tó sì ń dénà ìṣíkiri, ọ̀na mìíràn gbọ́dọ̀ wà láti wo ìdojúkọ yìí.

English: I'm much more interested in holistic and natural methods to keep elephants and people apart where necessary.
Yoruba: Mo nífẹ̀ púpọ̀ sí ìlànà apapọ̀ àti àdámọ́ láti ya erin àti ènìyàn sọ́tọ̀ níbi tó bá yẹ.

English: Simply talking to people, talking to rural pastoralists in northern Kenya who have so much knowledge about the bush, we discovered this story that they had that elephants would not feed on trees that had wild beehives in them.
Yoruba: Bíbá àwọn ènìyàn sọ̀rọ̀, bíbá àwọn adaranjẹ̀ agbègbè ní àríwa orílẹ̀-ède Kenya tí wọ́n ní ìmọ̀ tó pọ̀ nípa ìgbẹ́ sọ̀rọ̀, a ṣàwárí ìtàn yìí tí wọ́n gbọ́ pé àwọn erin ò ní jẹ igi tí afárá-oyin bá wà nínú rẹ̀.

English: Now this was an interesting story.
Yoruba: Ìtàn tó panilẹ́rìn lèyìí.

English: As the elephants were foraging on the tree, they would break branches and perhaps break open a wild beehive.
Yoruba: Bí àwọn erin ṣe ń wá oúnjẹ kiri lára igi, wọ́n máa gé ẹ̀ka àti bóyá wọ́n á gé afárá oyin tó burú.

English: And those bees would fly out of their natural nests and sting the elephants.
Yoruba: Àwọn oyin yìí máa fò jáde kúrò nínú ilé àdámọ́ wọn wọn ó sì ta erin náà.

English: Now if the elephants got stung, perhaps they would remember that this tree was dangerous and they wouldn't come back to that same site.
Yoruba: Bí wọ́n bá ta erin náà, bóyá wọ́n máa ràntí pé igi yìí léwu wọn ò sì ní padà sí agbègbè yẹn mọ́.

English: It seems impossible that they could be stung through their thick skin -- elephant skin is around two centimeters thick.
Yoruba: Ó jọ bí ẹni wí pé kò ṣe é ṣe pé wọ́n lè tawọ́n níbi awọ wọn tó nípọ̀n -- awọ erin nípọn tó sẹ̀ntímítà méjì.

English: But it seems that they sting them around the watery areas, around the eyes, behind the ears, in the mouth, up the trunk.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó dàbí eni pé wọ́n máa ń ta wọ́n ní àwọn àyè tó lómi, níbi ojú, lẹ́yìn eti, ní ẹnu, àti ní òke owójà wọn.

English: You can imagine they would remember that very quickly.
Yoruba: Ẹ lè wòye wí pé wọn máa rántí ìyẹn kíákíá.

English: And it's not really one sting that they're scared of.
Yoruba: Kìí ṣe títa ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo ló ń bàwọ́n lẹ́rù.

English: African bees have a phenomenal ability: when they sting in one site, they release a pheromone that triggers the rest of the bees to come and sting the same site.
Yoruba: Àwọn oyin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní ipa tóyátọ̀: tí wọ́n bá tá nǹkan ní àyè kan, wọn yóò tu kẹ́míkà tí yóò ṣe okùnfa kí àwọn oyin tókù wá ta nǹkan náà ní àyè kan náà.

English: So it's not one beesting that they're scared of -- it's perhaps thousands of beestings, coming to sting in the same area -- that they're afraid of.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà kìí ṣe títa oyin ló ń bà wọ́n lẹ́rù -- bóyá títa ẹgbẹ̀rún oyin, tí wọ́n ń bọ̀ wá ta á ní àyè kan náà -- ló ń bà wọ́n lẹ́rù.

English: And of course, a good matriarch would always keep her young away from such a threat.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́, obìnrin olórí ilé tó dára yóò mú àwọn omọ rẹ̀ kúrò níbi irú ewu bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Young calves have much thinner skins, and it's potential that they could be stung through their thinner skins.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ erin máa ń ní awọ tó tírín díẹ̀, ó sì ṣe é ṣe pé kí wọ́n tawọ́n ní àwọn awọ tó tínrín yìí.

English: So for my PhD, I had this unusual challenge of trying to work out how African elephants and African bees would interact, when the theory was that they wouldn't interact at all.
Yoruba: Fún oyè òmọ̀wé mi, mo ní ìdojúkọ tó ṣọ̀wọ́n nínú ìgbìyànjú láti wá ọ̀nà àbáyọ sí bí àwọn erin nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti àwọn oyin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ṣe lè ní àjọṣepọ̀, nígbà tí tíọ́rì náà jẹ́ wí pé wọn ò lè ní àjọṣepọ̀ rárá.

English: How was I going to study this?
Yoruba: Báwo ni mo ṣe fẹ́ ṣẹ̀wádi èléyìí?

English: Well, what I did was I took the sound of disturbed African honey bees, and I played it back to elephants resting under trees through a wireless speaker system, so I could understand how they would react as if there were wild bees in the area.
Yoruba: Ó dáa, nǹkan tí mo ṣe ni pé mo mú ohùn àwọn oyin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó ń dàmú, mo wá pílé rẹ̀ padà fún àwọn erin tí wọ́n ń simi lábẹ́ igi nínú ẹ̀rọ-gbohùngbohùn tí ò ní wáyà, kín lè mọ bí wọn ó ṣe sẹ tó bá ṣe wí pé oyin tó burú bá wà ní agbègbè náà.

English: And it turns out that they react quite dramatically to the sound of African wild bees.
Yoruba: Àbájáde rè ni wí pé wọ́n húwà tó jọ bí eré sí ohùn àwọn oyin ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó burú.

English: Here we are, playing the bee sounds back to this amazing group of elephants.
Yoruba: Àwa rè é, tí à ń pílè ohùn oyin padà fún ẹgbẹ́ àwọn oyin tí wọ́n yanilẹ́nu yìí.

English: You can see the ears going up, going out, they're turning their heads from side to side, one elephant is flicking her trunk to try and smell.
Yoruba: Ẹ rí bí etí wọn ṣe ń lọ sókè, tó ń jáde, tí wọ́n ń yí orí wọn láti apákan sí ìkejì, erin kan ń fi ọwọ́ja rẹ̀ láti gbìyànjú lati gbóòrún.

English: There's another elephant that kicks one of calves on the ground to tell it to get up as if there is a threat.
Yoruba: Erin mìíràn wà tó ń ta ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ọmọ rẹ̀ tó wà nílẹ̀ nípà láti sọ fún-un wí pé kó dìde bí ẹni pé ewú wà.

English: And one elephant triggers a retreat, and soon the whole family of elephants are running after her across the savannah in a cloud of dust.
Yoruba: Erin kan ń gbíyànjú láti sá sẹ́yìn, láìpẹ́ gbogbo ẹbí erin ti ń sá tẹ̀le fòna nínú ẹ̀ṣú eruku.

English: (Sound of bees buzzing)
Yoruba: (ohùn oyin tó ń kùn).

English: (Sound of bees ends)
Yoruba: (ohùn oyin ti parí).

English: Now I've done this experiment many, many times, and the elephants almost always flee.
Yoruba: Mo ti ṣe ìdánwò yìí láìmọye ìgbà, àwọn erin náà fẹ́rẹ̀ lè sálọ ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: Not only do they run away, but they dust themselves as they're running, as if to knock bees out of the air.
Yoruba: Kìí ṣe pé wọ́n sálọ nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n máa ń gbọnra bí wọ́n ṣe ńsálọ, bí ẹni pé wọ́n ń gbọn oyin danù.

English: And we placed infrasonic microphones around the elephants as we did these experiments.
Yoruba: A gbé àwọn ẹ̀rọ agbohùn kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ sí ọrùn àwọn erin náà bí a ṣe ń ṣe àyẹ̀wò wọ̀nyí.

English: And it turns out they're communicating to each other in infrasonic rumbles to warn each other of the threat of bees and to stay away from the area.
Yoruba: Àbájáde rẹ̀ ni wí pé wọ́n ń bá ara wọn sọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìkùn kẹ́lẹ́kẹ́lẹ́ láti kira wọn nílọ̀ nípa ewu oyin àti jíjínà sí agbègbè náà.

English: So these behavioral discoveries really helped us understand how elephants would react should they hear or see bee sounds.
Yoruba: Àwọn àwárí ìṣesí wọ̀nyí rànwá lọ́wọ́ gan-an láti ní òye bí àwọn erin ṣe ń húwà tí wọ́n bá fi lè gbọ́ ohùn oyin.

English: This led me to invent a novel design for a beehive fence, which we are now building around small, one-to-two-acre farms on the most vulnerable frontline areas of Africa where humans and elephants are competing for space.
Yoruba: Èyí ló darí mi láti ṣẹ̀da ìṣelọ́jọ̀ ọgbà afárá oyin àkọ́kọ́ṣe, tí à ń kọ́ nísinyìí káàkiri àwọn saare ilẹ̀ kan sí méjì oko kékèèké, ní àwọn àyè tí wọ́n léwájú ìkángun-séwu nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ níbi tí àwọn ènìyàn àti erin ti ń jìjàgùdù fún àyè.

English: These beehive fences are very, very simple.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọgbà afárá oyin wọ̀nyí rọrùn gidi gaan.

English: We use 12 beehives and 12 dummy hives to protect one acre of farmland.
Yoruba: A lo afárá oyin méjílà àti ẹ̀da afárá oyin méjílà láti dáààbòbo saare ilẹ̀-oko kan.

English: Now a dummy hive is simply a piece of plywood which we cut into squares, paint yellow and hang in between the hives.
Yoruba: Báyìí igi pilaiwúdù kan tí a gé sí igun mẹ́rin ni ẹ̀da afárá oyin, tí a kùn ní àwọ ayìnrín tí a fi há sáàrín afárá-oyin náà.

English: We're basically tricking the elephants into thinking there are more beehives than there really are.
Yoruba: À ń tan àwọn erin náà láti rò wí pé ilé oyin pọ̀ níbẹ̀ ju bó ṣe yẹ lọ.

English: And of course, it literally halves the cost of the fence.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni, ó sọ iye owó ọgbà náà di àbọ̀.

English: So there's a hive and a dummy hive and a beehive and now dummy hive, every 10 meters around the outside boundary.
Yoruba: Afárá kan àti ẹ̀da afárá àti afárá-òyin àti ẹ̀da afárá ló wà, ní gbogbo mítà mẹ́wà yíká ààlà ìta.

English: They're held up by posts with a shade roof to protect the bees, and they're interconnected with a simple piece of plain wire, which goes all the way around, connecting the hives.
Yoruba: Àwọn igi ló gbé wọn dúró pẹ̀lú òrùle abòji láti dáààbòbo àwọn oyin, wọ́n sì sopọ̀ pẹ̀lú ògidi wáyà kékeré kan, tó lọ yíká, tó so àwọn afárá oyin náà papọ̀.

English: So if an elephant tries to enter the farm, he will avoid the beehive at all cost, but he might try and push through between the hive and the dummy hive, causing all the beehives to swing as the wire hits his chest.
Yoruba: Bí erin kan bá gbìyànjú láti wọ oko náà, yóò sá fún afárá oyin náà lọ́nà kọnà, ṣùgbọ́n ó lè gbìyànjú láti kọjá láàárín afárá oyin àti ẹ̀da afárá oyin náà, tí yóò mú kí àwọn ilé oyin náà ó sún bí wáyà náà bá ṣe ń ba àya rẹ̀.

English: And as we know from our research work, this will cause the elephants to flee and run away -- and hopefully remember not to come back to that risky area.
Yoruba: Bí a ṣe mọ̀ látara iṣẹ́ ìwádìí wa, èyí máa jẹ́ kí erin náà sá kó sì feré ge – pẹ̀lú ìrètí wí pé yóò rántí láti má padà wá sí agbègbe ewu yẹn.

English: The bees swarm out of the hive, and they really scare the elephants away.
Yoruba: Àwọn oyin náà máa ṣùrù jáde nínú afárá náà, wọ́n ó sì lé erin náà lọ.

English: These beehive fences we're studying using things like camera traps to help us understand how elephants are responding to them at night time, which is when most of the crop raiding occurs.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọgbà afárá oyin tí à ń ṣe ìwádìí rẹ̀ pẹ̀lu lílo àwọn nǹkan bíi pánpẹ́ ayàwòrán láti jẹ́ ká ní òye bí àwọn erin ṣe ń húwà sí wọn lálẹ́, tó jẹ́ àsìkò tí jíjẹ nǹkan ọ̀gbìn máa ń ṣẹlẹ̀ jù.

English: And we found in our study farms that we're keeping up to 80 percent of elephants outside of the boundaries of these farms.
Yoruba: A rí i nínú àwọn oko ìwádìí wa wí pé à ń lé tó ìdá ọgọ́rin erin síta ààlà àwọn oko wọ̀nyí.

English: And the bees and the beehive fences are also pollinating the fields.
Yoruba: Àwọn oyin àti ọgbà afárá oyin náà ń gbọn ìyẹ̀rin sóri ilẹ̀ náà.

English: So we're having a great reduction both in elephant crop raids and a boost in yield through the pollination services that the bees are giving to the crops themselves.
Yoruba: À ń ní àdínkù tó pọ̀ nínú ìjẹko erin àti àlékún nínú irè oko nípasẹ̀ iṣẹ́ gbíbọn ìyẹ̀rin tí àwọn oyin náà ń fún àwọn nǹkan ọ̀gbìn fúnra wọn.

English: The strength of the beehive fences is really important -- the colonies have to be very strong.
Yoruba: Agbára ọgbà afárá oyin náà ṣe pàtàkì gidi gan-an -- àwọn ilé náà ní láti lágbára gidi gan-an.

English: So we're trying to help farmers grow pollinator-friendly crops to boost their hives, boost the strength of their bees and, of course, produce the most amazing honey.
Yoruba: À ń gbìyànjú láti bá àwọn àgbẹ̀ gbin àwọn irè-oko tí wọ́n bá ìyẹ̀rin rẹ́ láti ṣàlékún agbára afárá wọn, lóòótọ́, pèse oyin tó dára jù.

English: This honey is so valuable as an extra livelihood income for the farmers.
Yoruba: Oyin yìí lówó lórí gidi gan-an gẹ́gẹ́ bi àfikún ìpawówọlé fún àwọn àgbẹ̀.

English: It's a healthy alternative to sugar, and in our community, it's a very valuable present to give a mother-in-law, which makes it almost priceless.
Yoruba: Arọ́pò tó dára ló jẹ́ fún ṣúgà, ní àwùjọ wa, ẹ̀bùn tó jọjú ló jẹ́ láti fún ìyá-ìyàwo wa, tó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ sọ ọ́ di nǹkan olówó iye-bíye.

English: We now bottle up this honey, and we've called this wild beautiful honey Elephant-Friendly Honey.
Yoruba: A ti ń pọn oyin yìí sínú ìgò, a sì ti pe oyin búburú tó rẹwà yìí ní Oyin Abérin Sọ̀rẹ́.

English: It is a fun name, but it also attracts attention to our project and helps people understand what we're trying to do to save elephants.
Yoruba: Orúkọ tó panilẹ́rìn ni, ṣùgbọ́n ó tún pe àkíyèsí sí iṣẹ́ àkànṣe wa ó dẹ̀ ń ran àwọn ènìyàn lọ́wọ́ láti ní òye nǹkan tí à ń gbìyànjú láti ṣe láti dóòla àwọn erin.

English: We're working now with so many women in over 60 human-elephant conflict sites in 19 countries in Africa and Asia to build these beehive fences, working very, very closely with so many farmers but particularly now with women farmers, helping them to live better in harmony with elephants.
Yoruba: À ń ṣiṣẹ́ pọ̀ pẹ̀lú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn obìnrin ní àwọn àyè rògbòdìyàn ènìyàn àti ẹranko tó lé ní ọgọ́ta ní orílẹ̀-èdè mọ́kàn-dín-lógún nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti Asia láti kọ́ àwọn ọgbà afárá oyin wọ̀nyí, à ń ṣiṣẹ́ papọ̀ pẹ̀lú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn agbẹ̀ ṣùgbọ́n ní pàápàah jùlọ báyìí pẹ̀lú àwọn àgbẹ̀ lóbìnrin, ríràn wọ́n lọ́wọ́ láti gbé ní ìrẹ́pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn erin.

English: One of the things we're trying to do is develop a toolbox of options to live in better harmony with these massive pachyderms.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan nínú àwọn nǹkan tí à ń gbìyànjú láti ṣe ni láti pèse àpótí-irinṣẹ́ oní yíyàn kan láti túbọ̀ gbé ní ìrẹ́pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹranko ńlá wọ̀nyí.

English: One of those issues is to try and get farmers, and women in particular, to think different about what they're planting inside their farms as well.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan nínú ìṣoro yẹn ni láti rí àwọn àgbẹ̀, ní pátàkì jùlọ àwọn obìnrin, láti ní ìrónú tó yátọ̀ nípa nǹkan tí wọ́n ń gbìn sínú oko wọn bákan náà.

English: So we're looking at planting crops that elephants don't particularly want to eat, like chillies, ginger, Moringa, sunflowers.
Yoruba: À ń wo ṣíṣe ọ̀gbin àwọn irè oko tí àwọn erin ní pàtàkì jùlọ ò fẹ́ jẹ, bíi ata, ata ilẹ̀, mọ̀ríńgà, àti òdòdó-oòrùn.

English: And of course, the bees and the beehive fences love these crops too, because they have beautiful flowers.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́ ni, àwọn oyin àti àwọn ọgbà afárá oyin fẹ́ràn àwọn irè-oko wọ̀nyìí pẹ̀lú, nítorí pé wọ́n ní àwọn òdòdó tó rẹwà.

English: One of these plants is a spiky plant called sisal -- you may know this here as jute.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan nínú àwọn nkan ọ̀gbìn wọ̀nyí jẹ́ àwọn nǹkan-ọ̀gbìn tó máa ń pọ̀ tí wọ́n ń pè ní sísun -- ẹ lè mọ èyí sí júútì níbí yìí.

English: And this amazing plant can be stripped down and turned into a weaving product.
Yoruba: Nǹkan ọ̀gbìn tó dára yìí lè di bíbọ́ sí hòhò ká sì yi padà sí èròja híhun.

English: We're working with these amazing women now who live daily with the challenges of elephants to use this plant to weave into baskets to provide an alternative income for them.
Yoruba: À ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn obìnrin tí wọ́n dára báyìí tí wọ́n ń gbé pẹ̀lú ìdojúkọ àwọn erin ẹ̀da afárá oyin jẹ́ láti lo àwọn nǹkan ọ̀gbìn yìí láti hun apẹ̀rẹ̀ láti pèse apààrọ̀ ìpawówọlé fún wọn.

English: We've just started construction only three weeks ago on a women's enterprise center where we're going to be working with these women not only as expert beekeepers but as amazing basket weavers; they're going to be processing chili oils, sunflower oils, making lip balms and honey, and we're somewhere on our way to helping these participating farmers live with better eco-generating projects that live and work better with living with elephants.
Yoruba: A ṣẹ̀ bẹ̀rè síní kọ́ ọ ní bíi ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́ta sẹ́yìn sí àyè ilé-iṣẹ́ àwọn obìnrin níbi tí a ó ti máa ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn obìnrin wọ̀nyí tí kìí ṣe gẹ́gẹ́ bi òjìni olùtọ́jú-oyin nìkan ṣùgbọ́n gẹ́gẹ́ bi oníṣẹ́ ọnà apẹ̀rẹ̀; wọn yóò ma pèse òróró ṣílì, òróró òdòdó-oòrùn, ṣíṣe ìpara ètè àti oyin, a wà níbìkan lójú ọ̀nà láti ran àwọn àgbẹ̀ tí wọ́n ń kópa wọ̀nyí lọ́wọ́ láti ní ìgbeayé tó dára pẹ̀lú àwọn iṣẹ́-àkànṣe tó ń pèsè ọjọ̀ tó dára tí yóò ma gbé tí yóó sì ma ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú ìgbépọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn erin.

English: So whether it's matriarchs or mothers or researchers like myself, I do see more women coming to the forefront now to think differently and more boldly about the challenges that we face.
Yoruba: Torí náà bóyá àwọn obìnrin olórí ilé ni tàbí àwọn abiyamọ tàbí àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí bíi tèmi, mo máa ń rí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn obìnrin tí wọ́n ń léwájú báyìí láti ronú lọ́nà ọ̀tọ̀ tí wọ́n sì ní ìgboyà si nípa àwọn ìdojúkọ tí à ń kojú.

English: With more innovation, and perhaps with some more empathy towards each other, I do believe we can move from a state of conflict with elephants to true coexistence.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ìṣẹdá lọ́pọ̀, àti bóyá pẹ̀lú àánú fún arawa, mo nígbàgbọ́ pé a lẹ̀ sún láti rògbòdìyàn pẹ̀lú erin sí àjọgbépọ̀ tòótọ́.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ seun.

English: Will automation take away all our jobs?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ àdáṣe lè gba gbogbo iṣẹ́ wa lọ?

English: Here's a startling fact: in the 45 years since the introduction of the automated teller machine, those vending machines that dispense cash, the number of human bank tellers employed in the United States has roughly doubled, from about a quarter of a million to a half a million.
Yoruba: Òdodo-ọ̀rọ̀ tó yanilẹ́nu rè é: ní bíi ọdún márùn-lé-lógójì látígbà tí wọ́n ti ṣàfihàn ẹ̀rọ tó ń pọwó, àwọn ẹ̀rọ tó máa ń pọwó jáde wọ̀nyí, iye àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń gbà láti máa kawó ní orílẹ̀-ède United State ti di ìlọ́po méjì, láti bí ìdá mẹ́rin ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún di ìdajì àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́.

English: A quarter of a million in 1970 to about a half a million today, with 100,000 added since the year 2000.
Yoruba: Ìdá 4 àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ ní ọdún 1970 sí bíi ìdajì ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún lónìí, pẹ̀lú àfikún ẹgbẹ̀rún lọ́nà ọgọ́rùn láti ọdún 2000.

English: These facts, revealed in a recent book by Boston University economist James Bessen, raise an intriguing question: what are all those tellers doing, and why hasn't automation eliminated their employment by now?
Yoruba: Àwọn òdodo wọ̀nyí, tí wọ́n yojú rẹ̀ síta nínú ìwe onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé ní fásitì Boston James Bassen, béèrè ìbéèrè t’ó bà mí lẹ́rù: kíni àwọn tí wọ́n ń sanwó wọ̀nyẹn ń ṣe, kí l’ó fà á tí ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ-àdáṣiṣẹ́ ò ṣe tíì gbaṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́ wọn lásíkò yìí?

English: If you think about it, many of the great inventions of the last 200 years were designed to replace human labor.
Yoruba: Bí ẹ bá ronú nípa rẹ̀, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìṣẹ̀dá ńlá láti bíi igba odún sẹ́yìn ni wọ́n ṣe láti rọ́pò iṣẹ́ ọmọ ènìyàn.

English: Tractors were developed to substitute mechanical power for human physical toil.
Yoruba: A ṣẹ̀da ọkọ̀ katakata ìdáko láti fi agbára ẹ̀rọ rọ́pò làálàá agbára kíkan ọmọ ènìyàn.

English: Assembly lines were engineered to replace inconsistent human handiwork with machine perfection.
Yoruba: A ṣẹ̀da ibi-ìtọkọ̀-papọ̀ láti fi ìṣedéédéé ẹ̀rọ rọ́pò àìṣedéédéé iṣẹ́-ọwọ́ ọmọ ènìyàn.

English: Computers were programmed to swap out error-prone, inconsistent human calculation with digital perfection.
Yoruba: A kọ-èdè-ìṣiṣẹ́ ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá láti pààrọ àṣìṣe, àìṣedéédéé ìṣirò ọmọ ènìyàn pẹ̀lú àìṣedéédéé ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá ìgbàlódé.

English: These inventions have worked.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọgbọ́n ìpilẹ̀ṣe wọ̀nyí ti ṣiṣẹ́.

English: We no longer dig ditches by hand, pound tools out of wrought iron or do bookkeeping using actual books.
Yoruba: A ò fi ọwọ́ gbẹ́ kótò mọ́, k’á lu irinṣẹ́ jáde látara akọ irin tàbí k’á fi àwọn ìwé gangan ṣe ìfìwépamọ́.

English: And yet, the fraction of US adults employed in the labor market is higher now in 2016 than it was 125 years ago, in 1890, and it's risen in just about every decade in the intervening 125 years.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀, apá kan àwọn àgbàlagbà tí wọ́n ń gbà ní ọjà òṣìṣẹ́ ti ga báyìí ní ọdún 2016 ju bí ó ṣe wà ní ọdún márùn-ún-lé-lọ́gọ́fà sẹ́yìn, ní ọdún 1890, ó sì ń lékún ní gbogbo ẹ̀wá ọdún láàárín ọdún márùn-ún-lé-lọ́gọ́fà náà.

English: This poses a paradox.
Yoruba: Èyí ń ṣe àfihàn ajọ̀ró-ṣòótọ́.

English: Our machines increasingly do our work for us.
Yoruba: Àwọn ẹ̀rọ wa ń ṣe àlékún iṣẹ́ wa fún wà.

English: Why doesn't this make our labor redundant and our skills obsolete?
Yoruba: Kí ló dé tí èyí ò ṣe jẹ́ kí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ó léélẹ̀ kí ìmọ́ṣe wa ó sì má wúlò mọ́?

English: Why are there still so many jobs?
Yoruba: Kí ló dé tí iṣẹ́ ṣì ṣe pọ̀?

English: I'm going to try to answer that question tonight, and along the way, I'm going to tell you what this means for the future of work and the challenges that automation does and does not pose for our society.
Yoruba: Mà á gbìyànjú láti dáhùn ìbéèrè yẹn lálẹ́ yìí, bí a bá ṣe ń ṣe èyí, màá sọ nǹkan tí èyí túmọ̀ sí fún ọjọ́-iwájú iṣẹ́ àti ìdojúkọ tí ìdáṣe ń ṣe àti àwọn tí kò sí fún àwùjọ wa.

English: Why are there so many jobs?
Yoruba: Kí ló dé tí iṣẹ́ ṣe pọ̀.

English: There are actually two fundamental economic principles at stake.
Yoruba: Ìlàna ọrọ̀-ajé tó ṣe pàtàkì méjì ló wà nínú ewu.

English: One has to do with human genius and creativity.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan ní ṣe pẹ̀lú ọpọlọ ọmọ ènìyàn àti ọgbọ́n àtinúdá.

English: The other has to do with human insatiability, or greed, if you like.
Yoruba: Ìkejì níṣe pẹ̀lu àìláyo-ọkàn ọmọ ènìyàn, ọ̀kánjúà, tí ẹ bá fẹ́.

English: I'm going to call the first of these the O-ring principle, and it determines the type of work that we do.
Yoruba: Màá pe àkọ́kọ́ nínú àwọn yìí ní ìlàna òrùka-O, ó sì máa ń ṣe okùnfa irú iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe.

English: The second principle is the never-get-enough principle, and it determines how many jobs there actually are.
Yoruba: Ìlànà kejì ni ìlàna kòtó, ó sì máa ń ṣe okùnfa iye iṣẹ́ tó wà.

English: Let's start with the O-ring.
Yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ ká bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú òrùka-O.

English: ATMs, automated teller machines, had two countervailing effects on bank teller employment.
Yoruba: Àwọn ATM, ẹ̀rọ tó ń dá pọwó, ní ipa alágbára méjì lára ìgbanisíṣẹ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ ilé-ìfowópamọ́ tí wọ́n ń fúni lówó.

English: As you would expect, they replaced a lot of teller tasks.
Yoruba: Bí ẹ ṣe ń retí rẹ̀, wọ́n rọ́pọ̀ ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iṣẹ́ àwọn tí wọ́n ń fúni lówó.

English: The number of tellers per branch fell by about a third.
Yoruba: Iye àwọn tí wọ́n ń fúnni lówó ní ẹ̀ka kọ̀ọ̀kan dínkù pẹ̀lú ìdá mẹ́ta.

English: But banks quickly discovered that it also was cheaper to open new branches, and the number of bank branches increased by about 40 percent in the same time period.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ilé-ìfowópamọ́ padà ri wí pé ó rọjú láti ṣí ẹ̀ka tuntun, iye ẹ̀ka ilé-ìfowópamọ́ lékún pẹ̀lú bíi ìdá ogójì ní àsìkò kan náà.

English: The net result was more branches and more tellers.
Yoruba: Èsì àpapọ̀ ni wí pé bí ẹ̀ka ṣe ń pọ̀ si ni àwọn tí wọ́n ń fúni lówó náà ń pọ̀ si.

English: But those tellers were doing somewhat different work.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn tí wọ́n ń fúni lówó yìí ń ṣiṣẹ́ ọ̀tọ̀.

English: As their routine, cash-handling tasks receded, they became less like checkout clerks and more like salespeople, forging relationships with customers, solving problems and introducing them to new products like credit cards, loans and investments: more tellers doing a more cognitively demanding job.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bi ojúṣe wọn, iṣẹ́ gbígba-owó dínkù, wọn ò yàtọ̀ sí agbowó wọ́n sì jọ abánitajà, níní àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn oníbàráà, yíyanjú àwọn ìṣòro àti ṣíṣe àfihàn àwọn ohun-èlò ọ̀tun bíi ike-ìgbawó, owó-ìyá àti ìdókòwò: ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn afúni lówó tí wọ́n ń ṣe àwọn iṣẹ́ tó gba ọpọlọ.

English: There's a general principle here.
Yoruba: Ìlànà àpapọ̀ wà níbí.

English: Most of the work that we do requires a multiplicity of skills, and brains and brawn, technical expertise and intuitive mastery, perspiration and inspiration in the words of Thomas Edison.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe ló gba ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe lọ́pọ̀, àti ọpọ̀lọ àti agbára, òjìni onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ àti ọpọlọ ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe, ìlàágùn àti ìmísí nínú ọ̀rọ Thomas Edison.

English: In general, automating some subset of those tasks doesn't make the other ones unnecessary.
Yoruba: Lápapọ̀, ìdáṣe àwọn àtúnpín sẹ́ẹ́tì àwọn iṣẹ́ wọ̀nyẹn ò ní sọ àwọn tókù di aláìṣe pàtàkì.

English: In fact, it makes them more important.
Yoruba: Ní tòótọ́, ó máa ń jẹ́ kí wọ́n ṣe pàtàkì si ni.

English: It increases their economic value.
Yoruba: Ó máa ń ṣe àfikún ìwúlò ọrọ̀-ajé wọn ni.

English: Let me give you a stark example.
Yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ kín fún-un yín ní àpẹẹrẹ kan tó fojú hàn.

English: In 1986, the space shuttle Challenger exploded and crashed back down to Earth less than two minutes after takeoff.
Yoruba: Ní ọdún 1986, ọkọ̀ òfuurufú oníjà gbiná ó sì já padà sí ayé lẹ́yìn bí ìṣẹ́jú méjì tó gbéra.

English: The cause of that crash, it turned out, was an inexpensive rubber O-ring in the booster rocket that had frozen on the launchpad the night before and failed catastrophically moments after takeoff.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tó ṣokùnfa jíjá yẹn, àbájáde rẹ̀, jẹ́ rọ́bà òrùka-O tí kìí ràn nínú afún rọ́kẹ́tì lágbára tó ti dì sóri páádì-ìgbéra lálẹ́ẹ ó kọ̀la tó sì kọṣẹ́ lọ́nà tó léwu ní àsìkò díẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tó gbéra.

English: In this multibillion dollar enterprise that simple rubber O-ring made the difference between mission success and the calamitous death of seven astronauts.
Yoruba: Ní ilé-iṣẹ́ ọlọ́pọ̀ bílíọ̀nu dọ́là tí rọ́bà òrùka-O lásán ti ṣe ìyàtọ̀ láàárín iṣẹ́ tó yege àti àjálù ikú àwọn arédùmarè méje.

English: An ingenious metaphor for this tragic setting is the O-ring production function, named by Harvard economist Michael Kremer after the Challenger disaster.
Yoruba: Ojúlówó àfiwé ẹlẹ́lọ̀ọ́ fún ibùdó ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ burúkú yìí ni ojúṣe ìṣẹ̀da òrùka-O, tí onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé Michael Kremer fún lórúkọ lẹ́yìn àjálù burúkú àwọn oníja.

English: The O-ring production function conceives of the work as a series of interlocking steps, links in a chain.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ìpèsè òrùka-O fa ìròrí iṣẹ́ náà gẹ́gẹ́ bí oríṣiríṣi ìgbésẹ̀ tó wọnú ara wọn, tí wọ́n sopọ̀ nínú okùn kan.

English: Every one of those links must hold for the mission to succeed.
Yoruba: Ìkọ̀ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìsopọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn gbọ́dọ̀ ṣẹlẹ̀ kí iṣẹ́ náà lè di àṣeyọrí.

English: If any of them fails, the mission, or the product or the service, comes crashing down.
Yoruba: Bí ìkànkan nínú wọn bá kúnà, iṣẹ́ náà, tàbí ohun-èlò tàbí iṣẹ́ náà, yóò já lulẹ̀.

English: This precarious situation has a surprisingly positive implication, which is that improvements in the reliability of any one link in the chain increases the value of improving any of the other links.
Yoruba: Ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ aṣe é ṣe yìí ní àpadàbọ̀ rere tó yani lẹ́nu, tó ṣe wí pé àtúnṣe nínú ìgbáralé ìkọ̀ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìsopọ̀ náà máa ṣe àfikún ìwúlò àtúnṣe ìkànkan àwọn ìsopọ̀ yókù.

English: Concretely, if most of the links are brittle and prone to breakage, the fact that your link is not that reliable is not that important.
Yoruba: Ní àrídìmú, tí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ìsopọ̀ náà bá le tí wọ́n sì lè kán, pàápàá pé ìsopọ̀ yín ò ṣé gbáralé ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ṣe pàtàkì.

English: Probably something else will break anyway.
Yoruba: Bóyá nǹkan mìíràn ló máa kán báyẹn.

English: But as all the other links become robust and reliable, the importance of your link becomes more essential.
Yoruba: S̀ùgbọ́n bí àwọn ìsopọ̀ tókù ṣe ń tóbi síi tí wọ́n sì ṣe é gbáralé, pàtàki ìsopọ̀ yín yóò túbọ̀ wúlò si.

English: In the limit, everything depends upon it.
Yoruba: Ní gbèdéke, gbogbo nǹkan ló gbára lé e.

English: The reason the O-ring was critical to space shuttle Challenger is because everything else worked perfectly.
Yoruba: Ìdí tí òrùka-O ṣe ṣe pàtàkì sí àwọn ọkọ̀ òfuurufú oníjà ni wí pé gbogbo nǹkan tókù ló ṣiṣẹ́ dáadáa.

English: If the Challenger were kind of the space era equivalent of Microsoft Windows 2000 --the reliability of the O-ring wouldn't have mattered because the machine would have crashed.
Yoruba: Bí àwọn oníjà náà bá jẹ́ adọ́gba pẹ̀lú Microsoft Window ọdún 2000 -- ìgbáralé òrùka-O ò ní kàn wọ́n nítorí ẹ̀rọ náà yóò ti já lulẹ̀.

English: Here's the broader point.
Yoruba: Kókó-ọ̀rọ̀ tó tún fẹjú rè é.

English: In much of the work that we do, we are the O-rings.
Yoruba: Nínú ọ̀pọ̀lọ pọ̀ iṣẹ́ tí à ń ṣe, àwa ni òrùka-O.

English: Yes, ATMs could do certain cash-handling tasks faster and better than tellers, but that didn't make tellers superfluous.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn ẹ̀rọ ATM lè yára ṣe àwọn iṣẹ́ ju àwọn tí wọ́n ń fún ni lówó lọ, ṣùgbọ́n ìyẹn ò sọ àwọn tí wọ́n ń fún ni lówó di aláìwúlò.

English: It increased the importance of their problem-solving skills and their relationships with customers.
Yoruba: Ó ń ṣe àfikún sí pàtàki ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe ìyanjú-ìṣòro wọn àti àjọṣepọ̀ wọn pẹ̀lú àwọn oníbàárà.

English: The same principle applies if we're building a building, if we're diagnosing and caring for a patient, or if we are teaching a class to a roomful of high schoolers.
Yoruba: Irú ìlànà bẹ́ẹ̀ la máa lò tí a bá ń kọ́ ilé kan, tí a bá ń ṣe àyẹ̀wò tí a sì ń ṣe ìtọ́jú àwọn aláìsàn, tàbí tí a bá ń kọ́ kílásì àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní ilé-ìwe girama tó kún dẹ́nu.

English: As our tools improve, technology magnifies our leverage and increases the importance of our expertise and our judgment and our creativity.
Yoruba: Bi irinṣẹ́ ṣe ń dàgbá sókè, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí ṣe àfikún agbára wa ó sì ti ṣe àfikún sí pàtàkì ìmọ̀-òjìni wa àti ìdájọ́ wa àti ọgbọ́n àtinúdá wa.

English: And that brings me to the second principle: never get enough.
Yoruba: Èyí ló mú mi lọ síbi ìlànà kejì: kòtó.

English: You may be thinking, OK, O-ring, got it, that says the jobs that people do will be important.
Yoruba: Ẹ lè máa rò wí pé, ó dára, òrùka-O, ó yémi, tó sọ wí pé àwọn iṣẹ́ tí àwọn ènìyàn ń ṣe máa ṣe pàtàkì.

English: They can't be done by machines, but they still need to be done.
Yoruba: Àwọn ẹ̀rọ ò lè ṣe wọ́n, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n ṣì gbọdọ̀ di ṣíṣe.

English: But that doesn't tell me how many jobs there will need to be.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ìyen ò sọ fún mi iye iṣẹ́ tí yóò wà.

English: If you think about it, isn't it kind of self-evident that once we get sufficiently productive at something, we've basically worked our way out of a job?
Yoruba: Tí ẹ bá ronú nípa ẹ̀, ṣé kò fojú hàn pé tí a bá ti rí nǹkan ṣe, a ti wá ọ̀nà wa jáde kúrò níbi iṣẹ́ yẹn?

English: In 1900, 40 percent of all US employment was on farms.
Yoruba: Ní ọdún 1900, ìdá ogójì gbogbo ìgbanisíṣẹ́ ní orílẹ̀-ède US jẹ́ lórí oko.

English: Today, it's less than two percent.
Yoruba: Lónì, ó ti dínkù ní ìdá méjì.

English: Why are there so few farmers today?
Yoruba: Kí ló dé tí àwọn àgbẹ́ ṣe kéré lónì?

English: It's not because we're eating less.
Yoruba: Kìí ṣe nítorí pé a ò jẹun púpọ̀.

English: A century of productivity growth in farming means that now, a couple of million farmers can feed a nation of 320 million.
Yoruba: Òrún ọdún ìdàgbàsókè nínú iṣẹ́-àgbẹ̀ túmọ̀ sí wí pé ní báyìí, ìlọ́po ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn àgbẹ̀ lè bọ́ orílẹ̀-èdè tó ní ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún ọ̀rìn-dín-nírinwó lé lógún ènìyàn.

English: That's amazing progress, but it also means there are only so many O-ring jobs left in farming.
Yoruba: Ìtẹ̀síwájú tó yanilẹ́nu nìyẹn, ṣùgbọ́n ó tún túmọ̀ sí wí pé àwọn iṣẹ́ òrùka-O tó pọ̀ ló kù nínú iṣẹ́ àgbẹ̀.

English: So clearly, technology can eliminate jobs.
Yoruba: Ó fojú hàn kedere, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ lè pa iṣẹ́.

English: Farming is only one example.
Yoruba: Àpẹẹrẹ kan ṣoṣo ni iṣẹ́-àgbẹ̀ jẹ́.

English: There are many others like it.
Yoruba: Àwọn mìíràn bi irú rẹ̀ tún wà.

English: But what's true about a single product or service or industry has never been true about the economy as a whole.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan tó jẹ́ òtítọ́ nípa ohun-èlò kan ṣoṣo tàbí iṣẹ́ tàbí ilé-iṣẹ́ kò fìgbà kan jẹ́ òtítọ́ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé lápapọ̀.

English: Many of the industries in which we now work -- health and medicine, finance and insurance, electronics and computing -- were tiny or barely existent a century ago.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ tí a ti ń ṣisẹ́ báyìí -- ìlera àti òògùn, ìṣúná àti ìdójútófò, ohun-èlò tó ń loná àti ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá -- kéré tàbí wọn ò fẹ́rẹ̀ sí rárá bí ọ̀rún ọdún sẹ́yìn.

English: Many of the products that we spend a lot of our money on -- air conditioners, sport utility vehicles, computers and mobile devices -- were unattainably expensive, or just hadn't been invented a century ago.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ nínú àwọn èròjà tí à ń ná ọ̀pọ owó wa lé lórí -- ẹ̀rọ amúlétutù, àwọn ọkọ̀ ọ̀bọ̀kún ọlọ́yé, ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àti àwọn ẹ̀rọ ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ -- gbówó lórí gidi gan-an, tàbí wọn ò tíì ṣẹ̀da wọn bí ọrún ọdún sẹ́yìn.

English: As automation frees our time, increases the scope of what is possible, we invent new products, new ideas, new services that command our attention, occupy our time and spur consumption.
Yoruba: Bí àdáṣe ṣe ń ṣe ìtúsílẹ̀ àsìkò wa, tó ń ṣe àlékún ojú-ìwòye nǹkan tó ṣe é ṣe, a ṣẹ̀dá àwọn èròjà tuntun, èrò tuntun, iṣẹ́ tuntun t’ó ń pàṣẹ fún àkíyèsi wa, t’ó ń gba àkókò àti ìlo wa.

English: You may think some of these things are frivolous -- extreme yoga, adventure tourism, Pokémon GO -- and I might agree with you.
Yoruba: Ẹ lè rò bóyá àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí jẹ́ ìná àpà -- ìpẹ̀kun yóga, ìrìn-àjo afẹ́, Pokémon GO -- mo sì lè gbà pẹ̀lú yín.

English: But people desire these things, and they're willing to work hard for them.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ènìyàn nífẹ̀ sí àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí, wọ́n sì ṣetán láti ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára fún wọn.

English: The average worker in 2015 wanting to attain the average living standard in 1915 could do so by working just 17 weeks a year, one third of the time.
Yoruba: Àròpin àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ní ọdún 2015 tí wọ́n dúró láti dé ipò àròpin ìgbeayé àwòkọ́ṣe ní ọdún 1915 lè ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe iṣẹ́ fún ọ̀sẹ̀ mẹ́tà-dín-lógún péré nínú ọdún kan, ìdá mẹ́ta àsìkò náà.

English: But most people don't choose to do that.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ènìyàn kìí fẹ́ ṣe ìyẹn.

English: They are willing to work hard to harvest the technological bounty that is available to them.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ṣetán láti ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára láti kórè ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ lọ́pọ̀ bó ṣe wà fún wọn.

English: Material abundance has never eliminated perceived scarcity.
Yoruba: Wíwà lọ́pọ̀ àwọn ohun-èlò kò tíì pa ọ̀wọ́n ti a kẹ́fín.

English: In the words of economist Thorstein Veblen, invention is the mother of necessity.
Yoruba: Nínú ọ̀rọ̀ onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé Thorstein Veblen, ìṣẹ̀dá ni ìyá fún kò ṣe é má nì.

English: Now. So if you accept these two principles, the O-ring principle and the never-get-enough principle, then you agree with me.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà tí ẹ bá gba àwọn ìlànà méjì wọ̀nyí, ìlàna òrùka-O àti ìlàna kòtó, ẹ ó gbà pẹ̀lú mi nígbà náà.

English: There will be jobs.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ yóò wà.

English: Does that mean there's nothing to worry about?
Yoruba: Ṣé ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí wí pé kò sí nǹkankan láti bẹ̀rù?

English: Automation, employment, robots and jobs -- it'll all take care of itself?
Yoruba: Ìdáṣe, ìgbanisíṣẹ́, ṣìgìdì-òyìnbó àti iṣẹ́ -- gbogbo wọn máa mójútó ara wọn?

English: That is not my argument.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe àríyànjiyàn mi nìyẹn.

English: Automation creates wealth by allowing us to do more work in less time.
Yoruba: Ìdáṣe ń pèse ọrọ̀ pẹ̀lú fífún wa ní àǹfààní láti ṣiṣẹ́ tó pọ̀ ní àkókò péréte.

English: There is no economic law that says that we will use that wealth well, and that is worth worrying about.
Yoruba: Kò sí òfin ọrọ̀-ajé tó sọ wí pé a máa lo ọrọ̀ yẹn dáadáa, ìyen sì tó nǹkan tó yẹ ká ronú nípa rẹ̀.

English: Consider two countries, Norway and Saudi Arabia.
Yoruba: Ẹ wo orílẹ̀-èdè méjì, Norway àti Saudi Arabia.

English: Both oil-rich nations, it's like they have money spurting out of a hole in the ground.
Yoruba: Àwọn méjèèjì ni wọ́n ní epo, ó dà bí ẹni pé wọ́n ní owó tó ń jáde láti inú ihò kan nínú ilẹ̀ ni.

English: But they haven't used that wealth equally well to foster human prosperity, human prospering.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n wọn ò lo ọrọ̀ náà dọ́gba dáadáa láti ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún àṣeyọrí ọmọ ènìyàn, àwọn ènìyàn tó ń ṣàṣeyọrí.

English: Norway is a thriving democracy.
Yoruba: Norway jẹ́ òṣèlú àwarawa tó ń dágbà.

English: By and large, its citizens work and play well together.
Yoruba: Lápapọ̀, àwọn ọmọ-ilú rẹ̀ ń ṣe iṣẹ́ àti eré papọ̀.

English: It's typically numbered between first and fourth in rankings of national happiness.
Yoruba: Ó wà láàárín ipò àkọ́kọ́ sí ìkẹ́rin ní àtò ìdùnú orílẹ̀-èdè.

English: Saudi Arabia is an absolute monarchy in which many citizens lack a path for personal advancement.
Yoruba: Saudi Arabia jẹ́ ilú ọlọ́ba tí àwọn ọmọ-ìlú rẹ̀ ò ní ònà sí ìtẹ̀síwájú araẹni.

English: It's typically ranked 35th among nations in happiness, which is low for such a wealthy nation.
Yoruba: Ó wà nípò karùn-lé-lọ́gbọ̀n nínú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tí wọ́n wà nínú ìdùnnú, tí ó kéré fún irú orílẹ̀-èdè tó lọ́rọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Just by way of comparison, the US is typically ranked around 12th or 13th.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe àfiwé lásán, orílẹ̀ ède US wà nípò kejìlá tàbí ìkẹtàlá.

English: The difference between these two countries is not their wealth and it's not their technology.
Yoruba: Ìyàtọ̀ tó wà láàárín àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè méjì yìí kì í ṣe ọrọ̀ wọn kì í sì í ṣe ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wọn.

English: It's their institutions.
Yoruba: Àwọn ilé iṣẹ́ wọn ni.

English: Norway has invested to build a society with opportunity and economic mobility.
Yoruba: Norway ti dókòwò láti kọ́ àwùjọ tó ní àǹfààní àti àgbékiri ọrọ̀-ajé.

English: Saudi Arabia has raised living standards while frustrating many other human strivings.
Yoruba: Saudi Arabia ti ṣe àfikún sí afiṣòdiwọ̀n ìgbeayé nígba tí wọ́n ń wàhálà ọ̀pọ̀ ìgbìyànjú àwọn ènìyàn mìíràn.

English: Two countries, both wealthy, not equally well off.
Yoruba: Orílẹ̀-èdè méjì, tí wọ́n lọ́rọ̀, tí ọrọ̀ wọn ò dọ́gba.

English: And this brings me to the challenge that we face today, the challenge that automation poses for us.
Yoruba: Èyí ló mú mi wá síbi ìdojúkọ tí à ń kojú lónì, ìdojúkọ tí àdáṣe ń ṣe fún wa.

English: The challenge is not that we're running out of work.
Yoruba: Ìdojúkọ náà kìí ṣe wí pé kò sí iṣẹ́.

English: The US has added 14 million jobs since the depths of the Great Recession.
Yoruba: Orílẹ̀-ède US tí ṣe àfikún àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ mẹ́rìnlá iṣẹ́ láti ìgbà òpin òjòjo ọrọ̀-ajé tó lágbára.

English: The challenge is that many of those jobs are not good jobs, and many citizens cannot qualify for the good jobs that are being created.
Yoruba: Ìdojúkọ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn iṣẹ́ wọ̀nyẹn kìí ṣe iṣẹ́ rere, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ará ìlú ò sì peregedé fún iṣẹ́ gidi tí wọ́n pésè.

English: Employment growth in the United States and in much of the developed world looks something like a barbell with increasing poundage on either end of the bar.
Yoruba: Ìdàgbàsókè ìgbanisíṣẹ́ ní orílẹ̀-ède United States àti ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn orílẹ́ èdè tí wọ́n ti gòkè àgbà dà bi irin tí wọ́n ń ṣe àfikún ìgbérin ní ìpẹ̀kun irin méjééjì.

English: On the one hand, you have high-education, high-wage jobs like doctors and nurses, programmers and engineers, marketing and sales managers.
Yoruba: Ní apá kan, ẹ ní ẹ̀kọ́ gíga, àwọn iṣẹ́ tí owó-iṣẹ́ wọ́n ga bíi oníṣégùn òyìnbó àti àwọn olùtọ́-ilé-ìwòsàn, àwọn onímọ̀ nípa kọ̀mpúta àti àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ, ìtajà àti àwọn alámòjútó ìtajà.

English: Employment is robust in these jobs, employment growth.
Yoruba: Ìgbanisíṣẹ́ pọ̀ nínú àwọn iṣẹ́ yìí, ìdàgbàsókè ìgbanisíṣẹ́.

English: Similarly, employment growth is robust in many low-skill, low-education jobs like food service, cleaning, security, home health aids.
Yoruba: Bákan náà, ìdàgbàsókè ìgbanisíṣẹ́ pọ̀ nínú àwọn iṣẹ́ oní ìmọ́ọ́ṣe-kékeré, àti ẹ̀kọ́ kékeré bíi iṣẹ́ oúnjẹ, agbálẹ̀, elétò ààbò, ìralnwọ́ ìlera inú-ilé.

English: Simultaneously, employment is shrinking in many middle-education, middle-wage, middle-class jobs, like blue-collar production and operative positions and white-collar clerical and sales positions.
Yoruba: Lásíkò kan náà, ìgbanisíṣẹ́ ń rù ní ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ẹ̀kọ́ tó wà lágbede méjì, owó-iṣẹ́ agbedeméjì, àwọn iṣẹ́-agbedeméjì, bi ìṣiṣẹ́ amojú-ẹ̀rọ àti iṣẹ́ alákọ̀wé àti ìtajà.

English: The reasons behind this contracting middle are not mysterious.
Yoruba: Ìdí tí àárín yìí fi ń há yìí kìí ṣémò.

English: Many of those middle-skill jobs use well-understood rules and procedures that can increasingly be codified in software and executed by computers.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn iṣẹ́ ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe agbedeméjì máa ń lo àwọn òfin àti ìlànà tí ó yéni yéké tí wọ́n lè gbé sínú ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn tí wọ́n lè lò lórí ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá.

English: The challenge that this phenomenon creates, what economists call employment polarization, is that it knocks out rungs in the economic ladder, shrinks the size of the middle class and threatens to make us a more stratified society.
Yoruba: Ìdojúkọ tí nǹkan yìí ń dásílẹ̀, nǹkan tí àwọn onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé ń pè ní ìpín sí méjì ìgbanisíṣẹ́, ni wí pé ó máa ń já àwọn àkàsọ nínú àkàba ọrọ̀-ajé, ó máa n jóro ìwọn àwọn tí wọ́n wà lágbedeméjì ó sì ń dúkokò láti sọ àwùjọ wa di onípele.

English: On the one hand, a set of highly paid, highly educated professionals doing interesting work, on the other, a large number of citizens in low-paid jobs whose primary responsibility is to see to the comfort and health of the affluent.
Yoruba: Ní apá kan, ọ̀wọ́ àwọn tí wọ́n ń gbowó geere, àwọn akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ tí wọ́n kàwé tí wọ́n ń ṣe iṣẹ́ tó rọrùn, lápá kejì, ogunlọ́gbọ̀n àwọn ará-ìlú tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ tí owó iṣẹ́ wọn kéré tí ojúṣe wọn gangan jẹ́ láti rí sí ìdẹ̀rùn àti ìlèra àwọn ọlọ́rọ̀.

English: That is not my vision of progress, and I doubt that it is yours.
Yoruba: Èyí kìí ṣe àfojúsùn ìlọsíwájú mi, mo sì ń ṣeyè méjì pé tiyín nìyẹn.

English: But here is some encouraging news.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ìròyìn tó wúnilórí nìyí.

English: We have faced equally momentous economic transformations in the past, and we have come through them successfully.
Yoruba: A ti kojú àwọn àsìkò àyípadà ọrọ̀-ajé sẹ́yìn, a sì ti rí ọ̀nà àbáyọ kúrò nínú wọn láṣeyọrí.

English: In the late 1800s and early 1900s, when automation was eliminating vast numbers of agricultural jobs -- remember that tractor?-- the farm states faced a threat of mass unemployment, a generation of youth no longer needed on the farm but not prepared for industry.
Yoruba: Ní ìpẹ̀kun àsìkò 1800 àti ìbẹ̀rẹ àsìko 1900, nígbà tí ìdáṣiṣẹ́ ń pa ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn iṣẹ́ àgbẹ̀ -- ẹ rántí ọkọ̀-katakata-ìdáko? ipò àwọn oko náa kojú ewu aìníṣẹ́lọ́wọ́ tó pọ̀, ìran àwọn ọ̀dọ́ tí a ò nílò lórí oko ṣùgbọ́n tí wọn ò ṣetán fún ilé-iṣẹ́.

English: Rising to this challenge, they took the radical step of requiring that their entire youth population remain in school and continue their education to the ripe old age of 16.
Yoruba: Kíkojú àwọn ìdojúkọ yìí, wọ́n gbé ìgbésẹ̀ akin fún pípè fún gbogbo àwọn ọ̀dọ́ láti dúró sí ilé-ẹ́kọ kí wọ́n sì tẹ̀sìwájú ẹ̀kọ wọn títí tí wọn ó fi bàlágà di ọmọ ọdún mẹ́rìn-dín-lógún.

English: This was called the high school movement, and it was a radically expensive thing to do.
Yoruba: Èyí ni wọ́n pè ní ìtẹ̀síwájú ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga, ó sì jẹ́ nkan tó wọ́n láti ṣe.

English: Not only did they have to invest in the schools, but those kids couldn't work at their jobs.
Yoruba: Kìí ṣe pé wọ́n ní láti dókòwò nínú àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ọmọ wọ̀nyẹn ò lè ṣe iṣẹ́ wọn.

English: It also turned out to be one of the best investments the US made in the 20th century.
Yoruba: Ó padà di ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìdókòwò t’ó dára jù tí orílẹ̀-ède US ti ṣe ní ọ̀rún ọdún ogún.

English: It gave us the most skilled, the most flexible and the most productive workforce in the world.
Yoruba: Ó fún wa ní ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe tó pọ̀ jù, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ tí wọ́n lè yípadà jù tí wọ́n sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ jù lágbàáyé.

English: To see how well this worked, imagine taking the labor force of 1899 and bringing them into the present.
Yoruba: Láti lè rí bí èyí ṣe ṣiṣẹ́ sí, ẹ wòye mímú àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ odún 1899 ká mú wọn wá sí àsìkò lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: Despite their strong backs and good characters, many of them would lack the basic literacy and numeracy skills to do all but the most mundane jobs.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ẹ̀yìn líle àti ìwà rere wọn, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wọn ò ní ìmọ̀ ìpìlẹ̀ àti ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe ònkà láti ṣe gbogbo rẹ̀ ṣùgbọ́n àwọn iṣẹ́ tí ò múnú ẹni dùn.

English: Many of them would be unemployable.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀ nínú wọn ni ò ní ṣe é gbà síṣẹ́.

English: What this example highlights is the primacy of our institutions, most especially our schools, in allowing us to reap the harvest of our technological prosperity.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí àpẹẹrẹ yìí tọ́ka sí ni pàtàkì àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ wa, pàápàá jùlọ àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ wa, láti gbàwá láyè láti kórè ìlọsíwájú ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ wa.

English: It's foolish to say there's nothing to worry about.
Yoruba: Ìwà òpònú ni láti sọ wí pé kò sí nǹkankan láti bẹ̀rù.

English: Clearly we can get this wrong.
Yoruba: Ó hàn gbangba pé a lè ṣi eléyí.

English: If the US had not invested in its schools and in its skills a century ago with the high school movement, we would be a less prosperous, a less mobile and probably a lot less happy society.
Yoruba: Bí orílẹ̀-ède US bá ti dókòwò nínú àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ rẹ̀ àti ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe rẹ̀ láti bíi ọ̀rún ọdún sẹ́yìn pẹ̀lú ìtẹ̀síwájú ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga ni, a ó ní lámìlaka púpọ̀, a ò ní sún káàkiri púpọ̀ àti bóyá àwùjọ tí ò ní ìdùnnú púpọ̀.

English: But it's equally foolish to say that our fates are sealed.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ìwà òpònú tún ni bákan náà láti sọ wí pé wọ́n ti parí kádára wa.

English: That's not decided by the machines.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe àwọn ẹ̀ro ni yóò ṣe ìyẹn.

English: It's not even decided by the market.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe ọjà gan-an ni yóò ṣe é.

English: It's decided by us and by our institutions.
Yoruba: Àwa àti àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ wa la máa ṣe ìyẹn.

English: Now, I started this talk with a paradox.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ atótónu yìí pẹ̀lú ajọ̀ró-ṣòótọ́.

English: Our machines increasingly do our work for us.
Yoruba: Àwọn ẹ̀rọ wa ń ṣe iṣẹ́ wa fún wa lọ́pọ̀lọpọ̀.

English: Why doesn't that make our labor superfluous, our skills redundant?
Yoruba: Kí ló dé tí ìyẹn ò ṣe sọ àwọn òṣìṣẹ wa di aláìwúlò, kí ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe wa sì lélẹ̀?

English: Isn't it obvious that the road to our economic and social hell is paved with our own great inventions?
Yoruba: Ṣé kò fojú hàn pé ojú ọ̀nà sí àpadì ọrọ̀-ajé àti àwùjọ wa ti di ṣíṣí látara ìṣẹ̀da ńlá wa?

English: History has repeatedly offered an answer to that paradox.
Yoruba: Ìtàn ti ń fún wa ní ìdáhùn sí ajọ̀ró-ṣòótọ́ yẹn ní tẹ̀lé-ń-tẹ̀lé.

English: The first part of the answer is that technology magnifies our leverage, increases the importance, the added value of our expertise, our judgment and our creativity.
Yoruba: Abala àkọ́kọ́ ìdáhùn náà ni wí pé ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ti ṣe àfikún agbára wa, ti ṣe àfikún sí ìwúlò àwọn àgbà-ọ̀jẹ wa, ìdájọ́ wa àti ọgbọ́n àtinúdá wa.

English: That's the O-ring.
Yoruba: Òrùka-O náà nìyẹn.

English: The second part of the answer is our endless inventiveness and bottomless desires means that we never get enough, never get enough.
Yoruba: Apá kejì ìdáhùn náà ni pé ìṣẹ̀dá àìlópin wa àti ìfẹ́ tí ò nípẹ̀kun túmọ̀ sí wí pé kòtó, kòtó.

English: There's always new work to do.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ìgbà ni iṣẹ́ tuntun máa ń wà láti ṣe.

English: Adjusting to the rapid pace of technological change creates real challenges, seen most clearly in our polarized labor market and the threat that it poses to economic mobility.
Yoruba: Ìsúrakì sí ọ̀pọ eré àyípadà ìmọ̀ ẹ̀rọ ti pèse ìdojúkọ tòótọ́ sílẹ̀, tí à ń rí kedere lọ́pọ̀ nínú ìsọdi méjì ọjà àwọn òṣìṣẹ wa àti ewu tó ń fà fún ìlọsíwájú ọrọ̀-ajé.

English: Rising to this challenge is not automatic.
Yoruba: Ìdìde sí ìdojúkọ yìí kìí ṣe àdáṣe.

English: It's not costless.
Yoruba: Kìí ṣe pé kò ní náni lówó.

English: It's not easy.
Yoruba: Kò rọrùn.

English: But it is feasible.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó ṣe é ṣe.

English: And here is some encouraging news.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìròyìn tó ń fún ni ní ìwúrí rèé.

English: Because of our amazing productivity, we're rich.
Yoruba: Nítorí ìṣiṣẹ́ wa, a ti dolówó.

English: Of course we can afford to invest in ourselves and in our children as America did a hundred years ago with the high school movement.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́ a lówó láti dókòwò nínú ara wa àti àwọn ọmọ wa gẹ́gẹ́ bí orílẹ̀-ède America ṣe ṣe ní ọgọ́rùn ọdún sẹ́yìn pẹ̀lú ìtẹ̀síwájú àwọn ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga.

English: Arguably, we can't afford not to.
Yoruba: Ó ṣe é jiyàn, a ò lè tẹ̀tì láti má ṣe é.

English: Now, you may be thinking, Professor Autor has told us a heartwarming tale about the distant past, the recent past, maybe the present, but probably not the future.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, ẹ lè máa rò ó wí pé, ọ̀jọ̀gbọ́n Autor ti sọ ìtàn atunilára fún wa nípa ìgbà pípẹ́, ìgbà tí ò tíì pẹ́, bóyá lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí, ṣùgbọ́n bóyá kì í ṣe nípa ọjọ́ iwájú.

English: Because everybody knows that this time is different.
Yoruba: Nítorí gbogbo ènìyàn ló mọ̀ wí pé àsìkò yìí yátọ̀.

English: Is this time different?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ àsìkò yìí yátọ̀?

English: Of course this time is different.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni àsìkò yìí yátọ̀.

English: Every time is different.
Yoruba: Gbogbo àsìkò ló yátọ̀.

English: On numerous occasions in the last 200 years, scholars and activists have raised the alarm that we are running out of work and making ourselves obsolete: for example, the Luddites in the early 1800s; US Secretary of Labor James Davis in the mid-1920s; Nobel Prize-winning economist Wassily Leontief in 1982; and of course, many scholars, pundits, technologists and media figures today.
Yoruba: Lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà ní igba ọdún sẹ́yìn, àwọn òmọ̀wé àti àwọn ajàfẹ́tọ̀ ti kébòsí pé a ò ní iṣẹ́ mọ́ a sì ń sọ ara wa di aláìwúlò: fún àpẹẹrẹ, àwọn onímọ̀-ẹrọ ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ àsìko 1800; akọ̀wé àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ fún orílẹ̀-ède US james Davis ní àárín àsìko 1920; onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé tó tún gba ẹ̀bùn Wassily Leontief ní ọdún 1982; bẹ́ẹ̀ sì ni, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ọ̀mọ̀wé, ayànàná, àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ àti àwọn agbóhùn-sáfẹ́fẹ́ lónìí.

English: These predictions strike me as arrogant.
Yoruba: Àwọn àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ wọ̀nyí bàmi bí onígbèraga.

English: These self-proclaimed oracles are in effect saying, "If I can't think of what people will do for work in the future, then you, me and our kids aren't going to think of it either.
Yoruba: Àwọn tí wọ́n sọra wọn di òòṣà wọ̀nyí tí wọ́n ń sọ wí pé, “tí mi ò bá lè ronú nípa nǹkan tí àwọn ènìyàn máa ṣe láti ríṣẹ́ lọ́jó iwájú, ìwọ, èmi àti àwọn ọmọ wa ò ní ronú nípa rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú.

English: " I don't have the guts to take that bet against human ingenuity.
Yoruba: “ Mí o lọ́kàn láti ta tẹ́tẹ́ yẹn tako ọgbọ́n inú ọmọ ènìyàn.

English: Look, I can't tell you what people are going to do for work a hundred years from now.
Yoruba: È wò ó, mi ò lè sọ nǹkan tí àwọn ènìyàn máa ṣe láti ríṣẹ́ ní ọgọ̀rùn ọdún sí àsìkò yìí fún yín.

English: But the future doesn't hinge on my imagination.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ọjọ́ iwájú ò gbára lé ìrònú mi.

English: If I were a farmer in Iowa in the year 1900, and an economist from the 21st century teleported down to my field and said, "Hey, guess what, farmer Autor, in the next hundred years, agricultural employment is going to fall from 40 percent of all jobs to two percent purely due to rising productivity.
Yoruba: Bí mo bá jẹ́ àgbẹ̀ ní lowa ní ọdún 1900, tí àwọn onímọ̀ nípa ọrọ̀-ajé ọ̀rún odún kankàn-lé-lógún wá jáde sóri ilẹ̀ mi tó wá sọ pé, “ìwọ, ṣé o mọ nǹkan, àgbẹ̀ Autor, ní ogọ́rùn ọdún tó ń bọ̀, ìgbanisíṣẹ́ àgbẹ̀ máa dínkù láti ìdá ogójì gbogbo iṣẹ́ sí ògéré ìdá méjì nítorí ìṣiṣẹ́ tó ń lọ sókè.

English: What do you think the other 38 percent of workers are going to do?
Yoruba: Kí lẹ rò wí pé ìdá méjì-dín-lógójì àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ yóò máa ṣe?

English: " I would not have said, "Oh, we got this.
Yoruba: “ mi ò bà má sọ pé, “Óh, a mọ èyí.

English: We'll do app development, radiological medicine, yoga instruction, Bitmoji.
Yoruba: A máa ṣe ìpèse àwọn ohun-èlò, àwọn ẹ̀rọ ayàwòrán-ara fún ìṣègùn, ìkọ́ni ní yógà, Bitmojì.

English: I wouldn't have had a clue.
Yoruba: Mi ò bá ti má nì ìmọ̀ kankan.

English: But I hope I would have had the wisdom to say, "Wow, a 95 percent reduction in farm employment with no shortage of food.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo lérò wí pé màá ní ọgbọ́n láti sọ wí pé, “Wow, àdínkù ìdá márùn-ún-lé láàdọ́rùn nínú ìgbanisíṣẹ́ oko láìsí àdínkù oúnjẹ.

English: That's an amazing amount of progress.
Yoruba: Ìtẹ̀síwájú tó yanilẹ́nu nìyẹn.

English: I hope that humanity finds something remarkable to do with all of that prosperity.
Yoruba: Mo lérò wí pé àwọn ọmọ ènìyàn yóò rí nǹkan gidi láti ṣe pẹ̀lú gbogbo ìlàmìlaka yẹn.

English: And by and large, I would say that it has.
Yoruba: Lápapọ̀, màá sọ wí pé ó ti rí bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Thank you very much.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun púpọ̀.

English: A celebration of natural hair
Yoruba: Àjọ̀dún irun àmútọ̀run wá.

English: I am from the South Side of Chicago, and in seventh grade, I had a best friend named Jenny who lived on the Southwest Side of Chicago.
Yoruba: Mo wá láti Apá Gúúsù orílẹ̀-ède Chicago, mo sì wà ní ìpele kéje, mo ní ọ̀rẹ́dénú kan tí orúkọ rẹ̀ ń jẹ́ Jenny tó ń gbé ní Apá Gúúsù-ìwọ̀-oòrùn orílẹ̀-ède Chicago.

English: Jenny was white, and if you know anything about the segregated demographics of Chicago, you know that there are not too many black people who live on the Southwest Side of Chicago.
Yoruba: Jenny jẹ́ aláwọ̀ funfun, tí ẹ bá sì mọ nǹkankan nípa àwọn àyè tí wọ́n yà sọ́tọ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède Chicago, ẹ mọ̀ wí pé àwọn ènìyàn dúdú ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ gbé ní Apá Gúúsù-ìwọ̀-oòrùn orílẹ̀-ède Chicago.

English: But Jenny was my girl and so we would hang out every so often after school and on the weekends.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n Jenny ní arábìnrin mi nítorí náà a máa ń jáde papọ̀ lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà lẹ́yìn tí a bá jáde ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ àti ní òpin ọ̀sẹ̀.

English: And so one day we were hanging out in her living room, talking about 13-year-old things, and Jenny's little sister Rosie was in the room with us, and she was sitting behind me just kind of playing in my hair, and I wasn't thinking too much about what she was doing.
Yoruba: Ní ọjọ́ kan a jọ wà ní yàrá ìgbàlejò wọn, tí à ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa àwọn nǹkan ọmọ ọdún mẹ́tàlá, àbúro Jenny lóbìnrin Rosie wà nínú yàrá náà pẹ̀lú wa, ó jókòó lẹ́yìn mi tí ó ń fi irun mi ṣeré, mi ò sì ronú púpọ̀ nípa nǹkan tí ó ń ṣe.

English: But at a pause in the conversation, Rosie tapped me on the shoulder.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí a dánu dúró díẹ̀ nínú ìfọ̀rọ̀jomitoro náà, Rosie fọwọ́ tọ́mi léjìká.

English: She said, "Can I ask you a question?
Yoruba: Ó wí pé. “Ǹjẹ́ mo lè bi ọ́ ní ìbéèrè kan.

English: I said, "Yeah, Rosie.
Yoruba: Mo ní, “bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, Rosie.

English: "Are you black?
Yoruba: “Ṣé aláwọ̀ dúdú ni ọ́ ni?

English: The room froze.
Yoruba: Yàrá náà tutù.

English: Jenny and Rosie's mom was not too far away.
Yoruba: Ìya Jenny àti Rosie ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ jìnọ̀ sí wa.

English: She was in the kitchen and she overheard the conversation, and she was mortified.
Yoruba: Wọ́n wà nínú ilé-ìdáná wọ́n sì ń gbọ́ ọ̀rọ wa, ojú tìwọ́n.

English: She said, "Rosie! You can't ask people questions like that.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ní, “Rosie! O ò lè ma bère irú ìbéèrè báyẹn lọ́wọ́ àwọn ènìyàn.

English: " And Jenny was my friend, and I know she was really embarrassed.
Yoruba: “ Jenny jẹ́ ọ̀rẹ́ mi, mo sì mọ̀ wí pé ojú tìí gidi gan-an.

English: I felt kind of bad for her, but actually I was not offended.
Yoruba: Inú mi bájẹ́ nítorí tiẹ̀, ṣùgbọ́n kò ṣẹ̀mí.

English: I figured it wasn't Rosie's fault that in her 10 short years on this earth, living on the Southwest Side of Chicago, she wasn't 100 percent sure what a black person looked like.
Yoruba: Mo rí I wí pé kìí ṣẹ ẹjọ́ọ Rosie pé ní odún kékeré rẹ̀ bíi mẹ́wà t’ó ti lò láyé, t’ó sì ń gbé ní Apá Gúúsù-ìwọ̀-oòrun orílẹ̀-ède Chicago, kò ní ìdánilójú tó pé ìda ọgọ́rùn bí ènìyàn dúdú ṣe rí.

English: That's fair.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn dára.

English: But what was more surprising to me was, in all of this time I had spent with Jenny and Rosie's family -- hanging out with them, playing with them, even physically interacting with them -- it was not until Rosie put her hands in my hair that she thought to ask me if I was black.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan t’ó jọmí lójú jù ni pé, ní gbogbo àsìkò tí mo ti lò pẹ̀lú ẹbí Jenny àti Rosie -- tí mò ń jáde pẹ̀lú wọn, tí mò ń báwọn ṣeré, tí mo sì ń bá wọn sọ̀rọ̀ lójúkojú -- àfi ìgbà tí Rosie fi ọwọ́ kan irun mi ni ó tó béèrè bóyá aláwọ̀ dúdú ni mí.

English: That was the first time I would realize how big of a role the texture of my hair played in confirming my ethnicity, but also that it would play a key role in how I'm viewed by others in society.
Yoruba: Ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ nìyẹn tí mo máa mọ ipa ńlá tí ìrísí irun mi lè kó láti sọ ìran mi, pé ó tùn lè kó ipa tó ṣe pàtàkì sí bí àwọn ènìyan t’ó kù láwùjọ ṣe ń wò mi.

English: Garrett A.Morgan and Madame CJ Walker were pioneers of the black hair-care and beauty industry in the early 1900s.
Yoruba: Garrett A. Morgan àti Madame CJ Walker ni wọ́n ṣe ìdásílẹ̀ ìtójú-irun dúdú àti ilé-iṣẹ́ ìṣaralóoge ní ìbẹ̀rẹ̀ àsìko ọdún 1900.

English: They're best known as the inventors of chemically-based hair creams and heat straightening tools designed to permanently, or semipermanently, alter the texture of black hair.
Yoruba: A mọ̀ wọ́n sí olùṣẹ̀dá àwọn ìparun oní kẹ́míkà àti àwọn irinṣẹ́ ìforu na nǹkan tí wọ́n ṣe láti ṣe àyídà ìrísí irun dúdú fún gbére tàbí fúngbà díẹ̀.

English: Oftentimes when we think about the history of blacks in America, we think about the heinous acts and numerous injustices that we experienced as people of color because of the color of our skin, when in fact, in post-Civil War America, it was the hair of an African-American male or female that was known as the most "telling feature" of Negro status, more so than the color of the skin.
Yoruba: Nígbà míràn nígbà tí a bá ronú nípa ìtàn àwọn aláwọ̀ dúdú ní ilẹ̀ America, a máa ń ronú nípa àwọn ìwà burúkú àti ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àìṣedédé tí a kojú gẹ́gẹ́ bi aláwọ̀ dúdú nítorí àwọ ara wa, nígbà tó sì jẹ́ pé lóòótọ́, léyìn ogun abẹ́lé ilẹ̀ America, irun ọmọ ilẹ̀ America aláwọ̀-dúláwọ̀ lọ́kùnrin tàbí lóbìnrin ni wọ́n mọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bi “àwòmọ́ asọ̀rọ̀” ìjẹ́ aláwọ̀ dúdú, ju àwọ ara lọ.

English: And so before they were staples of the multibillion-dollar hair-care industry, our dependency on tools and products, like the hair relaxer and the pressing comb, were more about our survival and advancement as a race in postslavery America.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà kí wọ́n tó di àsopọ̀ ilé-iṣẹ́ aṣerun lóge ọlọ́pọ̀ ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún dọ́là, àgbọ́kàn le wa lórí àwọn irinṣẹ́ àti ohun-èlò, bíi ọsẹ-irun àti ìyarun, ni à ń lò fún ìmóríbọ́ àti ìlọsíwájú gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìran kan lẹ́yìn ìkónilẹ́rú nílẹ̀ America.

English: Over the years, we grew accustomed to this idea that straighter and longer hair meant better and more beautiful.
Yoruba: Láti bí àìmọye ọdún, à ń dágbà sí mímọ èrò yìí pé irun tó nà tó sì gùn túmọ̀ sí dídára ó sì máa ń rẹwà si.

English: We became culturally obsessed with this idea of having what we like to call "good hair.
Yoruba: A sọ́ èrò yìí di àṣà níní nǹkan tí a fẹ́ràn láti máa pè ní “irun gidi.

English: " This essentially means: the looser the curl pattern, the better the hair.
Yoruba: “ Ní pàtàkì èyí túmọ̀ sí wí pé: bí bátàni lílọ́ bá ṣe sì sí, ni irún ṣe máa dára sí.

English: And we let these institutionalized ideas form a false sense of hierarchy that would determine what was considered a good grade of hair and what was not.
Yoruba: A jẹ́ kí àwọn ìwòye àwùjọ wọ̀nyí di ọpọlọ ìpele àgbékà tí ò yẹ tí yóò máa sọ ohun tí a mọ̀ sí ìsọ̀rí irun gidi àti èyí tí ò ṣẹ.

English: What's worse is that we let these false ideologies invade our perception of ourselves, and they still continue to infect our cultural identity as African-American women today.
Yoruba: Nǹkan t’ó tún burú jù ni wí pé a jẹ́ kí àwọn èro báyéṣerí tí ò yẹ wọ̀nyí ń kógun ja èro wa nípa ara wa, wọ́n sì ń tẹ̀síwájú láti kóbá àṣà ìdánimọ̀ wa gẹ́gẹ́ bi obìnrin Ọmọ-ilẹ̀ America Adúláwọ̀ lónìí.

English: So what did we do?
Yoruba: Torí náà kí la ṣe?

English: We went to the hair salon every six to eight weeks, without fail, to subject our scalps to harsh straightening chemicals beginning at a very young age -- sometimes eight, 10 -- that would result in hair loss, bald spots, sometimes even burns on the scalp.
Yoruba: A lọ sí ilé ìṣerunlóge ní ọ̀sẹ̀ méfà-mẹ́fà sí mẹ́jọ-mẹ́jọ, láìyẹ̀, láti jọ̀wọ awọ-orí wa fún àwọn èròjà ti kì í ṣe ti ẹ̀dá amúrunnà tí ó lágbára bẹ̀rẹ̀ láti ọjọ́ orí kékeré -- nígbà mìíràn odún mẹ́jọ, 10 -- èyí yóò yorí sí irun jíjá, pípárí, nígbà mìíràn egbò lè wà lórí awọ-orí.

English: We fry our hair at temperatures of 450 degrees Fahrenheit or higher almost daily, to maintain the straight look.
Yoruba: À ń yan irun wa pẹ̀lú oru ti òdiwọ̀n rẹ̀ t’ó 450 tàbí jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ lójoojúmọ́, láti jẹ́ k’ó nà síbẹ̀.

English: Or we simply cover our hair up with wigs and weaves, only to let our roots breathe in private where no one knows what's really going on under there.
Yoruba: Tàbí kí á kàn bo irun wa pẹ̀lú irun-àdàborí àti ẹ̀hun, láti lè jẹ́ kí gbòngbò orí wa lè mí níbi tí ẹnìkankan ò ti ní mọ nǹkan t’ó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ nísálẹ̀ ńbẹ̀.

English: We adopted these practices in our own communities, and so it's no wonder why today the typical ideal vision of a professional black woman, especially in corporate America, tends to look like this, rather than like this.

English: And she certainly doesn't look like this.

Yoruba: Ní oṣù Ọ̀wẹwẹ̀ odún yìí, ilé ẹjọ́ àpapọ̀ kan pà á láṣẹ fún ilé-iṣẹ́ kan láti má ṣe ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà nípa ìgbanisíṣẹ́ lórí bóyá ẹni náà lókùrin tàbí lóbìnrin ṣerun dàda.

English: In the case, the hiring manager in Mobile, Alabama is on record as saying, "I'm not saying yours are messy, but you know what I'm talking about.

English: " Well, what was she talking about?
Yoruba: “ Ó dáa, kínni nǹkan t’ó ń sọ nípa ẹ̀?

English: Did she think that they were ugly?

English: Or maybe they were just a little too Afrocentric and pro-black-looking for her taste.
Yoruba: Àbí bóyá wọ́n ń ṣe bí ọmọ ilẹ̀ adúláwọ̀ díẹ̀ ni tí wọ́n dàbí aláwọ̀ dúdú ju bó ṣe fẹ́ lọ.

English: Or maybe it's not about Afrocentricity, and it's more just about it being a little too "urban" for the professional setting.
Yoruba: Tàbí bóyá kì í ṣe nípa Ìṣe-bí-ọmọ-adúláwọ̀, t’ó sì jẹ́ nítorí wọ́n jẹ́ “ìgboro” díẹ̀ fún àwùjọ àwon akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́.

English: Perhaps she had a genuine concern in that they looked "scary" and that they would intimidate the clients and their customer base.
Yoruba: Bóyá ó ní ìrònú t’ó tọ́ nípa pé ìrísí wọ́n “banilẹ́rù” wọn ó sì máa dẹ́rùba àwọn alájọṣe àti ẹgbẹ́ àwọn oníbàráà wọn.

English: All of these words are ones that are too often associated with the stigma attached to natural hairstyles.
Yoruba: Gbogbo àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ wọ̀nyí jẹ́ àwọn t’ó jọ mọ́ ìdẹ́yẹsí tí ó sopọ̀ mọ́ àṣà irun àmútọ̀runwá.

English: And this has got to change.
Yoruba: Èyí sì ní láti yípadà.

English: In 2013, a white paper published by the Deloitte Leadership Center for Inclusion, studied 3,000 individuals in executive leadership roles on the concept of covering in the workplace based on appearance, advocacy, affiliation and association.
Yoruba: Ní ọ̀dún 2013, ìwé àpilẹ̀kọ ìjọba tí Deloitte Leadership Center for Inclusion tẹ̀ jáde, ṣe àyẹ̀wo ẹgbẹ̀rún 3 àwọn ènìyàn ti wọ́n wà nípò adárí ìjọba lórí èro bíbòrí níbi iṣẹ́ lórí ìrísí, ìgbàwí, ilé-iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n wà àti ẹgbẹ́.

English: When thinking about appearance-based covering, the study showed that 67 percent of women of color cover in the workplace based on their appearance.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí ẹ bá ń ronú nípa bíbòri tó níṣe pẹ̀lú ìrísí, ìwádìí náà fi hàn pé ìdá mẹ́tà-dín-láàdọ́rin àwọn obìnrin tí wọ́n jẹ́ aláwọ̀ dúdú ni wọ́n ń borí níbi iṣẹ́ nítorí ìrísí wọn.

English: Of the total respondents who admitted to appearance-based covering, 82 percent said that it was somewhat to extremely important for them to do so for their professional advancement.
Yoruba: Nínú àpapọ̀ àwọn abẹ́nà-ìmọ̀ tí wọ́n gbà fún ìborí nípa ìrísí, ìdá méjì-lé-lọ́gọ́rin sọ wí pé ó ṣe pàtàkì púpọ̀ fún wọn láti ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀ nítorí ìlọsíwájú ìkọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ wọn.

English: Now, this is Ursula Burns.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, Ursula Burns rè é

English: She is the first African-American female CEO of a Fortune 500 company -- of Xerox.
Yoruba: Òun ni aláṣẹ àti olùdarí ọmọ ilẹ America tó jẹ́ obìnrin adúláwọ̀ fún ilé-iṣẹ́ Fortune 500 -- ti Xerox

English: She's known by her signature look, the one that you see here.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyán mọ̀ ọ́ fún ìrísí rẹ̀, èyí tí ẹ̀ rí níbí.

English: A short, nicely trimmed, well-manicured Afro.
Yoruba: Irun ilẹ̀ Adúláwò tó kéré, tí wọ́n gé dọ́gba dáadáa, tó rí ìtọ́jú gidi.

English: Burns is what we like to call a "natural girl.
Yoruba: Burns ni a fẹ́ràn láti má ape “ọmọbìnrin tó jẹ́ abínibí.

English: " And she is paving the way and showing what's possible for African-American women seeking to climb the corporate ladder, but still wishing to wear natural hairstyles.
Yoruba: “ Ó ń lánà ó sì ń ṣàfihàn nǹkan tó ṣe é ṣe fún àwọn obìnrin ọmọ ilẹ̀ America tó jẹ́ adúláwọ̀ tí wọ́n ń wá láti gun àkàba alákọ̀wé, ṣùgbọ́n tó wùn wọ́n láti gbé irun abínibí wọn.

English: But today the majority of African-American women who we still look to as leaders, icons and role models, still opt for a straight-hair look.
Yoruba: Sùgbọ́n lénì púpọ̀ nínú àwọn obìnrin ọmọ ilẹ̀ America tó jẹ́ adúláwọ̀ tí a ṣì ń wò gẹ́gẹ́ bí aṣíwájú, akọni àti àwòkọ́ṣe, ṣì ń lọ fún irun nínà.

English: Now, maybe it's because they want to -- this is authentically how they feel best -- but maybe -- and I bet -- a part of them felt like they had to in order to reach the level of success that they have attained today.
Yoruba: Nísìnyìí, bóyá nítorí pé wọ́n fẹ́ ẹ bẹ́ẹ̀ ni -- bó ṣe wùn wọ́n jùlọ nìyí -- ṣùgbọ́n bóyá -- mo sì mọ̀ -- apá kan nínú wọn yóò dàbi wí pé wọ́n ní láti ṣe é láti dé ipele àṣeyọrí tí wọ́n ti dé lónì.

English: There is a natural hair movement that is sweeping the country and also in some places in Europe.
Yoruba: Ìtẹ̀síwájú irun àmútọ̀runwá kan wà tó ń lọ káàkiri orílẹ̀-èdè náà àti ní àwọn àyè kọ̀ọ̀kan nílẹ̀ Europe.

English: Millions of women are exploring what it means to transition to natural hair, and they're cutting off years and years of dry, damaged ends in order to restore their natural curl pattern.

English: I know because I have been an advocate and an ambassador for this movement for roughly the last three years.

English: After 27 years of excessive heat and harsh chemicals, my hair was beginning to show extreme signs of wear and tear.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ọdún mẹ́tà-dín-lọ́gbọ̀n ọ̀pọ̀ oru àti kẹ́míkà tó lágbára, irun mi ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní ṣàfihàn bíbàjẹ́ àti jíjá.

English: It was breaking off, it was thinning, looking just extremely dry and brittle.
Yoruba: Ó ń já danù, ó ń tu, ó gbẹ ó sì le gidi gan-an.

English: All those years of chasing that conventional image of beauty that we saw earlier was finally beginning to take its toll.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ọdún tí a fi ń lé àwòran ẹwà ojoojúmọ́ tí a rí níbẹ́rẹ̀ ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní ní ìpadàbọ̀.

English: I wanted to do something about it, and so I started what I called the "No Heat Challenge," where I would refrain from using heat styling tools on my hair for six months.
Yoruba: Mo fẹ́ ṣe nǹkan nípa rẹ̀, nítorí náà ni mo ṣe bẹ̀rẹ nǹkan tí mop è ní “ìpèníjà kò sí oru,” níbi tí mo ti máa jáwọ́ nínú lílo àwọn irinṣẹ́ oru sí irun mi fún oṣù mẹ́fà.

English: And like a good millennial, I documented it on social media.
Yoruba: Bíi ẹgbẹ̀rún ọdún tó dára, mo ṣe àkójọpọ̀ rẹ̀ sórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára

English: I documented as I reluctantly cut off three to four inches of my beloved hair.
Yoruba: Mo ṣe àkójọpọ̀ rẹ̀ bí mo ṣe ń lọ́ tíkọ̀ láti gé ínṣì mẹ́ta sí mẹ́rin irun mi tí mo fẹ́ràn.

English: I documented as I struggled to master these natural hairstyles, and also as I struggled to embrace them and think that they actually looked good.
Yoruba: Mo ṣe àkójọpọ̀ bí mo ṣe ń tiraka láti mọ àwọn ìṣọwọ́ ṣerun àmútọ̀runwa wọ̀nyí, àti bí mo ṣe ń tiraka láti gbàwọ́n mọ́ra àti láti ronú wí pé wọ́n dára

English: And I documented as my hair texture slowly began to change.
Yoruba: Mo sì ṣe àkójọpọ̀ bí ìrísí irun mi ṣe bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní yí padà.

English: By sharing this journey openly, I learned that I was not the only woman going through this and that in fact there were thousands and thousands of other women who were longing to do the same.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú sísọ ìrìnàjò yí síta, mo kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wí pé èmi nìkan kọ́ ni obìnrin tó ń la èyí kọjá àti wí pé lóòótọ́ ẹgbẹ̀rún àti ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn obìnrin mìíràn ni wọ́n wà tí wọ́n ń fojú sọ́nà láti ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: So they would reach out to me and they would say, "Cheyenne, how did you do that natural hairstyle that I saw you with the other day?
Yoruba: Wọ́n máa ń kàn sími wọ́n a sì sọ wí pé, “Cheyenne, báwo loṣe ṣe ìṣọwọ́ ṣerun tí mo rí pẹ̀lú rẹ lọ́jọ́sí yẹn?

English: What new products have you started using that might be a little better for my hair texture as it begins to change?
Yoruba: Èròjà tuntun wo lo ti bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní lò tó lè tún dára fún ìrísí irun mi bó bá ṣe ń yípadà?

English: " Or, "What are some of the natural hair routines that I should begin to adopt to slowly restore the health of my hair?
Yoruba: “ Tàbí, “kíni àwọn ìgbésẹ̀ irun àmútọ̀runwá tí mo gbọ́dọ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní ṣe láti ṣe àdápadà ìlera irun mi díẹ̀díẹ̀?

English: " But I also found that there were a large number of women who were extremely hesitant to take that first step because they were paralyzed by fear.
Yoruba: “ Ṣùgbọ́n mo tún rí i wí pé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn obìnrin ló wà tí wọ́n ń kọ̀jálẹ̀ láti gbé ìgbésẹ̀ àkọ́kọ́ yẹn nítorí pé ìbẹ̀rù ti sọwọ́n di aláìlè dìde.

English: Fear of the unknown -- what would they now look like?
Yoruba: Ìbẹ̀ru ohun tó lè ṣẹlẹ̀ -- báwo ni àwọ́n ṣe fẹ́ rí?

English: How would they feel about themselves with these natural hairstyles?
Yoruba: Báwo ni àwọ́n ṣe máa rí ara àwọn pẹ̀lú ìṣọwọ́ ṣerun àmútọ̀run wá wọ̀nyí?

English: And most importantly to them, how would others view them?
Yoruba: Nǹkan tó ṣe pàtakì sí wọn jù, irú ojú wo ni àwọn tókù yóò ma fi wò wọ́n?

English: Over the last three years of having numerous conversations with friends of mine and also complete strangers from around the world, I learned some really important things about how African-American women identify with their hair.
Yoruba: Láti bí ọdún mẹ́ta tí mo ti ń ní àsọgbà tó pọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ mi àti àwọn aráata jákèjádò àgbáyé, mo ti kọ́ àwọn nǹkan tó ṣe pàtàkì púpọ̀ nípa bí àwọn obìnrin ọmọ ilẹ̀ America tó jẹ́ adúláwọ̀ ṣe ń di mímọ̀ pẹ̀lú irun wọn.

English: And so when I think back to that hiring manager in Mobile, Alabama, I'd say, "Actually, no.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo bá ronú padà sí gbígba alámòjútó sí Mobile, Alabama, màá sọ wí pé, “ní pátàkì, rárá.

English: We don't know what you're talking about.
Yoruba: A ò mọ nǹkan tí ẹ̀ ń sọ.

English: " But here are some things that we do know.
Yoruba: “ Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn nǹkan tí a mọ̀ rèé.

English: We know that when black women embrace their love for their natural hair, it helps to undo generations of teaching that black in its natural state is not beautiful, or something to be hidden or covered up.
Yoruba: A mọ̀ wí pé tí àwọn obìnrin adúláwọ̀ bá gba ìfẹ wọn fún irun àmútọ̀runwá wọn, ó máa ṣe ìrànwọ́ láti ṣe àyọkúrò iran ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wí pé aláwọ̀ dúdú nípò abínibí ò rẹwà, tàbí nǹkan tó yẹ kọ́ fi pamọ́ tàbí kí wọ́n bò.

English: We know that black women express their individuality and experience feelings of empowerment by experimenting with different hairstyles regularly.
Yoruba: A mọ̀ wí pé àwọn obìnrin adúláwọ̀ ń ṣàfihàn ìmọ̀lára àdáni àti ìrírí nípa ìrónilágbára pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe àyẹ̀wò pẹ̀lú oríṣiríṣi ìṣọ̀wọ́ ṣerun ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: And we also know that when we're invited to wear our natural hair in the workplace, it reinforces that we are uniquely valued and thus helps us to flourish and advance professionally.
Yoruba: A sì mọ̀ wí pé nígbà tí wọ́n bá pè wá láti gbé irun àmútọ̀runwa wa wá síbi iṣẹ́, ó máa ń ṣe ìwúrí wí pé wọ́n mọyì wa gan-an yóò sì ràn wá lọ́wọ́ láti dàgbàsókè àti láti tẹ̀síwájú gẹ́gẹ́ bi akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́.

English: I leave you with this.
Yoruba: Màá fiyín sílẹ̀ pẹ̀lú èyí.

English: In a time of racial and social tension, embracing this movement and others like this help us to rise above the confines of the status quo.
Yoruba: Lásíkò ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà àti àìnífọ́kànbalẹ̀ àwùjọ, gbígba ìtẹ̀síwájú yìí àti àti àwọn mìíràn bí èyí máa ń rànwá lọ́wọ́ láti gorí ìfúnpinpin bí a ṣe wà.

English: So when you see a woman with braids or locks draping down her back, or you notice your colleague who has stopped straightening her hair to work, do not simply approach her and admire and ask her if you can touch it -- Really appreciate her.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà tí ẹ bá rí obìnrin kan pẹ̀lú irun kíkó tàbí dàda tó gùn dé ẹ̀yin rẹ̀, tàbí ẹ ṣe àkíyèsí akẹgbẹ́ yín tó ti dáwọ́ nína irun rẹ̀ wá síbi iṣẹ́ dúró, ẹ má kàn lọ bá a kí ẹ má yìn ín àti kí ẹ béèrè bóyá ẹ lè fọwọ́ kàn-án nìkan -- Ẹ mọ ríri rẹ̀.

English: Applaud her.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣá a ní àtẹ́wọ́.

English: Heck, even high-five her if that's what you feel so inclined to do.
Yoruba: Kásàà, kódà ẹ bọ̀ ọ́ lọ́wọ́ tí ó bá ṣe wí pé nǹkan tí ẹ̀mí darí yín láti ṣe nìyẹn.

English: Because this -- this is more than about a hairstyle.
Yoruba: Nítorí èyí -- èyí ju nípa ìṣọwọ́ ṣerun lọ.

English: It's about self-love and self-worth.
Yoruba: Nípa ìfẹ́ràn ara ẹni àti ìmọyì ara ẹni ni.
