English: It's about being brave enough not to fold under the pressure of others' expectations.
Yoruba: Nípa níní ìgboyà láti má kàá sábẹ́ ipá ìrètí àwọn tókù ni.

English: And about knowing that making the decision to stray from the norm does not define who we are, but it simply reveals who we are.
Yoruba: Nípa mímọ̀ pé ṣíṣe ìpinnu láti yàbàrà láti àṣà náà ò ṣàpèjúwe irú èni tí a jẹ́, ṣùgbọ́n yóò ṣàfihàn irú èni tí a jẹ́.

English: And finally, being brave is easier when we can count on the compassion of others.
Yoruba: Ní ìparí, níní ìgboyà rọrùn nígbà ti a bá lè gbáralé ìkáàánú àwọn tó kù.

English: So after today, I certainly hope that we can count on you.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà lẹ́yìn ònìí, mo lérò wí pé a lè gbáralé e yín.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: Your fingerprints reveal more than you think
Yoruba: Òntẹ̀-ìka yín ń ṣàfihàn nǹkan ju bí ẹ ṣe lérò lọ

English: Do you ever stop and think, during a romantic dinner, "I've just left my fingerprints all over my wine glass.
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ ẹ ti ẹ̀ ti dúró kí ẹ sì ronú, lásíkò oúnjẹ-alẹ́ ìpẹ̀kínrẹ̀kí-olólùfẹ́ kan, “mo ṣẹ̀ṣẹ̀ fi òntẹ̀-ìka mi sí gbogbo ara ife-aláwòjìjí ọtí mi ni.

English: Or do you ever worry, when you visit a friend, about leaving a little piece of you behind on every surface that you touch?
Yoruba: Àbí ṣe ẹ rò ó rí, nígbà tí ẹ bá lọ kí ọ̀rẹ yín kan, nípa fífi oríkè díẹ̀ lára yín sílẹ̀ ní gbogbo àyè tí ẹ ti fọwọ́ kàn?

English: And even this evening, have you paid any attention to sit without touching anything?
Yoruba: Kódà lálẹ́ yìí, ǹjẹ́ ẹ ti ṣe àkíyèsí jíjókò láì fi ọwọ́ kan nǹkankan?

English: Well, you're not alone.
Yoruba: Ó dáa, ẹ ò dá wà.

English: Thankfully, criminals underestimate the power of fingerprints, too.
Yoruba: Ìkúnfúnọpẹ́, àwọn ọ̀daràn ń ṣàfojúdi agbára òntẹ̀-ìka, bákan náà.

English: And I'm not just talking about the twisted parting of lines that make our fingerprint unique.
Yoruba: Mi ò sọ̀ nípa àwọn ilà lílọ́pọ̀ tí wọ́n jẹ́ kí òntẹ̀-ìka wá yátọ̀ gédéngbé nìkan.

English: I'm talking about an entire world of information hiding in a small, often invisible thing.
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa odidi àgbáramúramú ìfitóni t’ó sá pamọ́ sára nǹkan kékeré, tí ò ṣe é fojú rí lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà.

English: In fact, fingerprints are made up of molecules that belong to three classes: sweat molecules that we all produce in very different amounts molecules that we introduce into our body and then we sweat out and molecules that we may contaminate our fingertips with when we come across substances like blood, paint, grease, but also invisible substances.
Yoruba: Ní òótọ́, òntẹ̀-ìka jẹ́ àpapọ̀ àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tí wọ́n wà ní ẹ̀ka mẹ́ta: ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ àágùn tí à ń ṣẹ́ ní iye ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tó yátọ̀ tí à ń lò sínú ara wa tí a bá sì làágùn síta àti àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tí ó ń ṣàkóbá etí ọmọ-ìka wa tí a bá ṣe alábàpádè àwọn nǹkan bí ẹ̀jẹ̀, ọ̀dà, gírísì, àti àwọn nǹkan àìfojúrí.

English: And molecules are the storytellers of who we are and what we've been up to.
Yoruba: Ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ jẹ́ asọ̀tàn nípa irú ẹni tí à ń ṣe àti àti nǹkan tí a ti ṣe.

English: We just need to have the right technology to make them talk.
Yoruba: A kọ̀ nílò láti ní ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tó tọ́ láti jẹ́ kí wọ́n sọ̀rọ̀ ni.

English: So let me take you on a journey of unthinkable capabilities.
Yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ kí n múu yín rin ìrìnàjò ìkápá aláìlérò kan.

English: Katie has been raped and her lifeless body has been found in the woods three days later, after her disappearance.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ti fipá bá Katie lájọṣepọ̀ wọ́n sì ti rí òku rẹ̀ nínú igbó, lẹ́yìn ọjọ́ mẹ́ta tí ó pòórá.

English: The police is targeting three suspects, having narrowed down the search from over 20 men who had been seen in that area on the same day.
Yoruba: Awọn ọlọ́pàá ń tọpa àwọn afurasí mẹ́ta, lẹ́yìn ìgbà tí wọ́n mú ìtọpa ìwádìí àwọn afurasí wọn wálẹ̀ láti 20 ọkùnrin tí wọ́n ti rí ní agbègbè náà lọ́jọ́ yẹn náà.

English: The only piece of evidence is two very faint, overlapping fingerprints on the tape that was found wrapped around Katie's neck.
Yoruba: Èrí kan ṣoṣo ni òntẹ̀-ìka méjì tí kò hàn rere, àgbélérawọn lórí àjábùlẹ̀ tí wọ́n wé mọ́ ọrùn Katie tí wọ́n rí.

English: Often, faint and overlapping fingerprints cannot help the police to make an identification.
Yoruba: Lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà, òntẹ̀-ìka tí kò hàn rere, t’ó wà lórí ara wọn kò lè ran àwọn ọlọ́pàá lọ́wọ́ láti ṣe ìdánimọ̀.

English: And until recently, this might have been the end of the road, but this is where we can make the difference.
Yoruba: Àfi láìpẹ́ yìí, èyí ò bá ti jẹ òpin ọ̀nà, ṣùgbọ́n ibí tí a ti lè ṣe àtúnṣe nìyí.

English: The tape is sent to our labs, where we're asked to use our cutting-edge technology to help with the investigation.
Yoruba: Wọ́n fi àjábùlẹ̀ náà ránṣẹ́ sí àyè fún ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ wa, níbi tí wọ́n ti ní k’á lo ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ aláìlẹ́gbẹ́ wa láti ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ fún ìtọpinpin náà.

English: And here, we use an existing form of mass spectrometry imaging technology that we have further developed and adapted specifically for the molecular and imaging analysis of fingerprints.
Yoruba: Níbí, a lo ẹ̀dà ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ àṣàwòrán ẹ̀rọ igbọ̀n agbọ̀n ńlá tó wà nílẹ̀ tí a ti ṣe ìdàgbàsókè rẹ̀ síwájú síi tí a ṣe ní àdáyanrí fún ìyànàna ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ àti àwòran òntẹ̀-ìka.

English: In essence, we fire a UV laser at the print, and we cause the desorption of the molecules from the print, ready to be captured by the mass spectrometer.
Yoruba: Ní pàtàkì, a bẹ́ná ìtànṣán UV sí òntẹ̀ náà, a sì mú kí ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ náà ó yọ kúrò lára òntẹ̀ náà, t’ó ti ṣe tán láti di yíya pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rọ òdiwọ̀n-ìbìlù àkópọ̀.

English: Mass spectrometry measures the weight of the molecules -- or as we say, the mass -- and those numbers that you see there, they indicate that mass.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ òdiwọ̀n-ìbìlù àkópọ̀ máa dìwọ̀n ìwúwo ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ náà -- tàbí bí a ṣe sọ, ìwọn àkópọ̀ -- àti àwọn oǹkà tí ẹ̀ ń wò níbẹ̀ yẹn, wọ́n ń ṣàfihàn ìwọ̀n àkópọ̀ yẹn.

English: But more crucially, they indicate who those molecules are -- whether I'm seeing paracetamol or something more sinister, forensically speaking.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní pàtàkì jùlọ, wọ́n ń ṣàfihàn ẹni tí àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wọ̀nyí jẹ́ -- bóyá mò ń rí paracetamol tàbí nǹkan tó tún léwu jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ, tí a bá ń sọ̀rọ̀ nílàna ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀.

English: We applied this technology to the evidence that we have and we found the presence of condom lubricants.
Yoruba: A sàmúlò ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ yìí sí èrí tí a ní a dè rí ìdúró ìmúdiyíyọ̀ rọ́bà ìdáààbòbò.

English: In fact, we've developed protocols that enable us to even suggest what brand of condom might have been used.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́, a ti ṣe ìdàgbàsókè ìlànà-àátẹ̀lé tí yóò fún wa ní àǹfààní láti dábàá irú rọ́bà ìdáààbòbò tí wọ́n lò.

English: So we pass this information to the police, who, meanwhile, have obtained a search warrant and they found the same brand of condom in Dalton's premises.
Yoruba: A fi afitóni yìí ránṣẹ́ sí àwọn ọlọ́pàá, tí wọ́n, láímọ̀, ti gba àṣẹ láti túlé wọ́n sì ti rí irú rọ́bà idáààbòbò yìí kan náà ní àyíká ilé Dalton.

English: And with Dalton and Thomson also having records for sexual assaults, then it is Chapman that may become the less likely suspect.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú pé Dalton àti Thomson tún ní àkọsílẹ̀ ìfipábánilòpọ̀, a jẹ́ wí pé Chapman ló lè di ẹni tí a lè má furasí púpọ̀

English: But is this information enough to make an arrest?
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ṣe afitóni yìí tó láti fi àṣẹ ọba mú?

English: Of course not, and we are asked to delve deeper with our investigation.
Yoruba: Rárá, wọ́n sì sọ fún wa pé ká túṣu désálẹ̀ ìkòkò pẹ̀lú ìwádìí wa.

English: So we found out, also, the presence of other two very interesting molecules.
Yoruba: A ṣàwárí rẹ̀, bákan náà, ìdúró àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ méjì tó yanilẹ́nu.

English: One is an antidepressant, and one is a very special molecule.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan jẹ́ apa-ìrẹ̀wẹ̀sì-ọkàn, ọ̀kan sì jẹ́ ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ molecule tó yátọ̀ gidi gan-an.

English: It only forms in your body if you drink alcohol and consume cocaine at the same time.
Yoruba: Ó máa ń dì sára nígbà tí ẹ bá mu ọtí tàbí lo oògùn-olóró lásíkò kan náà.

English: And alcohol is known to potentiate the effects of cocaine, so here, we now have a hint on the state of mind of the individual whilst perpetrating the crime.
Yoruba: A sì mọ ọtí pé ó máa ń ṣe ìrólágbára fún ipa oògùn-olóró, nítorí náà níbí, a ti ní afitóni nípa ipò ẹ̀mí ẹni náà nígbà t’ó ń hu ìwà ọ̀daràn náà.

English: We passed this information to the police, and they found out that, actually, Thomson is a drug addict, and he also has a medical record for psychotic episodes, for which presumably the antidepressant was prescribed.
Yoruba: A fi afitóni yìí ránṣẹ́ sí àwọn ọlọ́pàá, wọ́n ṣàwárí rẹ̀ pé, lóòótọ́, Thomson kúndùn oògùn-olóró, ó sì ní àkọsílẹ̀ ìwòsàn agàná, fún èyì tó ṣe wí pé bóyá torí rẹ̀ ni wọ́n ṣe ṣe àṣàyàn apa-ìrẹ̀wẹ̀sì-ọkàn.

English: So now Thomson becomes the more likely suspect.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí Thomson ti di afurasí tó ṣe é ṣe.

English: But the reality is that I still don't know where these molecules are coming from, from which fingerprint, and who those two fingerprints belong to.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbón òdodo ibẹ̀ ni wí pé mi ò tíì mọ ibi tí àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wọ̀nyí ti ń wá, láti òntẹ̀-ìka wo, àti eni tí àwọn òntẹ̀-ìka méjì yìí jẹ́ tirẹ̀.

English: Fear not.
Yoruba: Ẹ má bẹ́rù.

English: Mass spectrometry imaging can help us further.
Yoruba: Ẹ̀rọ igbọ̀n agbọ̀n ńlá lè ràn wá lọ́wọ́ síwájú síi.

English: In fact, the technology is so powerful that we can see where these molecules are on a fingerprint.
Yoruba: Lódodo, ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ náà lágbára gidi gan-an débi wí pé a lè rí ibi tí àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wọ̀nyí wà lórí òntẹ̀-ìka.

English: Like you see in this video, every single one of those peaks corresponds to a mass, every mass to a molecule, and we can interrogate the software, by selecting each of those molecules, as to where they are present on a fingermark.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹ ṣe rí i nínú fọ́rán yìí, ọ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan àwọn tí wọ́n gajù wọ̀nyẹn túmọ̀ sí ìwọ̀n-okun, ìwọ̀n-okun kọ̀ọ̀kan sí ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ kan, a sì lè fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn náà lẹ́nu wò, pẹ̀lú mímú ìkọ̀ọ̀kan àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn, nípa ibi tí wọ́n wà lórí àpá-ìka náà.

English: And some images are not very revealing, some are better, some are really good.
Yoruba: Àwọn àwòràn kan ò kí ń f’ara hàn dáadáa, àwọn kan dára, àwọn kan dára gidi gan-an.

English: And we can create multiple images of the same mark -- in theory, hundreds of images of the same fingerprint -- for as many of the molecules that we have detected.
Yoruba: A ṣẹ̀dá ọ̀pọ̀ àwòrán àpá kan náà -- ní tíọ́rì, ọgọ́rùn àwòran òntẹ̀-ìka kan náà -- fún gbogbo iye ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tí a ti rí.

English: So step one for overlapping fingerprints, chances are, especially if they come from different individuals, that the molecular composition is not identical, so let's ask the software to visualize those unique molecules just present in one fingermark and not in the other one.
Yoruba: Ìgbésẹ̀ àkọ́kọ́ fún òntẹ̀-ìka tó gorí ara wọn, àǹfààní ni pé, pàápàá jùlọ tí wọ́n bá wá látara oríṣiríṣi ènìyàn, pé ìṣẹ̀da ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ náà kò jọra wọn, nítorí náà ẹ jẹ́ k’á béèrè lọ́wọ́ ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn láti wo àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ aṣèyàtò tó wà nínú òntẹ̀-ìka kan tí ò sí ní ìkejì.

English: By doing so, that's how we can separate the two ridge patterns.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, bí a ṣe lè ṣe ìyàsọ́tọ̀ bátánì etíi méjééjì nìyẹn.

English: And this is really important because the police now are able to identify one of the two fingerprints, which actually corresponds to Katie.
Yoruba: Èyí sì ṣe pàtàkì nítorí àwọn ọlọ́pàá lè tọ́ka sí ọ̀kan nínú òntẹ̀-ìka méjééjì báyìí, tó bá ti Katie mu.

English: And they've been able to say so because they've compared the two separate images with one taken posthumously from Katie.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ti lè sọ bẹ́ẹ̀ nítorí pé wọ́n ti fi àwòrá méjì ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ náà wéra wọn pẹ̀lú ìkan tí wọ́n mú látara òku Katie.

English: So now, we can concentrate on one fingerprint only -- that of the killer's.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, a lè gbájúmọ́ òntẹ̀-ìka kan ṣoṣo -- tó jẹ́ ti aṣekúpani yẹn.

English: So then, step two where are these three molecules that I've seen?
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn náà, ìgbésẹ̀ kejì àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ mẹ́ta wọ̀nyí tí mo ti rí yìí dà?

English: Well, let's interrogate the software -- show me where they are.
Yoruba: Ó dáa, ẹ jẹ́ k’á fi ọ̀rọ̀ wá ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn náà lẹ́nu wò -- fi ibi tí wọ́n wà hàn mí.

English: And by doing this, only portions of the image of the killer's fingerprint show up.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe èyí, apá kan àwòrán òntẹ̀-ìka aṣekúpani náà nìkan l’ó hàn.

English: In other words, those substances are only present in the killer's print.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn ni wí pé, àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyẹn wà nínú òntẹ̀ aṣekúpani náà nìkan ni.

English: So now our molecular findings start matching very nicely the police intelligence about Thomson, should that fingerprint belong to him.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí aṣàwárí ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ wa bẹ́rẹ̀ síní bá ìwádìí àwọn olọ́pà nípa Thomson mu dáadáa, tí ó bá jẹ́ wí pé òun ló ni òntẹ̀-ìka yẹn.

English: But the reality is that that print is still not good enough to make an identification.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n òtítọ́ ibẹ̀ ni wí pé ọ̀ntẹ̀ yẹn ò tíì dára tó láti ṣe ìdánímọ̀.

English: Step three: since we can generate hundreds of images of the same fingerprint, why don't we superimpose them, and by doing so, try to improve the rich pattern of continuity and clarity?
Yoruba: Ìgbésẹ̀ kẹ́ta: nígbà tó jé wí pé a lè ṣẹ̀da ọgọ́rùn àwòrán òntẹ̀ ìka kan náà, kí ló dé tí a ò gbé wọn sórí ara wọn, tí a bá ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, ká gbìyànjú láti ṣe àfikún bátánì ìtẹ̀síwájú àti ìfojúhàn tó kún?

English: That's the result.
Yoruba: Èsì náà nìyẹn.

English: We now have a very clear image of the fingerprint and the police can run it through the database.
Yoruba: A ti wá ní àwòrán òntẹ̀-ìka tó hàn kedere àwọn ọlọ́pàá sì le lò ó lórí àká-ìwífún-alálàyé.

English: The match comes out to Thomson.
Yoruba: Ìbámu náà jáde sí ti Thomson.

English: Thomson is our killer.
Yoruba: Thomson ni aṣekúpani wa.

English: Katie, the suspects and the circumstances of the crime aren't real, but the story contains elements of the real police casework we've been confronted with, and is a composite of the intelligence that we can provide -- that we have been able to provide the police.
Yoruba: Katie, afurasí náà àti àwọn nǹkan tó rọ̀ mọ́ ìwà-ọ̀daràn náà kìí ṣe tòótọ́, ṣùgbọ́n ìtàn náà ní àwọn ọmọlẹ̀ iṣẹ́-ìwádìí ọlọ́pàá tòótọ́ tí a ti kojú rẹ̀, ó sì jẹ́ ẹ̀ka ìwádìí tí a lè pèsè -- tí a ti pèsè fún àwọn olọ́pàá.

English: And I'm really, really thrilled that after nine years of intense research, as of 2017, we are able to contribute to police investigations.
Yoruba: Inú mi sì ń dùn gidi gan-an pé lẹ́yìn ọdún mẹ́sàn ìwádìí alágbára, ní ọdún 2017, a ní àǹfààní láti dásí ìtọpinpin àwọn ọlọ́pàá.

English: Mine is no longer a dream; it's a goal.
Yoruba: Tèmi kìí ṣe àlá mọ́; ìpinnu ni.

English: We're going to do this wider and wider, bigger and bigger, and we're going to know more about the suspect, and we're going to build an identikit.
Yoruba: A máa ṣe èyí ní fífẹ̀ àti fífẹ̀, ńlá àti ńlá, a sì ma nímọ̀ si nípa afurasí náà, a sì ma ṣẹ̀dá ẹ̀rọ-ìdánimọ̀.

English: I believe this is also a new era for criminal profiling.
Yoruba: Mo nígbàgbọ́ pé ìgbà ọ̀tun ni èyí fún ṣíṣe àkọsílẹ̀ ìwà-ọ̀daràn.

English: The work of the criminologist draws on the expert recognition of behavioral patterns that have been observed before to belong to a certain type, to a certain profile.
Yoruba: Iṣẹ́ ìwádìí ìwà ọ̀daràn máa ń lo ìdámọ̀ àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ nípa bátánì ìhùwàsí tí wọ́n ti ṣàkíyèsí tẹ́lẹ̀ pé ó jẹ́ ti ẹ̀yà kan, sí àkọsílẹ̀ kan.

English: As opposed to this expert but subjective evaluation, we're trying to do the same thing, but from the molecular makeup of the fingerprint, and the two can work together.
Yoruba: Ní àtakò sí àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ yìí ṣùgbọ́n ní aṣègbè ìgbéléwọ̀n, à ń gbìyànjú láti ṣe nǹkan kan náà, ṣùgbọ́n látara ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ tó papọ̀ di òntẹ̀-ìka, méjééì sì lè ṣiṣẹ́ papọ̀.

English: I did say that molecules are storytellers, so information on your health, your actions, your lifestyle, your routines, they're all there, accessible in a fingerprint.
Yoruba: Mo sọ wí pé àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ jẹ́ asọ̀tàn, nítorí náà àwọn afitóni nípa ìlera yín, ìṣesí yín, ìgbeayé yín, iṣẹ́ yín, gbogbo wọn ló wà níbẹ̀, tó ṣe é wò nínú òntẹ̀-ìka kan.

English: And molecules are the storytellers of our secrets in just a touch.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìdá-kékééké-nǹkan-tí-ó-ṣù-pọ̀ jẹ́ asọ̀tàn nípa àṣírí wa pẹ̀lú ìfọwọ́kàn kan.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ seun.

English: (Audience) Wow.
Yoruba: (Àwọn ònwòran) Wow.

English: Our immigration conversation is broken - here's how to have a better one
Yoruba: Asọgbà ìwọlé látókère wa ti fọ́ - bí a ṣe lè ní èyí tó dára rè é.

English: We often hear these days that the immigration system is broken.
Yoruba: A máa ń gbọ́ lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà lásíkò yìí pé èto ìwọlé látókèèrè ti fọ́.

English: I want to make the case today that our immigration conversation is broken and to suggest some ways that, together, we might build a better one.
Yoruba: Mo fẹ́ ṣe ìpẹ̀jọ́ lónì pé àsọgbà ìwọlé látókèère wa ti fọ́ àti láti dábàá àwọn ọ̀nà tí, lápapọ̀, a lè pèsè èyí tó dára.

English: In order to do that, I'm going to propose some new questions about immigration, the United States and the world, questions that might move the borders of the immigration debate.
Yoruba: Láti lè ṣe ìyẹn, màá dábàá àwọn ìbéèrè tuntun nípa ìwọlé látókèèrè, orílẹ̀-ède United States àti àgbáyé, àwọn ìbéèrè tí ó lè sún àríyànjiyàn ibodè ìwọlé látókèrè.

English: I'm not going to begin with the feverish argument that we're currently having, even as the lives and well-being of immigrants are being put at risk at the US border and far beyond it.
Yoruba: Mi ò ní bẹ́rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àríyànjiyàn tó ń ṣòjòjò tí à ń ní lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí, kódà bí ìgbéayé àti ìgbáyégbádùn àwọn aṣíkiri ṣe ń wà nínú ewu ní enu-ibodè orílẹ̀-ède US àti jù bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ.

English: Instead, I'm going to begin with me in graduate school in New Jersey in the mid-1990s, earnestly studying US history, which is what I currently teach as a professor at Vanderbilt University in Nashville, Tennessee.
Yoruba: Dípò bẹ́ẹ̀, màá bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ara mi ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́-jáde ní New Jersey ní àrín àsìko 1990, tí mò ń kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa ìtan orílẹ̀-ède US, tó jẹ́ nǹkan tí mò ń kọ́ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ọjọ̀gbọ́n ní fásitì Vanderbilt ní Nashville, Tennessee.

English: And when I wasn't studying, sometimes to avoid writing my dissertation, my friends and I would go into town to hand out neon-colored flyers, protesting legislation that was threatening to take away immigrants' rights.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mi ò bá kẹ́kọ̀ọ́, nígbà míràn láti sá fún kíkọ àpilẹ̀kọ àbọ̀ ìwádìí mi, èmi àti àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ mi máa wọ ìgboro lọ láti lọ fún àwọn ènìyàn ní ìwé-ìléwọ́ alárà-n-bara àwọ̀, tó ń fi èhónú han sí òfin tó ń dúkokò láti gba ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn aṣíkiri.

English: Our flyers were sincere, they were well-meaning, they were factually accurate.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìwé ìléwọ́ wa ṣòótọ́, wọ́n nítumọ̀ gidi, wọ́n péye ní òtítọ́.

English: But I realize now, they were also kind of a problem.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó wá yémi báyìí, wọ́n tún fẹ́ẹ̀ jẹ́ oríṣi wàhálà kan.

English: Here's what they said: "Don't take away immigrant rights to public education, to medical services, to the social safety net.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí wọ́n sọ rè é: “ẹ má gba ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn aṣíkiri sí ẹ̀kọ́ gbogbogbò, sí ètò ìlere, sí àwọ̀n ààbò àwùjọ.

English: They work hard.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára.

English: They pay taxes.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ń sanwó-orí.

English: They're law-abiding.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ń tẹ̀lé òfin.

English: They use social services less than Americans do.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ò lo àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ àwùjọ tó bí àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America ṣe ń lò ó.

English: They're eager to learn English, and their children serve in the US military all over the world.
Yoruba: Wọ́n nífẹ̀ láti kọ́ ède gẹ̀ẹ́sì, àwọn ọmọ wọn sì ń sìnrú-ìlú nínú ikọ̀ ọmọ-ogun orílẹ̀-ède US káàkiri àgbáyé.

English: " Now, these are, of course, arguments that we hear every day.
Yoruba: “ Báyìí, àwọn wọ̀nyí ni, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn àríyànjiyàn tí à ń gbọ́ lójoojúmọ́.

English: Immigrants and their advocates use them as they confront those who would deny immigrants their rights or even exclude them from society.
Yoruba: Àwọn aṣíkiri àti àwọn agbẹnusọ wọn ń lò wọ́n láti fi kojú àwọn tí wọn yóò fi ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn aṣíkiri dú wọ́n tàbí tí wọ́n fẹ́ yọ wọ́n kúrò nínú àwùjọ.

English: And up to a certain point, it makes perfect sense that these would be the kinds of claims that immigrants' defenders would turn to.
Yoruba: Dé ìpele kan, ó mú ọpọlọ dání pé àwọn wọ̀nyí yóò jẹ́ irú àwíjàre tí àwọn tí wọ́n ń gbè lẹ́yìn àwọn aṣíkiri máa kọjú sí.

English: But in the long term, and maybe even in the short term, I think these arguments can be counterproductive.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà pípẹ́, àti bóyá lásíkò díẹ̀, mo rò wí pé àwọn àríyànjiyàn wọ̀nyí lè díra wọn lọ́wọ́.

English: Because it's always an uphill battle to defend yourself on your opponent's terrain.
Yoruba: Torí ogun tó lágbára ló máa ń jẹ́ láti gbèja ara yín ní agbègbe alátakò yín.

English: And, unwittingly, the handouts my friends and I were handing out and the versions of these arguments that we hear today were actually playing the anti-immigrants game.
Yoruba: pẹ̀lú àìmọ̀kan, ìwé-ìléwọ́ tí èmi àti àwọn ọ̀rẹ́ mi ń fún àwọn ènìyàn àti ẹ̀dà àwọn àríyànjiyàn wọ̀nyí tí à ń gbọ́ lóni ń tayò atako-aṣíkiri ni.

English: We were playing that game in part by envisioning that immigrants were outsiders, rather than, as I'm hoping to suggest in a few minutes, people that are already, in important ways, on the inside.
Yoruba: À ń ta ayò yẹn lóríkè pẹ̀lú ojú-ìwòye pé aráàta ni àwọn aṣíkiri, yàtọ̀ sí pé, bí mo ṣe ń lérò láti dá lábà ní ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀, àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ti, ní àwọn ọ̀nà tó ṣe pàtàkì, wà nínú ilé tẹ́lẹ̀.

English: It's those who are hostile to immigrants, the nativists, who have succeeded in framing the immigration debate around three main questions.
Yoruba: Àwọn tí wọ́n ń dẹ́yẹsí àwọn aṣíkiri, àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú, tí wọ́n ti ṣàṣeyọrí níbi síso àríyànjiyàn ìwọlé látókèrè mọ́ kókó ìbéèrè mẹ́ta.

English: First, there's the question of whether immigrants can be useful tools.
Yoruba: Àkọ́kọ́, ìbéèrè kán wà nípa bóyá àwọn aṣíkiri lè di irinṣẹ́ tó wúlò.

English: How can we use immigrants?
Yoruba: Báwo la ṣe lè lo àwọn aṣíkiri?

English: Will they make us richer and stronger?
Yoruba: Ṣé wọ́n máa jé ká lówó ká sì tún lágbára síi?

English: The nativist answer to this question is no, immigrants have little or nothing to offer.
Yoruba: Ìdáhùn àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ ìlú sí ìbéèrè yìí ni rárá, àwọn aṣíkiri ní díẹ̀ tàbí wọn ò ní nǹkankan láti fún wa.

English: The second question is whether immigrants are others.
Yoruba: Ìbéèrè kejì ni wí pé bóyá àwọn aṣíkiri jẹ́ àwọn tókù.

English: Can immigrants become more like us?
Yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ àwọn aṣíkiri lè di ara wa?

English: Are they capable of becoming more like us?
Yoruba: Ṣé wọ́n níkàpá láti dàbi wa?

English: Are they capable of assimilating?
Yoruba: Ṣé wọ́n níkàpá láti farajọwá?

English: Are they willing to assimilate?
Yoruba: Ṣé wọ́n ṣe tán láti farajọwá?

English: Here, again, the nativist answer is no, immigrants are permanently different from us and inferior to us.
Yoruba: Níbí, lẹ́ẹ̀kan síi, ìdáhùn àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú ni rárá, àwọn aṣíkiri yátọ̀ pátápátá sí wa wọ́n sì kéré síwa.

English: And the third question is whether immigrants are parasites.
Yoruba: Ìbéèrè kẹ́ta ni bóyá àwọn aṣíkiri jẹ́ ajọ̀fẹ́.

English: Are they dangerous to us?
Yoruba: Ṣé wọ́n léwu fún wa?

English: And will they drain our resources?
Yoruba: Ṣé wọ́n máa gbọ́n ohun-àlùmọ́nì wa gbẹ?

English: Here, the nativist answer is yes and yes, immigrants pose a threat and they sap our wealth.
Yoruba: Níbí, ìdáhùn àwọn ọmọ ìlú ni bẹ́ẹ̀ ni àti bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn aṣíkiri lè fa ewu wọ́n sì ń gbọ́n ọrọ̀ọ wa gbẹ.

English: I would suggest that these three questions and the nativist animus behind them have succeeded in framing the larger contours of the immigration debate.
Yoruba: Máa dá a lábà wí pé àwọn ìbéèrè mẹ́ta wọ̀nyí àti ìpinnu àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú tó wà lẹ́yìn wọn ti ṣe aṣeyọrí níbi ṣíṣe àwọn igun ńlá nípa àríyànjiyàn ìwọlé látókèrè.

English: These questions are anti-immigrant and nativist at their core, built around a kind of hierarchical division of insiders and outsiders, us and them, in which only we matter, and they don't.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí jẹ́ atako-àwọn aṣíkiri àti àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ ìlú paraku, tí wọ́n sopọ̀ mọ́ ìpín onípele àgbékà àwọn arálé àti aráàta, àwa àti àwọn, tó jẹ́ wí pé àwa la ṣe pàtàkì jùlọ, tí àwọn ò sì rí bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: And what gives these questions traction and power beyond the circle of committed nativists is the way they tap into an everyday, seemingly harmless sense of national belonging and activate it, heighten it and inflame it.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tó ń fún àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí ní òkìkí àti agbára tayọ ẹgbẹ́ àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú tí wọ́n ní àfọkànsìn ni bí wọ́n ṣe ń pín nínú òye àjọgbépọ̀ àpapọ̀ ojoojúmọ́ tí ò léwu tí wọ́n sì ń ṣàmúlò rẹ̀, tí wọ́n ń gbé e sókè tí wọ́n sì ń fún-un lágbára.

English: Nativists commit themselves to making stark distinctions between insiders and outsiders.
Yoruba: Àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú ti jọ̀wọ́ ara wọn fún ṣiṣe ìyàtọ̀ tó fojú hàn láàárín aráalé àti aráàta.

English: But the distinction itself is at the heart of the way nations define themselves.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ìyàtọ̀ náà fún ra rẹ̀ wà ní gbùngun ọ̀nà tí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè ń gbà ṣe àpèjúwe ara wọn.

English: The fissures between inside and outside, which often run deepest along lines of race and religion, are always there to be deepened and exploited.
Yoruba: Ìyàtọ̀ tó wà láàárín inú àti ìta, to ṣe wí pé lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà o máa ń sá wọ ojú ọ̀nà ìran àti ẹ̀sìn, máa ń wà níbẹ̀ láti jinú àti láti di àmúlò.

English: And that potentially gives nativist approaches resonance far beyond those who consider themselves anti-immigrant, and remarkably, even among some who consider themselves pro-immigrant.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn sì ń fún àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ ìlú ní ọ̀nà-ìmúṣe alátapadà tayọ àwọn tí wọ́n ríra wọn bíi atako àwọn aṣíkiri, àti lílù lọ́gọ-ẹnu, kódà láàárín àwọn kan tí wọ́n ríra wọn gẹ́gẹ́ bi alátìlẹyìn àwọn aṣíkiri.

English: So, for example, when Immigrants Act allies answer these questions the nativists are posing, they take them seriously.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, nígbà tí àwọn alátìlẹyìn ìwé-òfin àwọn aṣíkiri dáhùn àwọn ìbéèrè tí àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú ń gbé jáde wọ̀nyí, wọ́n mú wọn lọ́kùkúdùn.

English: They legitimate those questions and, to some extent, the anti-immigrant assumptions that are behind them.
Yoruba: Wọ́n sọ àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí di òfin àti, dé àwọn àyè kan, ìmọ̀ọ́nú àwọn atako-aṣíkiri tí wọ́n wà lẹ́yìn wọn.

English: When we take these questions seriously without even knowing it, we're reinforcing the closed, exclusionary borders of the immigration conversation.
Yoruba: Bí a bá mú àwọn ìbéèrè wònyí lọ́kùnkúndùn láìnímọ̀ nípa ẹ̀, à ń ṣe ìwúrí fún títì, àyọkúrò àsọgbà ibodè ìwọlé látókèrè.

English: So how did we get here?
Yoruba: Torí náà báwo la ṣe débí?

English: How did these become the leading ways that we talk about immigration?
Yoruba: Báwo ni àwọn wọ̀nyí ṣe di ònà tó ń léwájú tí a fi ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa ìwọlé látókèrè?

English: Here, we need some backstory, which is where my history training comes in.
Yoruba: Níbí, a nílò àwọn ìtàn-ìpìlẹ̀, tó jẹ́ ibi tí ìdánilẹ́kọ̀ ìtàn mi yóò ti wọlé.

English: During the first century of the US's status as an independent nation, it did very little to restrict immigration at the national level.
Yoruba: Lásíkò ọrún ọdún àkọ́kọ́ ipò orílẹ̀-ède US gẹ́gẹ́ bi orílẹ̀-ède olómìnira, ó ṣe díẹ̀ láti ṣe ìdíwọ́ ìwọlé látókèrè ní ìpele orílẹ̀-èdè.

English: In fact, many policymakers and employers worked hard to recruit immigrants to build up industry and to serve as settlers, to seize the continent.
Yoruba: Ní tòótọ́, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn aṣòfin àti àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ń ṣiṣẹ́ kárakára láti gba àwọn aṣíkiri láti ṣẹ̀dá ilé-iṣẹ́ àti láti ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bi atẹ̀dó, láti gba ẹkùn náà.

English: But after the Civil War, nativist voices rose in volume and in power.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n lẹ́yìn ogun abẹ́lé, ohùn àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú gókè ní yíyí àti ní agbára

English: The Asian, Latin American, Caribbean and European immigrants who dug Americans' canals, cooked their dinners, fought their wars and put their children to bed at night were met with a new and intense xenophobia, which cast immigrants as permanent outsiders who should never be allowed to become insiders.
Yoruba: Àwọn ilẹ̀ Asia, Latin America, Caribbean àti àwọn aṣíkiri ilẹ̀-Europe tí wọ́n gbé kòtò-ìdaminù àwọn ọmọ-ilẹ̀ America, tí wọ́n ń dáná alẹ́ wọn, tí wọ́n ń jagun wọn tí wọ́n sì ń rẹ àwọn ọmọ wọn tẹ́ lálẹ́ ni wọ́n ṣe alábàápàde ìbẹ̀ru aráàta tuntun tó le, tó pín àwọn aṣíkiri gẹ́gẹ́ bi aráàta pátápátá tí wọn ò gbọdọ̀ gbà láyè láti di aráalé.

English: By the mid-1920s, the nativists had won, erecting racist laws that closed out untold numbers of vulnerable immigrants and refugees.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí yó fi di àrín àsìko 1920, àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú ti borí, gbígbé òfin ẹlẹ́yàmẹ̀yà dìde  ṣe agbétìsíta iye àwọn aṣíkiri tó kọ́gun-séwu àti àwọn ogúnléndé tí wọn ò sọ síta.

English: Immigrants and their allies did their best to fight back, but they found themselves on the defensive, caught in some ways in the nativists' frames.
Yoruba: Àwọn aṣíkiri àti àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn sapá wọn láti jà padà, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n bára wọn lẹ́ni tó ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn, wọ́n káwọn ní àwọn ọ̀nà kọ̀ọ̀kan nínú ìṣe àtìlẹ́yìn fún àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú.

English: When nativists said that immigrants weren't useful, their allies said yes, they are.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú sọ wí pé àwọn aṣíkiri ò wúlò, àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn ní bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, wọ́n wúlò.

English: When nativists accused immigrants of being others, their allies promised that they would assimilate.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú fi ẹ̀sùn kan àwọn aṣíkiri wí pé àwọn tókù niwọ́n, àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn ṣe àdéhùn pé wọ́n máa fara jọwọ́n.

English: When nativists charged that immigrants were dangerous parasites, their allies emphasized their loyalty, their obedience, their hard work and their thrift.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn alátìlẹyin ọmọ-ìlú fẹ̀sùn kàn wọn pé àwọn aṣíkiri jẹ́ ajọ̀fẹ́ tó léwu, àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn ṣe ìfirinlẹ̀ ìjólóòótọ́ wọn, ìgbọ́ràn wọn, ìṣiṣẹ́ kára wọn àti àìnáwó-nínàkúnà wọn.

English: Even as advocates welcomed immigrants, many still regarded immigrants as outsiders to be pitied, to be rescued, to be uplifted and to be tolerated, but never fully brought inside as equals in rights and respect.
Yoruba: Kódà bí àwọn agbẹnusọ ṣe ń gba àwọn aṣíkiri mọ́ra, ọ̀pọ́ ṣì ń ka àwọn aṣíkiri sí aráàta tó yẹ kí wọ́n káànú, tó yẹ kí wọ́n dóòlà, tó yẹ kí wọ́n gbéga kí wọ́n sì gbà mọ́ra, ṣùgbọ́n tí wọn ò ní mú wọlé gẹ́gẹ́ bi adọ́gba ní ẹ̀tọ́ àti ọ̀wọ̀.

English: After World War II, and especially from the mid-1960s until really recently, immigrants and their allies turned the tide, overthrowing mid-20th century restriction and winning instead a new system that prioritized family reunification, the admission of refugees and the admission of those with special skills.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ogun àgbáyé kejì, pàápàá jùlọ láti àrín àsìko 1960 yàtọ̀sí àìpẹ́ yìí, àwọn aṣíkiri àti àwọn alátìlẹyìn wọn ń fa ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ padà sẹ́yìn, tí wọ́n fẹ́ ti ìdíwọ́ ọ̀rún ọdún àrín-ogún ṣubú àti ìborí dípo ètò tuntun tí yóò gbájúmọ́ ìkójọpọ̀ àwọn ẹbi, gbígba àwọn ogúnléndé àti gbígba àwọn tí wọ́n ní ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe tó yátọ̀.

English: But even then, they didn't succeed in fundamentally changing the terms of the debate, and so that framework endured, ready to be taken up again in our own convulsive moment.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà náà, wọn ò ṣàṣeyọrí nínú ṣíṣe àyípadà ìpìlẹ̀ àwọn àdéhùn àríyànjiyàn náà, nítorí náà ẹ̀tò-ìgbésẹ̀ iṣẹ́ náà dúró, tó ṣetán láti di lílò padà ní àsìko ìparí titi wa.

English: That conversation is broken.
Yoruba: Àsọgbà yẹn ti fọ́.

English: The old questions are harmful and divisive.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè àtijọ́ náà léwu àti ìpínyà.

English: So how do we get from that conversation to one that's more likely to get us closer to a world that is fairer, that is more just, that's more secure?
Yoruba: Báwo la ṣe fẹ́ kúrò láti àsọgbà yẹn sí èyí tó lè múwa súmọ́ ilẹ̀-àgbáyé kan tó jẹ́ oní déédé, tó jẹ́ adọ́gba, tí ò léwu púpọ̀?

English: I want to suggest that what we have to do is one of the hardest things that any society can do: to redraw the boundaries of who counts, of whose life, whose rights and whose thriving matters.
Yoruba: Mo fẹ́ dábàá wí pé nǹkan tí a ní láti ṣe jẹ́ ọ̀kan nínú àwọn nǹkan tó le tí àwùjọ kankan lè ṣe: láti ṣe àtúnyà àwọn enu-àlà ẹni tó ṣe pàtàkì, tí ìgbésí ayé rẹ̀, tí ẹ̀tọ rẹ̀ àti ìdàgbàsókè ṣe pàtàkì.

English: We need to redraw the boundaries.
Yoruba: A nílò láti ṣe àtúnyà àwọn enu-àlà náà

English: We need to redraw the borders of us.
Yoruba: A nílò láti ṣe àtúnyà àwọn ibodè wa.

English: In order to do that, we need to first take on a worldview that's widely held but also seriously flawed.
Yoruba: Láti lè ṣe ìyẹn, a nílò láti kọ́kọ́ gbájúmọ́ ojú-ìwòye tí àwọn ènìyàn ní ṣùgbọ́n tí wọ́n ti ní akùdé gidi gan-an.

English: According to that worldview, there's the inside of the national boundaries, inside the nation, which is where we live, work and mind our own business.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bi ojú-ìwòye yẹn, inú àwọn enu-àlà àpapọ̀ wa, nínú orílẹ̀-èdè náà, tó jẹ́ ibi tí à ń gbé, tí a tí ń ṣiṣẹ́ tí a sì ń mọ̀wọn arawa.

English: And then there's the outside; there's everywhere else.
Yoruba: Ìta rẹ̀ náà wà; ibi gbogbo náà wà.

English: According to this worldview, when immigrants cross into the nation, they're moving from the outside to the inside, but they remain outsiders.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bi ojú-ìwòye yìí, nígbà tí àwọn aṣíkiri bá ta kọ́sọ́ sí orílẹ̀-èdè náà, wọ́n ń gbéra láti ìta sínú ilé, sùgbọ́n wọn ó ṣì jẹ́ aráàta.

English: Any power or resources they receive are gifts from us rather than rights.
Yoruba: Èyíkéyìí agbára tàbí ohun-èlò tí wọ́n bá gbà gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹ̀bùn látọ̀dọ wa yàtọ̀sí àwọn ẹ̀tọ wọn

English: Now, it's not hard to see why this is such a commonly held worldview.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, kò ṣòro láti rí èrèdí tí èyí fi jẹ́ irú ojú-ìwòye tí àwọn ènìyàn ní tọ wọ́pọ̀.

English: It's reinforced in everyday ways that we talk and act and behave, down to the bordered maps that we hang up in our schoolrooms.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ṣe ìwúrí fún-un ní àwọn ọ̀nà ojoojúmọ́ bí a ṣe ń sọrọ̀ àti bí a ṣe ń ṣe àti bí a ṣe ń húwà, débi àwòrán ẹnubodè tí a fi kọ́ sókè nínú àwọn yàra-ilé-ẹ̀kọ wa.

English: The problem with this worldview is that it just doesn't correspond to the way the world actually works, and the way it has worked in the past.
Yoruba: Ìṣòro tó wà pẹ̀lú ojú-ìwòye yìí ni wí pé kò papọ̀ mọ́ ònà tí ilẹ̀ àgbáyé ń gbà ṣiṣẹ́, àti ọ̀nà tí ó ti gbà ṣiṣẹ́ sẹ́yìn.

English: Of course, American workers have built up wealth in society.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn òṣìṣẹ ilẹ̀ America ti pèsè ọrọ̀ ní àwùjọ.

English: But so have immigrants, particularly in parts of the American economy that are indispensable and where few Americans work, like agriculture.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni àwọn aṣíkiri, pàtàkì jùlọ ní apá kan ọrọ̀-ajé ilẹ̀ America tí ò ṣe é fẹ́kù àti ibi tí díẹ̀ nínú àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America ti ń ṣiṣẹ́, bíi iṣẹ́ àgbẹ̀.

English: Since the nation's founding, Americans have been inside the American workforce.
Yoruba: Látígbà tí wọ́n ti dá orílẹ̀-èdè náà sílẹ̀, ni àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America ti wà nínú ẹgbẹ́-òṣìṣẹ́ ilẹ̀ America.

English: Of course, Americans have built up institutions in society that guarantee rights.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ ni, àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America ti kọ́ àwọn ilé-isẹ́ sínú àwùjọ tó ń ṣe ìdánilójú ẹ̀tọ́.

English: But so have immigrants.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ náà ni àwọn aṣíkiri.

English: They've been there during every major social movement, like civil rights and organized labor, that have fought to expand rights in society for everyone.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ti wà níbẹ̀ lásíkò kókó ìtẹ̀síwájú àwùjọ, bíi ẹ̀tọ́ ará-ìlú àti ẹgbẹ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́, tí a ti jà láti fẹ ẹ̀tọ́ lójú nínú àwùjọ fún gbogbo ènìyan.

English: So immigrants are already inside the struggle for rights, democracy and freedom.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà àwọn aṣíkiri ti wà nínú ìjà fún ẹ̀to, ìjọba àwarawa àti òmìnira

English: And finally, Americans and other citizens of the Global North haven't minded their own business, and they haven't stayed within their own borders.
Yoruba: Lákòtán, àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America àti àwọn àwọn ọmọ-ìlú tókù ní Global North ò mọ̀wọn ara wọn, wọn ò sì tíì dúró sáàrín ibódè tiwọn.

English: They haven't respected other nations' borders.
Yoruba: Wọn ò tíì ní ìbọ́wọ̀ fún enubodè àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tókù.

English: They've gone out into the world with their armies, they've taken over territories and resources, and they've extracted enormous profits from many of the countries that immigrants are from.
Yoruba: Wọ́n ti jáde lọ sínú ayé pẹ̀lú àwọn ọmọ-ogun wọn, wọ́n ti gba ìṣàkóso àwọn ilẹ̀ àti ohun àlùmọ́nì, wọ́n sì ti yọ èrè tó pọ̀ lára orílẹ̀-èdè púpọ̀ tí àwọn aṣíkiri ti wá.

English: In this sense, many immigrants are actually already inside American power.
Yoruba: Ni ti èyí, ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn aṣíkiri kulẹ̀ ti wà nínú agbára ilẹ̀ America tẹ́lẹ̀.

English: With this different map of inside and outside in mind, the question isn't whether receiving countries are going to let immigrants in.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú àwòrán inú àti ìta orílẹ̀-èdè lẹ́mi wọn, ìbéèrè náà kìí ṣe wí pé bóyá gbígba àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè wọ̀nyí yóò jẹ́ kí àwọn aṣíkiri ó wọlé.

English: They're already in.
Yoruba: Wọ́n kulẹ̀ ti wọlé.

English: The question is whether the United States and other countries are going to give immigrants access to the rights and resources that their work, their activism and their home countries have already played a fundamental role in creating.
Yoruba: Ìbéèrè náà ni pé bóyá orílẹ̀-ède United States àti àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tókù máa fún àwọn aṣíkiri ní àn àǹfààní fàní sí àwọn ẹ̀tọ́ àti ohun àlùmọ́nì tí iṣẹ́ wọn, ìjàfẹ́tọ̀ọ́ wọn àti àwọn orílẹ̀-ède wọn ti kó ipa pàtàkì nínú ìṣẹ̀da rẹ̀.

English: With this new map in mind, we can turn to a set of tough, new, urgently needed questions, radically different from the ones we've asked before -- questions that might change the borders of the immigration debate.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú àwòran orílẹ̀-èdè tuntun yìí lọ́kàn, a lè kọjú sí sẹ́ẹ́tì àwọn ìbéèrè líle, tuntun, tí a nílò kíákíá, tó yátọ̀ gédéngbé sí àwọn tí a ti bẹ̀rè tẹ́lẹ̀ -- àwọn ìbéèrè tó lè ṣe àyípadà àríyànjiyàn enubodè ìwọlé látókèrè.

English: Our three questions are about workers' rights, about responsibility and about equality.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè mẹ́ta wa jẹ́ nípa ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́, nípa ojúṣe àti nípa ìdọ́gba.

English: First, we need to be asking about workers' rights.
Yoruba: Àkọ́kọ́, a nílò láti máa bèrè nípa ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́.

English: How do existing policies make it harder for immigrants to defend themselves and easier for them to be exploited, driving down wages, rights and protections for everyone?
Yoruba: Báwo ni àwọn ìpinnu tó wà nílẹ̀ ṣe ń jẹ́ kó le fún àwọn aṣíkiri láti gbèja arawọn kó sì rọrùn fún wọn láti lò wọn nílò-kulò, wíwa owó-iṣẹ́ wálẹ̀, ẹ̀tọ́ àti ìdáààbòbò fún gbogbo ènìyàn?

English: When immigrants are threatened with roundups, detention and deportations, their employers know that they can be abused, that they can be told that if they fight back, they'll be turned over to ICE.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí wọ́n bá ń dúkokò mọ́ àwọn aṣíkiri pẹ̀lú ìkójọpọ̀, ìtì-mọ́lé àti ìdápadà-sílé, àwọn òṣìṣẹ wọn mọ̀ pé wọ́n lè bú wọn, pé wọ́n lè sọ fún wọn pé tí wọ́n bá jà padà, wọ́n lè fàwón fún ICE.

English: When employers know that they can terrorize an immigrant with his lack of papers, it makes that worker hyper-exploitable, and that has impacts not only for immigrant workers but for all workers.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn agbanisíṣẹ́ bá mọ pé àwọn lè dúkokò mọ́ aṣíkiri pẹ̀lú àìníwè rẹ̀, ó máa ń jẹ́ kí wọ́n lo òṣìṣẹ́ yẹn nílò kulò kọjá àyè, ìyẹn sì ti nípa kìí ṣe fún àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ aṣíkiri nìkan ṣùgbọ́n fún gbogbo àwọn òṣìṣẹ́.

English: Second, we need to ask questions about responsibility.
Yoruba: Ìkejì, a nílò láti bèrè ìbéèrè nípa ojúṣe.

English: What role have rich, powerful countries like the United States played in making it hard or impossible for immigrants to stay in their home countries?
Yoruba: Kíni ipa tí àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó lówó, tó lágbára bíi orílẹ̀-ède United State ń kó láti jẹ́ kó le tàbí kó má ṣe é ṣe fún àwọn aṣíkiri láti dúró sí orílè-èdè abínibí wọn?

English: Picking up and moving from your country is difficult and dangerous, but many immigrants simply do not have the option of staying home if they want to survive.
Yoruba: Ìdìde àti gbígbéra láti orílẹ̀-ède yín nira ó sì léwu, ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn aṣíkiri ò ní àǹfààní ìdúró sílé tí wọ́n bá fẹ́ yè.

English: Wars, trade agreements and consumer habits rooted in the Global North play a major and devastating role here.
Yoruba: Ogun, àdéhùn òwò àti ìwa oníbárá tó gbilẹ̀ ní Global North ń kópa pàtàkì àti aléwu níbí.

English: What responsibilities do the United States, the European Union and China -- the world's leading carbon emitters -- have to the millions of people already uprooted by global warming?
Yoruba: Ojúṣe wo ni orílẹ̀-ède United State àti China -- àwọn tí wọ́n ń léwájú níbi ìgbéjáde òyì-èédú lágbàáyé -- ní sí ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn ènìyàn tí ìgbóná àgbáyé ti ṣí nídì?

English: And third, we need to ask questions about equality.
Yoruba: Ìkẹ́ta, a nílò láti bèrè ìbéèrè nípa ìdọ́gba.

English: Global inequality is a wrenching, intensifying problem.
Yoruba: Aìdọ́gba àgbáyé jẹ́ ìṣòro tó ń rún nǹkan, t’ó sì lágbára.

English: Income and wealth gaps are widening around the world.
Yoruba: Àlàfo ìpawó-wọlé àti ọrọ̀ ń fẹjú jákèjádò àgbáyé.

English: Increasingly, what determines whether you're rich or poor, more than anything else, is what country you're born in, which might seem great if you're from a prosperous country.
Yoruba: Ní àlékún, nǹkan tó ń sọ bóyá ẹ lówó tàbí tòṣì, ju nǹkan mìíràn lọ, ni orílé-èdè wo ni wọ́n bíi yín sí, tó lè dàbi ẹni pé ó lágbára tí ẹ bá wá láti orílẹ̀-èdè tó làmìlaaka.

English: But it actually means a profoundly unjust distribution of the chances for a long, healthy, fulfilling life.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó túmọ sí ìpín àìṣedédé alágbára àwọn àǹfààní fún ìgbeayé pípẹ́, alálàáfíà, onítẹ́lọ́rùn.

English: When immigrants send money or goods home to their family, it plays a significant role in narrowing these gaps, if a very incomplete one.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí àwọn aṣíkiri bá fi owó tàbí ẹrù ránṣẹ́ sílé sí ẹbí wọn, ó máa ń kó ipa tó ṣe pàtàkì níbi ṣíṣe àdínkù àwọn àlàfo wọ̀nyí, tí ó bá jẹ́ èyí tí ò pé.

English: It does more than all of the foreign aid programs in the world combined.
Yoruba: Ó ṣe ju gbogbo àwọn ètò ìrànwọ́ ilẹ̀ òkèèrè ní àgbáríjọpọ̀ àgbáyé lọ.

English: We began with the nativist questions, about immigrants as tools, as others and as parasites.
Yoruba: A bẹ̀rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú ìbéèrè àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú, nípa àwọn aṣíkiri gẹ́gẹ́ bi irinṣẹ́, gẹ́gẹ́ bi àwọn tó kù àti ajọ̀fẹ́.

English: Where might these new questions about worker rights, about responsibility and about equality take us?
Yoruba: Níbo ni àwọn ìbéèrè tuntun wọ̀nyí nípa ẹ̀tọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́, nípa ojúṣe àti nípa ìdógba ń múwa lọ?

English: These questions reject pity, and they embrace justice.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí kọ ìkáàánú, wọ́n sì gba ìṣedédé.

English: These questions reject the nativist and nationalist division of us versus them.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè wọ̀nyí kọ ìpínyà àwọn alátìlẹyìn ọmọ-ìlú àti àwọn alátìlẹyìn àpapọ̀ nípa àwa kojú àwọn.

English: They're going to help prepare us for problems that are coming and problems like global warming that are already upon us.
Yoruba: Wọn yóò rànwá lọ́wọ́ láti múra sílẹ̀ fún àwọn ìṣòro tó ń bọ̀ àti àwọn ìṣòro bíi ìgbóná àgbáyé t’ó ti wà lórí wa.

English: It's not going to be easy to turn away from the questions that we've been asking towards this new set of questions.
Yoruba: Kò ní rọrùn láti yí kúrò níbi àwọn ìbéèrè tí a ti ń bérè nípa sẹ́ẹ́tì àwọn ìbéèrè tuntun yìí.

English: It's no small challenge to take on and broaden the borders of us.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe ìdojúkọ kékeré láti kojú k’á sì fẹ àwọn enubodè wa.

English: It will take wit, inventiveness and courage.
Yoruba: Ó máa gba ọgbọ́n, ìṣẹ̀dá àti ìgbóyà.

English: The old questions have been with us for a long time, and they're not going to give way on their own, and they're not going to give way overnight.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè àtijọ́ ti wà pẹ̀lu wa fún ìgbà pípẹ́, wọn ò sì ní bìlà fúnra wọn, tí wọn ò sì ní bìlà lọ́sàán-kan óru-kan.

English: And even if we manage to change the questions, the answers are going to be complicated, and they're going to require sacrifices and tradeoffs.
Yoruba: Kódà tí a bá gbìyànjú láti ṣe àyípadà àwọn ìbéèrè náà, àwọn ìdáhùn náà máa jẹ́ àmúdijú, wọ́n sì máa gba ìfarajìn àti ìṣedédé.

English: And in an unequal world, we're always going to have to pay attention to the question of who has the power to join the conversation and who doesn't.
Yoruba: Ní orílẹ̀-èdè àgbáyé tí ò dọ́gba, a máà nílò láti fi ọkàn sí ìbéèrè pé ta ló ní agbára láti darapọ̀ mọ́ àsọgbà náà àti eni tí ò ní.

English: But the borders of the immigration debate can be moved.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn enubòdè àríyànjiyàn ìwọlé látókèrè lè di sísún.

English: It's up to all of us to move them.
Yoruba: Ó dọwọ́ gbogbo wa láti sún wọn.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: What I learned about freedom after escaping North Korea
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí mo kò nípa òmìnira lẹ́yìn tí mo sá kúrò ní  orílẹ̀-ède North Korea.

English: I was born in 1993 in the northern part of North Korea, in a town called Hyesan, which is on the border with China.
Yoruba: Wọ́n bí mi ní ọdún 1993 ní apá àríwá orílẹ̀-ède North Korea, ní agbègbè kan tí wọ́n ń pè ní Hyesan, tó wà pààlà pẹ̀lú orílẹ̀-ède China

English: I had loving parents and one older sister.
Yoruba: Mo ní àwọn òbí tí wọ́n nífẹ̀ẹ́ àti ẹ̀gbọ́n obìnrin kan.

English: Before I was even 10 years old, my father was sent to a labor camp for engaging in illegal trading.
Yoruba: Kí n tiẹ̀ tó pé ọmọ ọdún mẹ́wà, wọ́n rán bàbá mi lọ sí ìpàgọ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ fún kíkópa nínú ìṣòwò àìbófinmu.

English: Now, by "illegal trading" -- he was selling clogs, sugar, rice and later copper to feed us.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, pẹ̀lú “ìṣòwò àìbófinmu”-- ó ń ta bàtà, ṣúgà, ìrẹsì lẹ́yìn náà kọ́pà láti fi bọ́ wa.

English: In 2007, my sister and I decided to escape.
Yoruba: Ní ọdún 2007, èmi àti ọmọ ìyá mi lóbìnrin pinnu láti sálọ.

English: She was 16 years old, and I was 13 years old.
Yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún mẹ́rìn-dín-lógún, èmí sì jẹ́ ọmọ ọdún mẹ́tàlá.

English: I need you to understand what the word "escape" means in the context of North Korea.
Yoruba: Mo nílò láti jẹ́ kí ẹ mọ nǹkan tí ọ̀rọ̀ yìí “sálọ” túmọ̀ sí ní ní ọ̀gangan ipò orílẹ̀-ède North Korea.

English: We were all starving, and hunger means death in North Korea.
Yoruba: Gbogbo wa ni ebi ń pa, ebí sì túmọ̀ sí ikú ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea,

English: So it was the only option for us.
Yoruba: Ó jẹ́ àǹfààní kan ṣoṣo fún wa.

English: I didn't even understand the concept of escape, but I could see the lights from China at night, and I wondered if I go where the light is, I might be able to find a bowl of rice.
Yoruba: Mi ò ti lẹ̀ lóye nípa èrò sísálọ, ṣùgbọ́n mo máa ń rí àwọn iná náà láti China lálẹ́,  mo sì rò ó pé bóyá tí mo bá lọ síbi tí iná náà wà, mo lè rí abọ́ ìrẹsì kan.

English: It's not like we had a grand plan or maps.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe wí pé a ní ìpinnu alágbára tàbí àwòrán kankan.

English: We did not know anything about what was going to happen.
Yoruba: A ò mọ nǹkankan nípa nǹkan tí yóò ṣẹlẹ̀.

English: Imagine your apartment building caught fire.
Yoruba: Ẹ wòye pé ilé ìgbe yín gbaná.

English: I mean, what would you do?
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, kí lẹ máa se?

English: Would you stay there to be burned, or would you jump off out of the window and see what happens?
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ máa dùró síbẹ̀ kí ẹ jóná ni, àbi ṣé ẹ máa fò jáde kúrò látojú fèrèsé kí ẹ sì wá wo ohun tí yóó ṣelẹ̀?

English: That's what we did.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí a ṣe nìyẹn.

English: We jumped out of the house instead of the fire.
Yoruba: A fò jáde kúrò nínú ilé náà dípò iná.

English: North Korea is unimaginable.
Yoruba: North Korea jẹ́ ibi tí ẹ ò leè ronú nípa rẹ̀.

English: It's very hard for me when people ask me what it feels like to live there.
Yoruba: Ó máa nira fún mi nígbà tí àwọn ènìyàn bá bi mí bó ṣe rí láti gbé nígbẹ̀.

English: To be honest, I tell you: you can't even imagine it.
Yoruba: Ká sọ tòótọ́, mo sọ fún yín: ẹ ò lè ronú nípa rẹ̀.

English: The words in any language can't describe, because it's a totally different planet, as you cannot imagine your life on Mars right now.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ inú èyíkéyìí èdè ò lè ṣàpèjúwe rẹ̀, nítorí àgbáyé tó yátọ̀ pátápátá ni, bí ẹ ò ṣe lè ronú ìgbésíayé yín nínú Ìsọ̀ngbè-oòrùn-kẹ́rin lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: For example, the word "love" has only one meaning: love for the Dear Leader.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, ọ̀rọ yìí “ìfẹ́” ní ìtumọ̀ kan ṣoṣo: ìfẹ́ fún adarí wa ọ̀wọ́n.

English: There's no concept of romantic love in North Korea.
Yoruba: Kò sí èrò ìfẹ́ ẹlẹ́yẹlé ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea

English: And if you don't know the words, that means you don't understand the concept, and therefore, you don't even realize that concept is even a possibility.
Yoruba: Tí ẹ ò bá mọ àwọn ọ̀rọ náà, ìyẹ́n túmọ̀ sí wí pé èrò náà ò ye yín, nítorí náà, ẹ ò ní mọ̀ pé èrò yẹn gan-an jẹ́ a ṣe é ṣe.

English: Let me give you another example.
Yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ kí n fún yín ní àpẹẹrẹ mìíràn.

English: Growing up in North Korea, we truly believed that our Dear Leader is an almighty god who can even read my thoughts.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mò ń dàgbà ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea, a nígbàgbọ́ lódodo wí pé adarí wa ọ̀wọ́n jẹ́ òòṣà tó lágbára tó lè mọ èro ọkàn wa.

English: I was even afraid to think in North Korea.
Yoruba: Èrú tún bàmí láti ronú nípa orílẹ̀-ède North Korea.

English: We are told that he's starving for us, and he's working tirelessly for us, and my heart just broke for him.
Yoruba: Wọ́n sọ fún wa pé ó ń f’ebi panú fún wa, ó sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ láìkáàrẹ̀ fún wa, ọkàn mí sì gbọgbẹ́ fún-un.

English: When I escaped to South Korea, people told me that he was actually a dictator, he had cars, many, many resorts, and he had an ultraluxurious life.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo sálọ sí orílẹ̀-ède South Korea, àwọn ènìyán sọ fún mi wí pé apàṣẹ wàá ni, ó ní àwọn ọkọ̀, oríṣiríṣi ilé-ìgbafẹ́, ó sì ń gbé ìgbeayé olówó ńlá.

English: And then I remember looking at a picture of him, realizing for the first time that he is the largest guy in the picture.
Yoruba: Nígbà náà ni mo bá rántí wíwo àwòran rẹ̀ kan, mímọ̀ fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́ pé òun lẹni tó tóbi jù nínú àwòrán náà.

English: And it hit me.
Yoruba: Ló bá yémi.

English: Finally, I realized he wasn't starving.
Yoruba: Nígbẹ́yìn, mo mọ̀ wí pé ebi ò pa á.

English: But I was never able to see that before, until someone told me that he was fat.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mi ò ní àǹfààní láti rí èyí tẹ́lẹ̀, àyàfi ìgbà tí ẹnìkan sọ fún mi wí pé òún sanra.

English: Really, someone had to teach me that he was fat.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́, ẹnìkán ní láti kọ́ mi pé òún sanra.

English: If you have never practiced critical thinking, then you simply see what you're told to see.
Yoruba: Tí ẹ ò bà tíì ṣe ìfikọ́ra ìrònú jinlẹ̀ rí, nǹkan tí wọ́n bá ní kí ẹ rí lẹ máa rìí.

English: The biggest question also people ask me is: "Why is there no revolution inside North Korea?
Yoruba: Ìbéèrè tó tóbi jù tí àwọn èniyàn máa ń bi mí ni: “Kí ló dé tí ò sí ìjàngbara nínú orílẹ̀-ède North Korea?

English: Are we dumb?
Yoruba: Ṣé odi niwá ni?

English: Why is there no revolution for 70 years of this oppression?
Yoruba: Kí ló dé tí ò sí ìjàngbara fún ìnira àádọ́rin ọdún yìí

English: " And I say: If you don't know you're a slave, if you don't know you're isolated or oppressed, how do you fight to be free?
Yoruba: “ Ti mo bá sọ wí pé: tí ẹ ò bá mọ̀ wí pé ẹrú niyín, tí ẹ ò bá mọ̀ wí pé wọ́n yà yín sọ́tọ̀ tàbí wọ́n ń fara niyín, báwo lẹ ṣe fẹ́ jà láti gba ìtúsílẹ̀?

English: I mean, if you know you're isolated, that means you are not isolated.
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, tí ẹ bá mọ̀ wí pé wọ́n yà yín sọ́tọ̀, ó túmọ̀ sí wí pé wọn ò yà yín sọ́tọ̀.

English: Not knowing is the true definition of isolation, and that's why I never knew I was isolated when I was in North Korea.
Yoruba: Àìmọ̀ ni ìtumọ̀ ìyanisọ́tọ̀ lódodo, ìdí nìyẹn tí mi ò fi mọ̀ wí pé wọ́n yàmí sọ́tọ̀ ni nígbà tí mo wà ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea.

English: I literally thought I was in the center of the universe.
Yoruba: Mo rò wí pé mo wà láàrín-gbùgbun àgbáyé ni.

English: So here is my idea worth spreading: a lot of people think humans inherently know what is right and wrong, the difference between justice and injustice, what we deserve and we don't deserve.
Yoruba: Èrò mi tó yẹ fún ìfọ́nká rè é: ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ènìyán rò wí pé ọmọ ènìyàn mọ nǹkan tó yẹ àti èyí tó burú jáì, ìyàtọ̀ tó wà láàárín ìṣedédé àti àìṣedédé, nǹkan tó tọ́ síwa àti nǹkan tí ò tọ́ síwa.

English: I tell them: BS.
Yoruba: Mo sọ fún wọn: BS.

English: Everything, everything must be taught, including compassion.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ẹ̀, gbogbo ẹ̀ gbọ́dọ̀ di kíkọ́, tó fi kan àánú.

English: If I see someone dying on the street right now, I will do anything to save that person.
Yoruba: Bí mo bá rí enìkan tó ń kú lọ láàárín adúgbò nísìyìí, mà á ṣe ohun-kóhun láti dóòlà ẹni náà.

English: But when I was in North Korea, I saw people dying and dead on the streets.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà ti mo wà ní orílẹ̀-ède North Korea, mo rí àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń kú àti òkú káàkiri àdúgbò.

English: I felt nothing.
Yoruba: Mi ò ní ìmọ̀lára kankan.

English: Not because I'm a psychopath, but because I never learned the concept of compassion.
Yoruba: Kìí ṣe nítorí mo jẹ́ ọlọ́dẹ-orí, ṣùgbọ́n nítorí mi ò kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ nípa èrò ìkáànú rí.

English: Only, I felt compassion, empathy and sympathy in my heart after I learned the word "compassion" and the concept, and I feel them now.
Yoruba: Mo ní ìmọ̀láa àánú, ìbánikẹ́dùn àti ìkáànú nínú ọkàn mi lẹ́yìn ìgbà tí mo kọ́ nípa ọ̀rọ̀ yìí “àánú” àti èro rẹ̀ nìkan, mo sì ní ìmọ̀lára wọn báyìí.

English: Now I live in the United States as a free person.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí mò ń gbé ní orílẹ̀-ède United State gẹ́gẹ́ bi olómìnira ènìyàn.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: And recently, the leader of the free country, our President Trump, met with my former god.
Yoruba: Láìpẹ́ yìí, àwọn adarí orílẹ̀-èdè olómìnira, Ààrẹ wa Trump, ṣe ìpàdé pẹ̀lú òòsa mi tẹ́lẹ̀.

English: And he decided human rights is not important enough to include in his agendas, and he did not talk about it.
Yoruba: Ó sì pinnu pé ẹ̀tọ ọmọ ènìyàn ò ṣe pàtàkì tó láti fi kún ìpinnu rẹ̀, kò sì sọ̀rọ̀ nípa rẹ̀.

English: And it scares me.
Yoruba: Ó bà mí lẹ́rù.

English: We live in a world right now where a dictator can be praised for executing his uncle, for killing his half brother, killing thousands of North Koreans.
Yoruba: Lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí à ń gbé nínú ayé níbi tí wọ́n ti lè gbóríyìn fún apàṣe-wàá kan pé ó pa ọmọ ìya bàba rẹ̀ lọ́kùrin, fún pípa ọmọ ìyàwo bàba rẹ̀, pípa ẹgbẹ̀rún àwọn ọmọ orílẹ̀-ède North korea.

English: And that was worthy of praise.
Yoruba: Ìyẹn sì tó nǹkan à ń gbóríyìn fún.

English: And also it made me think: perhaps we all need to be taught something new about freedom now.
Yoruba: Bákan náà ó múmi ronú: bóyá gbogbo wa la nílò láti kọ́ nǹkan tuntun nípa òmìnira báyìí.

English: Freedom is fragile.
Yoruba: Nǹkan ẹlẹgẹ́ ni òmìnira

English: I don't want to alarm you, but it is.
Yoruba: Mi ò fẹ́ fun yín lára, ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ ni.

English: It only took three generations to make North Korea into George Orwell's "1984.
Yoruba: Ìran mẹ́ta péré ló gbà láti sọ orílẹ̀-ède North Korea di “1984 ti Goorge Orwell

English: " It took only three generations.
Yoruba: Ìran mẹ́ta péré ló gbà.

English: If we don't fight for human rights for the people who are oppressed right now who don't have a voice, as free people here, who will fight for us when we are not free?
Yoruba: Bí a ò bá jà fún ètọ ọmọnìyàn fún àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń fìyà jẹ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí tí wọn ò lè fohùn, gẹ́gẹ́ bí àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n lómìnira níbí, ta ló máa jà fún wa nígbà tí a ò bá ní òmìnira?

English: I don't know.
Yoruba: Mi ò mọ̀.

English: I think it's wonderful that we care about climate change, animal rights, gender equality, all of these things.
Yoruba: Mo rò wí pé ó dára pé a káràmásìkí mọ́ àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́, ẹ̀tọ́ ẹranko, ìṣedédé láàárín akọ àti abo, gbogbo àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí.

English: The fact that we care about animals' rights, that means that's how beautiful our heart is, that we care about someone who cannot speak for themselves.
Yoruba: Òtítọ́ pé a káràmásìki nípa ẹ̀tọ́ ẹranko, ìyẹ́n túmọ̀ sí wí pé bí ọkàn wa ṣe rewà sí nìyẹn, pé a káràmásìkí nípa enìkan tí ò le fi ẹnu arawọn sọ̀rọ̀.

English: And North Koreans right now cannot speak for themselves.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ North Korea ò lè fi ẹnu arawọn sọ̀rọ̀ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: They don't have internet in the 21st century.
Yoruba: Wọn ò ní ẹ̀rọ-ayélukára-bí-ajere ní ọ̀rún ọdún kọkàn-lé-lógún.

English: We don't have electricity, and it is the darkest place on earth right now.
Yoruba: A ò ní iná mọ̀nàmọ́ná, òhun sì ni àyè tó ṣókùnkùn jù lórí ilẹ̀ eèpẹ̀ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: Now I want to say something to my fellow North Koreans who are living in that darkness.
Yoruba: Báyìí mo fẹ́ sọ nǹkankan fún àwọn tí a jìjọ jẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ North Korea tí wọ́n ń gbé nínú òkùkùn yẹn.

English: They might not believe this, but I want to tell them that an alternative life is possible.
Yoruba: Wọ́n lè má gba èyí gbọ́, ṣùgbọ́n mo fẹ́ sọ fún wọn pé ìpààrọ ìgbésí-ayé ṣe é ṣe.

English: Be free.
Yoruba: Ẹ gba ìtúsílẹ̀

English: From my experience, literally anything is possible.
Yoruba: Látara ìrírí mi, gbogbo nǹkan ló ṣe é ṣe.

English: I was bought, I was sold as a slave.
Yoruba: Wón rà mí, wọ́n tà mí gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹrú.

English: But now I'm here, and that is why I believe in miracles.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní báyìí mo ti wà níbí, ìyẹn ló sì fà á tí mo fi nígbàgbọ́ nínú iṣẹ́-ìyanu.

English: The one thing that I learned from history is that nothing is forever in this world.
Yoruba: Nǹkan kan tí mo kọ́ nínú ìtàn ni wí pé kò sí nǹkankan tó lọ títí nínú ayé yìí.

English: And that is why we have every reason to be hopeful.
Yoruba: Ìdí nìyẹn tí a fi ní gbogbo ẹ̀tọ́ láti ní ìrètí.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: Medical tech designed to meet Africa's needs
Yoruba: Ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ìṣègùn tí wọ́n ṣẹ̀dá láti pèse ohun tí ilẹ̀ Adúláwò nílò.

English: Like every passionate software engineer out there, I closely follow technology companies in Silicon Valley, pretty much the same way soccer fans follow their teams in Europe.
Yoruba: Bíi gbogbo onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ nípa ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn tí wọ́n wà níta níbẹ̀ yẹn, mo máa ń tẹ̀lé alwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ní Silicon Valley típẹ́-típẹ́, ní ọ̀nà kan náà tí àwọn olólùfẹ́ eré bólù aláfẹsẹ̀gbá ṣe ń tẹ̀lé ikọ̀ wọn nílẹ̀ Europe.

English: I read articles on tech blogs and listen to podcasts on my phone.
Yoruba: Mo máa ń ka àròkọ lórí ìkànnì ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ mo sì máa ń tẹ́ti sí àkáálẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ-agbagbe lórí ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ mi.

English: But after I finish the article, lock my phone and unplug the headphones, I'm back in sub-Saharan Africa, where the landscape is not quite the same.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n lẹ́yìn tí mo bá parí átíkù náà, tí mo ti ẹ̀rọ-ìbánisọ̀rọ̀ mi tí mo sì yọ àgbékarí, mo ti padà sí ìwò oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwò, níbi ti ààla-ilẹ̀ ò ti jọra wọn.

English: We have long and frequent power outages, low penetration of computers, slow internet connections and a lot of patients visiting understaffed hospitals.
Yoruba: Iná máa ń lọ fún ìgbà pípé lọ́pọ̀-ìgbà, àìlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá púpọ̀, ìkàni ayélukára tí ò yára àti ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn aláìsàn tí wọ́n lọ sílé ìwòsàn tí kò sí òṣìṣẹ́ púpọ̀.

English: Since the HIV epidemic, hospitals have been struggling to manage regular HIV treatment records for increasing volumes of patients.
Yoruba: Látìgbà àjàkálẹ̀ àrun kòkòro apa òkì àjẹsára àìfààyègba-àìsàn ara, àwọn ilé ìwòsàn tí ń tiraka láti ṣàmójútó àkọsílẹ̀ ìtọ́jú kòkòro apa sójà ara lóòrèkóòrè fún àlékún abala àwọn aláìsàn.

English: For such environments, importing technology systems developed elsewhere has not worked, but in 2006, I joined Baobab Health, a team that uses locally based engineers to develop suitable interventions that are addressing health care challenges in Malawi.
Yoruba: Fún irú àwùjọ bẹ́ẹ̀, gbigbé èto ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí wọ́n ṣẹ̀dá níbòmíràn ò tíì ṣiṣẹ́, ṣùgbọ́n ní ọdún 2006, mo darapọ̀ mọ́ Baoba Health, ikọ̀ kan tó máa ń lo àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ lábẹ́lé láti ṣẹ̀da àwọn ìdásí tó yẹ tí wọ́n ń yanjú àwọn ìdojúkọ ajẹmọ ìtọ́jú ní orílẹ̀-ède Malawi

English: We designed an electronic health record system that is used by health care workers while seeing patients.
Yoruba: A ṣẹ̀da ẹ̀rọ tó ń ṣe àkọsílẹ̀ ìlera onínọ́ tí àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera ń lò nígbà tí wọ́n bá ń rí àwọn aláìsàn.

English: And in the process we realized that we not only had to design the software, we had to implement the infrastructure as well.
Yoruba: Nínú ìgbésẹ̀ náà a mọ̀ pé a ò ní láti ṣẹ̀da ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn nìkan, a ní láti ṣàmúlò ohun amáyédẹrùn náà bákan náà.

English: We don't have enough medical staff to comprehensively examine every patient, so we embedded clinical guidelines within the software to guide nurses and clerks who assist with handling some of the workload.
Yoruba: A ò ní àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera tó tó láti ṣe àyèwò tó péye fún gbogbo aláìsàn, nítorí náà a ṣe àfibọ̀ ìlànà-ìtọ́sánà ajẹmọ́ ìtọ́jú sínu ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn náà láti ṣe ìtọ́sánà àwọn olùtọ́-ilé-ìwòsàn àti àwọn akọ̀wé tí wọ́n ń ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ pẹ̀lú ìmójútó díẹ̀ nínú àwọn iṣẹ́ náà.

English: Everyone has a birthday, but not everyone knows their birthday, so we wrote algorithms to handle estimated birthdates as complete dates.
Yoruba: Gbogbo wa la ní ọjọ́ ìbí, ṣùgbọ́n kìí ṣe gbogbo ènìyàn ló mọ ọjọ́ ìbi wọn, nítorí náà a kọ àwọn ètò láti mójútó àpapọ̀ àwọn ọjọ́ ìbí gẹ́gẹ́ bi déétì tó pé.

English: How do we follow up patients living in slums with no street and house numbers?
Yoruba: Báwo la ó ṣe ṣe ìtẹ̀lé àwọn aláìsàn tí wọ́n ń gbé ní àdúgbò elérò tí ò ní nọ́mbà àdúgbò àti ilé?

English: We used landmarks to approximate their physical addresses.
Yoruba: A lo ààla-ilẹ̀ láti ṣe àròpọ̀ àdírẹ́sì àfojúrí wọn.

English: Malawi had no IDs to uniquely identify patients, so we had to implement unique patient IDs to link patient records across clinics.
Yoruba: Orílẹ̀-ède Malawi ò ní ID láti ṣe ìdánimọ̀ àwọn aláìsàn yàtọ̀, nítorí náà a ní láti ṣàmúlò ID àwọn aláìsàn tó yátọ̀ láti ṣe àsopọ̀ àkọsílẹ̀ àwọn aláìsàn jákèjádò àwọn ilé ìtọ́jú.

English: The IDs are printed as barcodes on labels that are stuck on personal health booklets kept by each patient.
Yoruba: A ṣe àtẹ̀jáde àwọn ID náà gẹ́gẹ́ bi ẹ̀nà onílà òòró tí wọ́n lè mọ́ àwọn ìwé ìlera àdáni tí aláìsàn kọ̀ọ̀kan ń tọ́jú.

English: With this barcoded ID, a simple scan with a barcode reader quickly pulls up the patient's records.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ID tó ní ẹ̀nà onílà òòró yìí, ìfojúwò gara tíò le pẹ̀lú ẹ̀rọ tó ń ka ẹ̀nà onílà òòró yóò tètè gbé àkọsílẹ̀ aláìsàn náà síta.

English: No need to rewrite their personal details on paper registers at every visit.
Yoruba: Wọn ò nílò láti ṣe àtúnkọ àlàyé nípa ara wọn sóri ewé ìforúkọsílẹ̀ ní gbogbo ìgbà tí wọ́n bá wá.

English: And suddenly, queues became shorter.
Yoruba: Lójijì, àwọn ilà-ìtò bá di kúkurú

English: This meant patients, typically mothers with little children on their backs, had to spend less time waiting to be assisted.
Yoruba: Èyí túmọ̀ sí wí pé àwọn aláìsàn, àwọn ìyá tí wọ́n lọ́mọ lẹ́yìn wọn nìkan, yóò lo àsìkò díẹ̀ ní ìdúró de ìrànlọ́wọ́

English: And if they lose their booklets, their records can still be pulled by searching with their names.
Yoruba: Bí wọ́n bá ṣe àfẹ́kù ìwe wọn, àkọsílẹ̀ wọn ṣì lè di gbígbà pẹ̀lú wíwá orúkọ wọn.

English: Now, the way we pronounce and spell names varies tremendously.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, ònà tí à ń gbà pè àti kọ orúkọ yátọ̀ gidi gan-an.

English: We freely mix R's and L's, English and vernacular versions of their names.
Yoruba: A ṣe àdàpọ̀ R àti L láìsídìwọ́, ẹ̀dà ède gẹ̀ẹ́sì àti ède abínibí àwọn orúkọ wọn.

English: Even soundex, a standard method for grouping words by how similar they sound, was not good enough.
Yoruba: Kódà ìjọra-ìró, ìlànà àwòkọ́ṣe fún ìpín-sísọ̀rí àwọn ọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú bí wọ́n ṣe jọra ní ìró, kò dára tó.

English: So we had to modify it to help us link and match existing records.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà a ní láti ṣe àtúnṣe sí i láti lè bá wa ṣe àsopọ̀ àti ìbámu àwọn àkọsílẹ̀ tó ti wà tẹ́lẹ̀.

English: Before the iPhone, software engineers developed for personal computers, but from our experience, we knew our power system is not reliable enough for personal computers.
Yoruba: Ṣíwájú iPhone, àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ nípa ohun-èlo ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá tí ò ṣe é fọwọ́ kàn ṣẹ̀da rẹ̀ fún ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àdáni, ṣùgbọ́n látara ìrírí wa, a mọ̀ pé èto agbára wa ò ṣe é gbáralé fún ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá àdáni.

English: So we repurposed touch screen point-of-sale terminals that are meant for retail shops to become clinical workstations.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà a ṣe àmúyẹ àwọn ẹ̀rọ ibi-ìtajà agbàwòrán-tàn-aláfọwọ́tẹ̀ tí wọ́n wà fún àwọn ìsọ̀ alárà-tún-tà láti di ẹ̀rọ-iṣẹ́ ajẹmọ́wòsàn.

English: At the time, we imported internet appliances called i-Openers that were manufactured during the dot-com era by a failed US company.
Yoruba: Ní àsìkò náà, a ṣe ìkówọlé àwọn ohun-èlò ayélukára-bí-ajere tí wọ́n pè ní i-Opener tí wọ́n ṣe sànmání ìtakùn ẹ̀rọ ayélukára-bí-ajere àmì ti ìṣe òwò ní ilé-iṣẹ́ kan tí ó fìdí rẹmi ní orílẹ̀-ède US.

English: We modified their screens to add touch sensors and their power system to run from rechargeable batteries.
Yoruba: A ṣe àtúnṣe àtẹ agbàwòrán tàn wọn láti ṣe àfikún iyè ìfọwọ́kàn àti èto agbára-mànàmáná wọn láti lè ṣiṣẹ́ lára òkúta-agbagbará-iná-àsọdọ̀tun.

English: When we started, we didn't find a reliable network to transmit data, especially from rural hospitals.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí a bẹ̀rẹ̀, a ò rí ojú-òpó-ìsopọ̀ ayélukára-bí-ajere tó ṣe é gbáralé láti ta àtagbà ìwífún-alálàyé, pàápàá jùlọ láti àwọn ilé-ìwòsàn tí wọ́n wà ní ìgbèríko.

English: So we built our own towers, created a wireless network and linked clinics in Lilongwe, Malawi's capital.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà a kọ́ ilé-agbára tiwa, a ṣẹ̀dá àwọn òpó-ìsopọ̀ ayélukára-bí-ajere àìlokùn-agbé-òyì-iná tí a sì so ilé-ìwòsàn alábọ́dé ní Lilongwe, olú ìlu orílẹ̀-ède Malawi pọ̀.

English: With a team of engineers working within a hospital campus, we observed health care workers use the system and iteratively build an information system that is now managing HIV records in all major public hospitals in Malawi.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú ikọ̀ àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ láàárín ọgbà ilé-ìwòsàn kan, a ṣe àkíyèsí wí pé àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera ń lo ètò náà wọ́n sì ń ṣẹ̀da ètò ìfitóni t’ó ń ṣe àmójútó àkọsílẹ̀ HIV báyìí ní gbogbo àwọn ilé-ìwòsàn gbogbogbò t’ó tóbi jù ní orílẹ̀-ède Malawi.

English: These are hospitals serving over 2,000 HIV patients, each clinic.
Yoruba: Àwọn wọ̀nyí ni ilé-ìwòsàn tí ń ṣe ìtọ́jú àwọn aláìsan HIV tí ó lé ní ẹgbẹ̀rún méjì, ní ibi ilé-ìwòsàn kọ̀ọ̀kan.

English: Now, health care workers who used to spend days to tally and prepare quarterly reports are producing the same reports within minutes, and health care experts from all over the world are now coming to Malawi to learn how we did it.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ ìlera tí wọ́n máa lo àìmọye ọjọ́ láti ṣe àpapọ̀ àti láti ṣèto ìjábọ̀ olóṣù mẹ́ta-mẹ́ta ń ṣe ìjábọ̀ kan náà láàárín ìṣẹ́jú díẹ̀, àwọn àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ oníṣẹ́-ìlera káàkiri àgbáyé ti ń wá sí orílẹ̀-ède Malawi láti kọ́ nípa bí a ṣe ṣe é.

English: It is inspiring and fun to follow technology trends across the globe, but to make them work in low-resourced environments like public hospitals in sub-Saharan Africa, we have had to become jacks-of-all-trades and build whole systems, including the infrastructure, from the ground up.
Yoruba: Ó máa wúni lórí ó sì máa ń dùn mọ́ni láti tẹ̀ sí ibi tí àwọn ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ ń tẹ̀ sí káàkiri àgbáyé, ṣùgbọ́n láti lè jẹ́ kí wọ́n ṣiṣẹ́ ní àwọn agbègbè bíi Gúúsù aṣálẹ̀ Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ tí wọn ò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ni ohun èlò ilé-ìwòsan gbogbogbò, a ní láti di gbogbo-lòwò k’á sì kọ́ ṣe àwọn ètò gbogbo, t’ó fi kan ohun amáyédẹrùn náà, láti ilẹ̀ pẹ̀pẹ̀.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: What's missing from the American immigrant narrative
Yoruba: Kí ló sọnù nínú ìtan àwọn aṣíkiri-lọ-sí-ìlú-mìíràn ilẹ̀ America

English: Hi, everyone, my name is Elizabeth, and I work on the trading floor.
Yoruba: Ẹ ǹlẹ́, gbogbo ènìyàn, orúkọ mi ni Elizabeth, mo sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní àjà ìṣòwò.

English: But I'm still pretty new to it.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ojú mi ò tíì ṣálẹ̀ sí i dáadáa.

English: I graduated from college about a year and a half ago, and to be quite honest, I'm still recovering from the recruiting process I had to go through to get here.
Yoruba: Mo kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde nílé-ẹ̀kọ́ ní bíi odún kan àbọ̀ sẹ́yìn, k’á sì sọ òtítọ́, mo sì ń padà bọ̀ sípò látàrí ìgbésẹ̀ ìgbaniwọlé tí mo ní láti là kọjá láti débí.

English: Now, I don't know about you, but this is the most ridiculous thing that I still remember about the whole process, was asking insecure college students what their biggest passion was.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, mi ò mọ tiyín, ṣùgbọ́n èyí ni nǹkan tó burú jù tí mo ṣì ń rántí nípa gbogbo ìgbésẹ̀ náà, mò ń bèrè lọ́wọ́ àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ọkàn wọn ò balẹ̀ ohun tí ìfẹ́ gidigidi wọn t’ó tóbi jù jẹ́.

English: Like, do you expect me to have an answer for that?
Yoruba: Bíi, ṣé e ń retí kí n ní ìdáhùn fún ìyẹn?

English: Of course I did.
Yoruba: Bẹ́ẹ̀ni mo níi.

English: And to be quite honest, I really showed those recruiters just how passionate I was by telling them all about my early interest in the global economy, which, conveniently, stemmed from the conversations that I would overhear my immigrant parents having about money and the fluctuating value of the Mexican peso.
Yoruba: Kín ṣọ òtítọ́, mo fi han àwọn agbaniwọlé wọ̀nyẹn irú ìfẹ́ tí mo ní pẹ̀lú sísọ fún wọn nípa ìfẹ́ àtilẹ̀wá mi nínú ọrọ̀-ajé àgbáyé, tí, pẹ̀lú ìrọ̀rùn, ó ṣẹ́yọ látara àsọgbà tí mo máa ń gbọ́ tí àwọn òbí mi tí wọ́n jẹ́ aṣíkiri máa ń ṣe nípa owó àti àìṣedédé ìwúlò owó peso orílẹ̀-ède Mexico.

English: They love a good personal story.
Yoruba: Wọ́n fẹ́ràn ìtan ara ẹni t’ó dára.

English: But you know what?
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ṣé ẹ mọ nǹkan?

English: I lied.
Yoruba: Mo parọ́.

English: And not because the things I said weren't true -- I mean, my parents were talking about this stuff.
Yoruba: Kì í ṣe nítorí àwọn nǹkan tí mo sọ kì í ṣe ododo -- mò ń sọ nípa pé, àwọn òbí mi ń sọ̀rọ̀ nípa kiní yìí.

English: But that's not really why I decided to jump into finance.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan t’ó mú mi pinnu láti ta kọ́sọ́sọ́ sí ìsúná gangan kọ́ nìyẹn.

English: I just really wanted to pay my rent.
Yoruba: Mo kọ̀ fẹ́ san owó ilé mi lásán ni.

English: And here's the thing.
Yoruba: Nǹkan náà rèé.

English: The reality of having to pay my rent and do real adult things is something that we're rarely willing to admit to employers, to others and even to ourselves.
Yoruba: Òótọ́ nípa sísan owó ilé mi kín sì ṣe àwọn nǹkan agbàlagbà tòótọ́ jẹ́ nǹkan tí a ò férẹ̀ nífẹ̀ sí láti sọ fún àwọn olùgbanisíṣẹ́, fún àwọn tókù àti fún ara wa bákan náà.

English: I know I wasn't about to tell my recruiters that I was there for the money.
Yoruba: Mo mọ̀ wí pé mi ò ṣetán láti sọ fún olùgbanisíṣẹ́ mi pé torí owó ni mo ṣe wá síbẹ̀.

English: And that's because for the most part, we want to see ourselves as idealists and as people who do what they believe in and pursue the things that they find the most exciting.
Yoruba: Ìdi rẹ̀ sì ni wí pé fún ẹ̀yà tó pọ́jù, a fẹ́ rí ara wa gẹ́gẹ́ bi oníròrí àti bí ènìyàn tó mọ nǹkan tó nígbàgbọ́ nínú rẹ̀ tó sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ tọ àwọn nǹkan tó máa ń dùn wọ́n nínú jù.

English: But the reality is very few of us actually have the privilege to do that.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n òtítọ́ ni wí pé díẹ̀ nínú wa ló ní àǹfààní láti ṣe ìyẹn.

English: Now, I can't speak for everyone, but this is especially true for young immigrant professionals like me.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, mi ò le sọ ti gbogbo ènìyàn, ṣùgbọ́n èyí jẹ́ pàáp̀àá òtítọ́ fún ọ̀dọ́ akọṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ aṣíkiri bíi tèmi.

English: And the reason this is true has something to do with the narratives that society has kept hitting us with in the news, in the workplace and even by those annoyingly self-critical voices in our heads.
Yoruba: Ìdí tí èyí fi jẹ́ òdodo ní nǹkan ṣe pẹ̀lú àwọn ìtàn tí àwùjọ ti fín gbá wa nínú ìròyìn, níbi iṣẹ́ àti àwọn ohùn líle tó ń bíni nínú wọ̀nyẹn nínú orí wa.

English: So what narratives am I referring to?
Yoruba: Torí náà ìtàn wo ni mò ń tọ́ka sí?

English: Well, there's two that come to mind when it comes to immigrants.
Yoruba: Ó dáa, awọn méjì kan máa ń wá sórí ẹ̀mí tí ó bá di ọ̀rọ̀ àwọn aṣíkiri.

English: The first is the idea of the immigrant worker.
Yoruba: Àkọ́kọ́ ni èrò nípa àwọn òṣìṣẹ́ aṣíkiri.

English: You know, people that come to the US in search of jobs as laborers, or field workers, dish washers.
Yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n máa ń wá iṣẹ́ wá sí orílẹ̀-ède US gẹ́gẹ́ bi lébírà, tàbí òsìṣẹ́ orí oko, afọbọ́.

English: You know, things that we might consider low-wage jobs but the immigrants?
Yoruba: Ẹ mọ̀, àwọn nǹkan tí àwá lè rí gẹ́gẹ́ bi iṣẹ́ tí owó-iṣẹ́ rẹ̀ kéré ṣùgbọ́n àwọn aṣíkiri?

English: That's a good opportunity.
Yoruba: Àǹfààní gidi nìyẹn.

English: The news nowadays has convoluted that whole thing quite a bit.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìròyìn lásíkò yìí ti sọ gbobo nǹkan yẹn di àmúdijú díẹ̀.

English: You could say that it's made America's relationship with immigrants complicated.
Yoruba: Ẹ lè sọ wí pé ó ti jẹ́ kí àjọṣepọ̀ láàárín àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ America àti àwọn aṣíkiri di àmúdijú.

English: And as immigrant expert George Borjas would have put it, it's kind of like America wanted workers, but then, they got confused when we got people instead.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ nípa àwọn aṣíkiri George Borjas yóò ti ṣe sọ ọ́, ó dàbi ẹni pé ilẹ̀ America fẹ́ àwọn òṣìṣẹ́, ṣùgbọ́n síbẹ̀, ó dàrú mọ́wọn lójú nígbà tí wọ́n rí àwọn ènìyàn dípò bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: I mean, it's natural that people want to strive to put a roof over their heads and live a normal life, right?
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, abínibí ni pé àwọn ènìyàn fẹ́ tirika láti nílé lórí kí wọ́n sì gbé ìgbeayé gidi, àbí?

English: So for obvious reasons, this narrative has been driving me a little bit crazy.
Yoruba: Fún àwọn ìdí tó fojú hàn, ìtàn yìí ti ń sín mi níwín díẹ̀.

English: But it's not the only one.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe òhun nìkan.

English: The other narrative that I'm going to talk about is the idea of the superimmigrant.
Yoruba: Ìtàn mìíràn tí màá sọ nípa rẹ̀ jẹ́ nípa èrò àwọn aṣíkíri-alágbára.

English: In America, we love to idolize superimmigrants as the ideal symbols of American success.
Yoruba: Ní ilẹ̀ America, a fẹ́ràn láti sọ àwọn aṣíkiri-alágbára di òòṣà-àkúnlẹ̀bọ gẹ́gẹ́ bi àrokò tó yẹ fún àṣeyọrí ilẹ̀ America.

English: I grew up admiring superimmigrants, because their existence fueled my dreams and it gave me hope.
Yoruba: Mo dagbà lẹ́ni tó ń nífẹ̀ sí àwọn aṣíkiri-alágbára, nítorí ìṣẹ̀mi wọn ṣe ìrànwọ́ fún àlá mi ó sì fúnmi nírètí.

English: The problem with this narrative is that it also seems to cast a shadow on those that don't succeed or that don't make it in that way, as less than.
Yoruba: Ìṣòro tó wà pẹ̀lú ìtàn yìí ni wí pé ó tún dàbi ẹni pé wọ́n ń ṣọ́ àwọn tí wọn ò láṣeyọrí tàbí tí wọn ò rí ṣe lọ́nà yẹn.

English: And for years, I got caught up in the ways in which it seemed to celebrate one type of immigrant while villainizing the other.
Yoruba: Fún àìmọye ọdún, mo bára mi ní àwọn ọ̀nà tó dàbi ẹni pé wọ́n ń gbóríyìn fún aṣíkiri kan nígbà tí wọ́n sọ ìkejì dí aṣebi.

English: I mean, were my parents' sacrifices not enough?
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, ṣé ìfarajìn àwọn òbí mi ò tó ni?

English: Was the fact that my dad came home from the metal factory covered in corrosive dust, was that not super?
Yoruba: Ṣé ọ̀títọ́ pé bàbá mi wálé láti ilé-iṣọ̀pọ̀ àlùrọ tí eruku àlùrọ bòó, ṣé ìyẹn ò lágbára tó?

English: Don't get me wrong, I've internalized both of these narratives to some degree, and in many ways, seeing my heroes succeed, it has pushed me to do the same.
Yoruba: Ẹ má ṣìmí gbọ́, mo ti ro ìtàn méjééjì dé ìpele kan, ní ọ̀nà tó pọ̀, rírí àṣeyọrí àwọn akọni mi, ó ti tìmí láti ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: But both of these narratives are flawed in the ways in which they dehumanize people if they don't fit within a certain mold or succeed in a certain way.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n àwọn ìtàn méjéjì yìí ní akùdé ní àwọn ọ̀nà tí wọ́n fi ń ba ìjẹ́ ọmọ ènìyàn àwọn èyàn jẹ́ tí wọn ò bá yẹ ní ìmọ kan tàbí ní àwọn ọ̀nà kan

English: And this really affected my self-image, because I started to question these ideas for who my parents were and who I was, and I started to wonder, "Am I doing enough to protect my family and my community from the injustices that we felt every day?
Yoruba: Èyí sì ti ṣàkóbá fún àwòran ara mi, nítorí mo bẹrẹ̀ síní tako àwọn èrò wọ̀nyí nítorí irú ẹnìyàn tí àwọn òbí mi jẹ́ àti ẹni tí mo jẹ́, mo bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní rò ó, “Ṣé mò ń ṣe tó láti dáààbòbo ẹbí mi àti àwùjọ mi lọ́wọ́ àìṣedédé tí à ń ní lójoojúmọ́?

English: " So why did I choose to "sell out" while watching tragedies unfold right in front of me?
Yoruba: “ Kí ló dé tí mo yàn láti “tà” nígbà tí mò ń wo wàhálà bó ṣe ń ṣẹlẹ̀ níwájú mi?

English: Now, it took me a long time to come to terms with my decisions.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, ó gbàmí lásíkò púpọ̀ láti ṣe àdéhùn pẹ̀lú ìpinnu mi.

English: And I really have to thank the people running the Hispanic Scholarship Fund, or HSF, for validating this process early on.
Yoruba: Mo ní láti dúpẹ́ lọ́wọ́ àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń ṣe agbátẹrù Etò Ẹ̀kọ́ Òfẹ́ Hispanic, tàbí HSF, fún ìfọwọ́sí ìgbésẹ̀ yìí láti ìbẹ̀rẹ̀.

English: And the way that HSF -- an organization that strives to help students achieve higher education through mentorship and scholarships -- the way that they helped calm my anxiety, it was by telling me something super familiar.
Yoruba: Àti ọ̀nà tí HSF -- àjọ kan tó ń tiraka láti ran àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ lọ́wọ́ láti ṣe àṣeyọrí ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga nípasẹ̀ ìgbani nímọ́ràn àti ètò ẹ̀kọ́ ọ̀fẹ́ -- ọ̀nà tí wọ́n ti gbà láti ṣe ìsilẹ̀ ààbalẹ̀-ọkàn, pẹ̀lú sísọ nǹkan tó tó jọ ọ́ gidi gan-gan.

English: Something that you all probably have heard before in the first few minutes after boarding a flight.
Yoruba: Nǹkan tí ẹ lérò pé ẹ ti gbọ́ tẹ́lẹ̀ ní ìṣẹ̀jú díẹ̀ àkọ́kọ́ lẹ́yìn tí ẹ ti wọ ọkọ̀ òfuurufú.

English: In case of an emergency, put your oxygen mask on first before helping those around you.
Yoruba: Fún ìṣẹ̀lẹ pàjáwírì, ẹ kọ́kọ́ wọ ìbòjú èémí-àmísínú yin ná kí ẹ tó máa ran àwọn tí wọ́n rọkiriká yín lọ́wọ́.

English: Now I understand that this means different things to different people.
Yoruba: Báyìí ó yémi pé èyí túmọ̀ sí oríṣiríṣi nǹkan sí oríṣiríṣi ènìyàn.

English: But for me, it meant that immigrants couldn't and would never be able to fit into any one narrative, because most of us are actually just traveling along a spectrum, trying to survive.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n fún èmi, ó túmọ̀ sí wí pé àwọn aṣíkiri ò lè wọn ò sì ní yẹ nínú ìtàn Kankan láyéláye, nítorí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ wa kọ̀ ń bá afẹ́fẹ́ rìn ni, à sì ń gbìyànjú láti yè.

English: And although there may be people that are further along in life with their oxygen mask on and secured in place, there are undoubtedly going to be others that are still struggling to put theirs on before they can even think about helping those around them.
