Yoruba: Bó tilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé àwọn ènìyàn lè wà tí wọ́n ti lọ síwájú láyé pẹ̀lú ìbòjú èémí-àmísínú wọn tí wọ́n sì farapamọ́ sáyè kan, ó dájú wí pé àwọn mìíràn yóò wà tí wọ́n ṣì ń tiraka láti wọ tiwọn kí wọ́n tiẹ̀ tó ronú nípa ríran àwọn tí wọ́n rọkiriká wọn lọ́wọ́.

English: Now, this lesson really hit home for me, because my parents, while they wanted us to be able to take advantage of opportunities in a way that we wouldn't have been able to do so anywhere else -- I mean, we were in America, and so as a child, this made me have these crazy, ambitious and elaborate dreams for what my future could look like.
Yoruba: Báyìí, ẹ̀kọ́ yìí ṣiṣẹ́ fún mi, nítorí awọn òbí mi, nígbà tí àwọ́n ń fẹ́ kí a lè ṣàmúlò àwọn àǹfààní ní ọ̀nà tí a ò ní àǹfààní láti ṣe irú rẹ̀ rí nibò mìíràn -- mò ń sọ nípa pé, a wà ní ilẹ̀ America, gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọdé, èyí ń jẹ́ kí n ní àwọn àlá asíni níwín, onípinnu tó tóbi fún bí ọ̀jọ́ iwájú mi yóò ṣe rí.

English: But the ways in which the world sees immigrants, it affects more than just the narratives in which they live.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ọ̀nà tí gbogbo àgbáyé ń gbàá rí àwọn aṣíkiri, ó ń ṣàkóbá púpọ̀ ju àwọn ìtàn tí wọ́n ń gbé nínú rẹ̀ lọ.

English: It also impacts the ways laws and systems can affect communities, families and individuals.
Yoruba: Ó tún nípa lára ọ̀nà tí òfin àti àwọn ètò lè sàkóbá fún àwọn àwùjọ, àwọn ẹbí àti àwọn ènìyàn.

English: I know this firsthand, because these laws and systems, well, they broke up my family, and they led my parents to return to Mexico.
Yoruba: Mo mọ eléyìí tààrà, nítorí àwọn òfin àti ètò wọ̀nyí, ó dáa, wọ́n máa ń tú ẹbí ká, wọ́n sì mú kí àwọn òbí mi padà sí orílẹ̀-ède Mexico.

English: And at 15, my eight-year-old brother and I, we found ourselves alone and without the guidance that our parents had always provided us with.
Yoruba: Ní ọmọ odún mẹ́ẹ̀dógún, èmi àti àbúrò mi ọkùnrin ọmọ ọdún mẹ́jọ, a bárawa ní  àwa nìkan láaìsí ìtọ́sọ́nà tí àwọn òbi wa máa ń fún wa ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: Despite being American citizens, we both felt defeated by what we had always known to be the land of opportunity.
Yoruba: Pẹ̀lú pé a jẹ́ ọmọ ilẹ̀ America, àwa méjééjì dàbi ẹni tó rí ìjákulẹ̀ pẹ̀lú nǹkan ti a ti mọ̀ tẹ́lẹ̀ pé ilẹ̀ àǹfààní ni.

English: Now, in the weeks that followed my parents' return to Mexico, when it became clear that they wouldn't be able to come back, I had to watch as my eight-year-old brother was pulled out of school to be with his family.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, ní ọ̀sẹ̀ tó tẹ̀lé èyí tí àwọn òbí mi padà sí orílẹ̀-ède Mexico, nígbà tí ó hàn kedere pé wọn ò nílè padà wá, mo ní láti máa wo bí àbúrò mi ọmọ ọdún mẹ́jọ ṣe kúrò nílé-ẹ̀kọ́ kó lè wà pẹ̀lú ẹbí rẹ̀.

English: And during this same time, I wondered if going back would be validating my parents' sacrifices.
Yoruba: Ní àsìkò yìí kan náà, mò ń rò ó bóyá pípadà yóò ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún ìfarajìn àwọn òbí mi.

English: And so I somehow convinced my parents to let me stay, without being able to guarantee them that I'd find somewhere to live or that I'd be OK.
Yoruba: Mo ṣáà yí àwọn òbí mi lọ́kàn padà pé kí wọ́n jẹ́ kí n dúró, láìlè fún wọn ní ìdánilójú pé màá rí ibìkan láti gbé tàbí pé màá wà lálàáfíà.

English: But to this day, I will never forget how hard it was having to say goodbye.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n di òní, mi ò ní gbàgbe bó ṣe le tó láti sọ pé ó dábọ̀ láyéláyé.

English: And I will never forget how hard it was watching my little brother crumble in their arms as I waved goodbye from the other side of steel grates.
Yoruba: Mi ò sì ní gbàgbe bó ṣe le tó láti máa wo àbúrò mi bó ṣe ń yọ́bọ́rọ́ lọ́wọ́ wọn bí mo ṣe ń juwọ́ síwọn láti ẹ̀gbé kejì ilẹ̀kùn onírin.

English: Now, it would be naive to credit grit as the sole reason for why I've been able to take advantage of so many opportunities since that day.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, kò ní mópọlọ dání láti gbóríyìn fún àfojúsùn gẹ́gẹ́ bi èrèdí kan ṣoṣo tí mo fi ṣàmúlò ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àǹfààní láti ọjọ́ náà.

English: I mean, I was really lucky, and I want you to know that.
Yoruba: Mò ń sọ nípa pé, mo lórí lọ́wọ́ ni, mo sì fẹ́ kí ẹ mọ̀ bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: Because statistically speaking, students that are homeless or that have unstable living conditions, well, they rarely complete high school.
Yoruba: Nítorí ká sọ̀rọ̀ pẹ̀lú ìṣirò, àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tí ò nílé tàbí tí wọ́n gbé ìgbeayé tí ò ṣe déédéé, ó dáa, wọn kìí fi bẹ́ẹ̀ figa-gbága ní ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ gíga.

English: But I do think that it was because my parents had the trust in letting me go that I somehow found the courage and strength to take on opportunities even when I felt unsure or unqualified.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo máa ń rò ó wí pé nítorí àwọn òbí mi nígbàgbọ́ láti fimí sílẹ̀ ló jẹ́ kín nígboyà àti agbára láti ṣàmúlò àǹfààní kódà nígbà tí kò dámilójú tàbi pé mi ò peregedé.

English: Now, there's no denying that there is a cost to living the American dream.
Yoruba: Ní báyìí, a ò lè parọ́ pé kò sí ẹ̀jẹ́ fún gbígbé ìgbeayé àla ilẹ̀ America.

English: You do not have to be an immigrant or the child of immigrants to know that.

Yoruba: Wọ́n ṣe ìforúkọsílẹ̀ rẹ̀, MHRA -- àti àmi CE, fún àwọn tí ò mọ̀, fún ilẹ̀ Europe, ó ṣe déédé pẹ̀lú FDA ní orílẹ̀-ède US.

English: If you compare it with what's on the market, price-wise, size-wise, ease of use, complexity.
Yoruba: Bí ẹ bá ṣe àfiwé rẹ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn nǹkan tó wà lọ́jà, ní ti owó, ní ti títóbi, rírọ̀rùn láti lò, àmúdijú.

English: This picture was taken last year.
Yoruba: Ọdún tó kọjá ni wọ́n ya àwòrán yìí.

English: These are members of my graduating class, 1986.
Yoruba: Àwọn yìí ni àwọn àwọn tí a jọ kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde, ọdún 1986.

English: It was in this gentleman's house in the Potomac, for those of you who are familiar with Maryland.
Yoruba: Ilé arákùrin yìí ní Potomac ni, fún àwọn tí wọ́n mọ Maryland dijú.

English: There are too many of us outside and everybody, just to borrow a bit from Hans -- Hans Rosling, he's my guy -- if the size of the text represents what gets the most attention, it's the problems.
Yoruba: Àwa tí a wà níta pọ̀ gbogbo wa, láti yá díẹ̀ lọ́wọ Hans -- Hans Rosling, ènìyàn mi ni -- tí ìwọn àyọkà náà bá jẹ́ aṣojú nǹkan tó máa ń pe àkíyèsí jù, òun ni wàhálà.

English: But what we really need are African solutions that are appropriate for Africa -- looking at the culture, looking at the people, looking at how much money they've got.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan tí a nílò nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ni ọ̀nà-àbáyọ tó yẹ fún ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ -- tí a bá wo àṣa, tí a bá wo àwọn ènìyàn, tí a bá wo iye owó tí wọ́n ti gbà.

English: African people, because they will do it with a passion, I hope.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyan ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, nítorí wọ́n máa fi ẹ̀mí ṣe é, mo rò bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: And lots and lots of that little bit down there, sacrifice.
Yoruba: àìmọyẹ àti àìmọye díẹ̀ tó wà nísálẹ̀ yẹn, ìfarajìn ni.

English: You have to do it.
Yoruba: Ẹ ní láti ṣe é.

English: Africans have to do it, in conjunction with everyone else.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní láti ṣe é, pẹ̀lú àjọṣepọ̀ gbogbo àwọn ènìyàn tókù.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

English: How fake news does real harm
Yoruba: Bí ìròyìn òfegè ṣe ń ṣọṣẹ́ gidi.

English: I want to tell you a story about a girl.
Yoruba: Mo fẹ́ sọ ìtàn kan fún yín nípa ọmọdébìnrin kan.

English: But I can't tell you her real name.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mi ò lè sọ orúkọ rẹ̀ gangan fún yín.

English: So let's just call her Hadiza.
Yoruba: Torí náà ẹ jẹ́ ká pè é ní Hadiza

English: Hadiza is 20.
Yoruba: Hadiza jẹ́ ọmọ ogún ọdún.

English: She's shy, but she has a beautiful smile that lights up her face.
Yoruba: Ó lójútì, ṣùgbọ́n ẹlẹ́rìín ẹ̀yẹ ni tó sì máa ń mú kí ojú rẹ̀ gún régé.

English: But she's in constant pain.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ó wà nínú ìnira àtìgbàdégbà.

English: And she will likely be on medication for the rest of her life.
Yoruba: Ó sì ṣe é ṣe kó jẹ́ wí pé yóó ma lògùn fún èyí tó kù nínú ìgbésí-ayé rẹ̀ ni.

English: Do you want to know why?
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ fẹ́ mọ ìdí rẹ̀?

English: Hadiza is a Chibok girl, and on April 14, 2014, she was kidnapped by Boko Haram terrorists.
Yoruba: Hadiza jẹ́ ọmọdébìnrin Chibok, ní ọjọ́ kẹrìnlá oṣù Igbe ọdún 2014, àwọn agbésùmọ̀mí Boko Haram jí i gbé.

English: She managed to escape, though, by jumping off the truck that was carrying the girls.
Yoruba: Ó ráyè láti sá, bótilẹ̀ jẹ́ wí pé, pẹ̀lú fífò látinú ọkọ̀-akẹ́rù tó ń gbé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin náà ni.

English: But when she landed, she broke both her legs, and she had to crawl on her tummy to hide in the bushes.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tó lulẹ̀, ó kán ara rẹ̀ lẹ́sẹ̀ méjééjì, ó ni láti wọ́ pẹ̀lu ikùn rẹ̀ láti sápamọ́ sínú ìgbo.

English: She told me she was terrified that Boko Haram would come back for her.
Yoruba: Ó sọ fún mi pé ẹ̀rú bà òun wí pé àwọn Boko Haram máa padà wá fún òun

English: She was one of 57 girls who would escape by jumping off trucks that day.
Yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn ọmọ mẹ́tà-dín-lọ́gọ́ta tí wọn yóò sá pẹ̀lu fífò bọ́lẹ̀ nínú àwọn ọkọ̀ akẹ́rù lọ́jọ́ yẹn

English: This story, quite rightly, caused ripples around the world.
Yoruba: Ìtàn yìí, bó ṣe yẹ, ti fa rúkèrúdò káàkiri àgbáyé.

English: People like Michelle Obama, Malala and others lent their voices in protest, and at about the same time -- I was living in London at the time -- I was sent from London to Abuja to cover the World Economic Forum that Nigeria was hosting for the first time.
Yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn bíi Michelle Obama, Malala àti àwọn tí wọ́n ti fohùn síta ní ìfẹ̀hónúhàn, ní bíi àsìkò kan náà -- mò ń gbé ní ìlu London lásíkò náà -- wọn rán mi láti ìlu London lọ sí Abuja láti gbé Àpérò Ọrọ̀-Ajé Àgbáyé tí orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria ń gbàlejo rẹ̀ fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́.

English: But when we arrived, it was clear that there was only one story in town.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nígbà tí a dé, ó hàn gbangba pé ìròyìn kan ṣoṣo ló wà nígboro.

English: We put the government under pressure.
Yoruba: A ò fi ìjọba náà lára balẹ̀.

English: We asked tough questions about what they were doing to bring these girls back.
Yoruba: A bèrè àwọn ìbéèrè tó lágbára nípa nǹkan tí wọ́n ń ṣe láti gba àwọn ọmọdébìnrin wọ̀nyí padà.

English: Understandably, they weren't too happy with our line of questioning, and let's just say we received our fair share of "alternative facts.
Yoruba: Ó yé wa, inú wọn ò dùn pẹ̀lú àwọn ìbéèrè tí à ń bérè, e jẹ́ká kọ̀ sọ wí pé a gba ìpin tiwa nínú “arọ́pò òdodo.

English: Influential Nigerians were telling us at the time that we were naive, we didn't understand the political situation in Nigeria.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Nigeria tí wọ́n nífọ̀n-léèkán ná ń sọ fún wa ní àsìkò náà pé aláìmọ̀kan niwa, a ò ní òye òṣèlú tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria.

English: But they also told us that the story of the Chibok girls was a hoax.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n tún sọ fún wa pé ète ni ìròyìn nípa àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok náà.

English: Sadly, this hoax narrative has persisted, and there are still people in Nigeria today who believe that the Chibok girls were never kidnapped.
Yoruba: Ó bani nínú jẹ́, ìtàn ète yìí ń tẹ̀ síwájú, àwọn ènìyàn sì wà ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria lónì tí wọ́n gbágbọ́ pé wọn ò jí àwọn ọmọdẹ́bìnrin Chibok náà gbé rárá.

English: Yet I was talking to people like these -- devastated parents, who told us that on the day Boko Haram kidnapped their daughters, they ran into the Sambisa Forest after the trucks carrying their daughters.
Yoruba: Síbẹ̀ mò ń bá àwọn ènìyàn báyìí sọ̀rọ̀ -- àwọn òbí tí wọ́n ń banújẹ́, tí wọ́n sọ fún wí pé ọjọ́ tí àwọn Boko Haram wá jí àwọn ọmọbìnrin wọn gbé, àwọ́n sá tẹ̀lé ọkọ̀-akẹ́rù tó gbé àwọn ọmọbìnrin wọn wọnú igbó Sambisa.

English: They were armed with machetes, but they were forced to turn back because Boko Haram had guns.
Yoruba: Wọ́n dìhá ogun pẹ̀lú àdá, ṣùgbọ́n wọ́n ní láti padà ní tipátipá nítorí àwọn Boko Haram náà níbọn.

English: For two years, inevitably, the news agenda moved on, and for two years, we didn't hear much about the Chibok girls.
Yoruba: Fún ọdún méjì, láìyẹ̀, ìpinnu ìròyìn náà tẹ̀síwájú, fún odún méjì, a ò gbọ́ nípa àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok náà.

English: Everyone presumed they were dead.
Yoruba: Gbogbo ènìyán lérò wí pé wọ́n ti kú ni.

English: But in April last year, I was able to obtain this video.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ní oṣù Igbe ọdún tó kọjá, mo gba fọ́rán aláwòrán yìí.

English: This is a still from the video that Boko Haram filmed as a proof of life, and through a source, I obtained this video.
Yoruba: Àwòrán kan rèé lára fọ́rọ́n aláwòrán tí Boko Haram yà gẹ́gẹ́ bi ẹ̀rí ẹ̀mí, nípasẹ̀ orísun kan, mo gba fọ́rán yìí.

English: But before I could publish it, I had to travel to the northeast of Nigeria to talk to the parents, to verify it.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kín tó ṣe ìtẹ̀jáde rẹ̀, mo ní láti rin irìnàjò lọ sí àríwá-ìlà-oòrun ilẹ̀ Nigeria láti bá àwọn òbí náà sọ̀rọ̀, láti fìdí ẹ̀ múlè.

English: I didn't have to wait too long for confirmation.
Yoruba: Mi ò ní láti dúró pẹ́ fún ìfẹsẹ̀múlẹ̀ rẹ̀.

English: One of the mothers, when she watched the video, told me that if she could have reached into the laptop and pulled our her child from the laptop, she would have done so.
Yoruba: Ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ìyá náà, nígbà tó wo fọ́rán náà, sọ fún mi pé tí òun bá lè wọnú ẹ̀rọ ayárabíàṣá àgbélétan náà kí òun sì fa ọmọ rẹ̀ jáde láti inú ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàṣá alágbèlétan ni, òun ìbá ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

English: For those of you who are parents, like myself, in the audience, you can only imagine the anguish that that mother felt.
Yoruba: Fún ẹ̀yin tí ẹ jẹ́ òbí, bíi tèmi, nínú ẹ̀yin olùgbọ́, ẹ kọ̀ lè wòye ìbànújẹ́ tí ìyá yẹn ti ní.

English: This video would go on to kick-start negotiation talks with Boko Haram.
Yoruba: Fọ́rán yìí máa tẹ̀síwájú láti bẹ̀rẹ ìdúnàdúrà pẹ̀lú Boko Haram

English: And a Nigerian senator told me that because of this video they entered into those talks, because they had long presumed that the Chibok girls were dead.
Yoruba: Aṣòfin kan ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria sọ fún mi pé nítorí fọ́rán yìí ni àwọn ṣe ń ṣe afọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn, nítorí tipẹ́ làwọ́n ti gbà wí pé àwọn ọmọdébìnrin Chibok náà ti kú.

English: Twenty-one girls were freed in October last year.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọmọdébìnrin mọ́kànlé-lógún ni wọ́n tú sílẹ̀ ní oṣù Ọ̀wàrà odún tó kọjá.

English: Sadly, nearly 200 of them still remain missing.
Yoruba: Ó bani nínú jẹ́, ó súmọ́ igba nínú wọn tí wọ́n ṣì ń wá báyìí.

English: I must confess that I have not been a dispassionate observer covering this story.
Yoruba: Mo gbọ́dọ̀ jẹ́wọ́ wí pé mi ò tíì jáwọ́ àkíyèsí bí mo ṣe ń  gbéróyìn yìí.

English: I am furious when I think about the wasted opportunities to rescue these girls.
Yoruba: Inú ń bími nígbà tí mo bá ronú nípa àwọn àǹfààní láti gba àwọn ọmọdébìnrin wọ̀nyí padà tó ti ṣòfò

English: I am furious when I think about what the parents have told me, that if these were daughters of the rich and the powerful, they would have been found much earlier.
Yoruba: Inú ń bími nígbà tí mo bá ronú nípa nǹkan tí àwọn òbí náà ti sọ fún mi, pé tí àwọn wọ̀nyí bá jẹ́ àwọn ọmọbìnrin olówó àti alágbára ni, wọn ò bá ti ríwọn tipẹ́.

English: And I am furious that the hoax narrative, I firmly believe, caused a delay; it was part of the reason for the delay in their return.
Yoruba: Inú ń bími pé ìtàn ète náà, mo nígbàgbọ́ tó rinlẹ̀, máa ń fa ìdádúró; ó wà lára okùnfa fún ìdádúró nínú ìpadàbọ wọn.

English: This illustrates to me the deadly danger of fake news.
Yoruba: Èyí ń ṣàpèjúwe ewu aṣekúpani ìròyìn òfegè fúnmi.

English: So what can we do about it?
Yoruba: Nítorí náà kíni a lè ṣe nípa rẹ̀?

English: There are some very smart people, smart engineers at Google and Facebook, who are trying to use technology to stop the spread of fake news.
Yoruba: Àwọn ọlọ́gbọ́n ènìyán kan wà, àwọn onímọ̀-ẹ̀rọ tí wọ́n gbọ́n ní Google àti Facebook, tí wọ́n ń gbìyànjú láti fi ìmọ̀-ẹ̀rọ dá ìròyìn òfegè dúró.

English: But beyond that, I think everybody here -- you and I -- we have a role to play in that.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ju bẹ́ẹ̀ lọ, mo rò wí pé gbogbo wa níbí -- ìwọ àti èmi -- a nípa láti kó nínú ìyẹn.

English: We are the ones who share the content.
Yoruba: Àwa ni a máa ń ṣe àtagbà àwọn àkóónú náà.

English: We are the ones who share the stories online.
Yoruba: Àwa la máa ń ṣe àtagbà àwọn ìròyìn náà lórí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára.

English: In this day and age, we're all publishers, and we have responsibility.
Yoruba: Ní ìgbà àti àkókò yìí, gbogbo wa ni atẹ̀wétà, a sì ní ojúṣe.

English: In my job as a journalist, I check, I verify.
Yoruba: Nínú iṣẹ́ mi gẹ́gẹ́ bi akọ̀ròyìn, mo máa ń ṣáyẹ̀wò, mo máa ń ṣe ìfesẹ̀múlẹ̀.

English: I trust my gut, but I ask tough questions.
Yoruba: Mo jẹ́ri ìgboyà mi, ṣùgbọ́n mo béére àwọn ìbéèrè alágbára.

English: Why is this person telling me this story?
Yoruba: Kíló dé tí ẹni yìí ń sọ ìtàn yìí fún mi?

English: What do they have to gain by sharing this information?
Yoruba: Kíni wọ́n fẹ́ jẹ lérè pẹ̀lú ṣíṣe àtagbà ìfitónilétí yìí?

English: Do they have a hidden agenda?
Yoruba: Ṣé ẹ ní ipinnu Kankan tí ẹ fi ń pamọ́?

English: I really believe that we must all start to ask tougher questions of information that we discover online.
Yoruba: Mo nígbàgbọ́ gidi gan-an wí pé a gbogbo wá gbọ́dọ̀ bẹ̀rẹ̀ síni béérè ìbéèrè alágbára nípa àwọn ìfitóniléti tí a bá ṣàwárí rẹ̀ lórí òpo ayélukára.

English: Research shows that some of us don't even read beyond headlines before we share stories.
Yoruba: Ìwádìí fi hàn pé àwọn kan nínú wa ò kí ń kà ju àkòrí lọ kí a tó ṣe àtagbà awọn ìròyìn.

English: Who here has done that?
Yoruba: Ta ni ẹni náà níbí tó ti ṣe ìyẹn?

English: I know I have.
Yoruba: Mo mọ̀ mo ti ṣe é.

English: But what if we stopped taking information that we discover at face value?
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n tí a bá jáwọ́ mínú àwọn ìfitóniléti tí a ṣàwárí pẹ̀lú ìṣojúlọ́yìn ńkọ́?

English: What if we stop to think about the consequence of the information that we pass on and its potential to incite violence or hatred?
Yoruba: Bí a bá dúró láti ronú nípa ìpadàbọ àwọn ìfitónilétí tí à ń tì síwájú àti ìkápá rẹ̀ láti fa rògbòdìyàn tàbí ọ̀tá ńkọ́?

English: What if we stop to think about the real-life consequences of the information that we share?
Yoruba: Bí a bá dúró láti ronú nípa àwọn ìpadàbọ ojú aye àwọn afitóni tí à ń ṣe àtagbà rẹ̀ ńkọ́?

English: Thank you very much for listening.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun gidi gan-an fún ìtẹ́tíi yín.

English: How we can stop Africa's scientific brain drain?
Yoruba: Bí a ṣe lè dèna ìgbọ́ngbẹ ọpọlọ ìmọ-ìjìnlẹ̀ nílẹ̀ Adúláwò.

English: So many of us who care about sustainable development and the livelihood of local people do so for deeply personal reasons.
Yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ nínú wa tó nífẹ̀ sí ìdàgbàsókè alálòpẹ́ àti ìgbáyégbádùn àwọn enìyàn ìgbèríko ń ṣe é fún àǹfààní ara ẹni ni.

English: I grew up in Cameroon, a country of enchanting beauty and rich biodiversity, but plagued by poor governance, environmental destruction, and poverty.
Yoruba: Mo dàgbà ní orílẹ̀-ède Cameroon, orílẹ̀-èdè tó kún fún ẹwà àti oríṣiríṣi ojúlówó àṣà, ṣùgbọ́n tó ń ṣàìsàn pẹ̀lú ìṣèjọba tí ò da, bíba àwùjọ jẹ́, àti òṣì.

English: As a child, like we see with most children in sub-Saharan Africa today, I regularly suffered from malaria.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọmọde, bí a ṣe ń rí pẹ̀lú ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ọmọ ní ìwò oòrun ilẹ̀ adúláwò lónì, mo máa ń ní iba ní gbogbo ìgbà.

English: To this day, more than one million people die from malaria every year, mostly children under the age of five, with 90 percent occurring in sub-Saharan Africa.
Yoruba: Títí di òní, ó lé ní àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ kan àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń kú látara ibà lọ́dọọdún, pàápàá jùlọ àwọn ọmọdé lábẹ́ ọdún márùn-ún, tí ìdá àádọ́rùn sì ń ṣẹlẹ̀ ní ìwọ̀ oòrun ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀

English: When I was 18, I left Cameroon in search of better educational opportunities.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo wà lọ́mọ ọdún méjì-dín lógún, mo fi orílẹ̀-ède Cameroon sílẹ̀ léni tó ń wá àǹfààní ètò-ẹ̀kọ́ tó dára.

English: At the time, there was just one university in Cameroon, but Nigeria next door offered some opportunities for Cameroonians of English extraction to be trained in various fields.
Yoruba: Ní àsìkò náà, fásitì kan ṣoṣo ló wà ní Cameroon níbẹ̀, Sùgbọ́n orílẹ̀-èdè Nàìjíríà  tí ó jẹ́ amúlétì wọn fún àwon ọmò Kamẹrúùnù tí wọn gbọ́ ède gẹ̀ẹ́sì ní ànfàní láti gba orísìrísì ìdánilẹ́ẹ̀kọ́

English: So I moved there, but practicing my trade, upon graduation as an ecologist in Nigeria, was an even bigger challenge.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ṣíṣe òwò mi, lẹ́yìn tí mo kẹ́kọ̀ọ́ jáde gẹ́gẹ́ bí onímọ̀ nípa ọjọ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède Nigeria, tún jẹ́ ìdojúkọ tó tún tóbi.

English: So I left the continent when I was offered a scholarship to Boston University for my PhD.
Yoruba: Nítorí náà mo fi ẹkùn náà sílẹ̀ nígba tí wọ́n fún mi ní ẹ̀kọ́ ọ̀fẹ́ sí Fásitì Boston fún oyè ọ̀mọ̀wé mi.

English: It is disheartening to see that, with all our challenges, with all the talents, with all the skills we have in Africa as a continent, we tend to solve our problems by parachuting in experts from the West for short stays, exporting the best and brightest out of Africa, and treating Africa as a continent in perpetual need of handouts.
Yoruba: Ó bani lọ́kàn jẹ́ láti ríi pé, pẹ̀lú gbogbo ìdojúkọ wa, pẹ̀lú gbogbo ẹ̀bun wa, pẹ̀lú gbogbo ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe tí a ní nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ẹkùn kan, a ń yanjú àwọn ìṣòro wa pẹ̀lú mímú àwọn òjìnì wọlé láti ilẹ̀ aláwọ̀ funfun fún ìgbà díẹ̀, àti gbígbé àwọn tó dára tó sì lọ́pọlọ kúrò nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, àti ṣíṣe ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ bíi ẹkùn tó nílò owó ìrànwọ́.

English: After my training at Boston University, I joined a research team at the University of California's Institute of the Environment and Sustainability because of its reputation for groundbreaking research and the development of policies and programs that save the lives of millions of people the world over, including in the developing world.
Yoruba: Lẹ́yìn ẹ̀kọ́ mi ní fásiti Boston, mo darapọ̀ mọ́ ikọ̀ oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí kan ní Ilé-ẹ̀kọ Àwùjọ àti Ìmúdúró ní Fásitì California nítorí ìdánimọ̀ rẹ̀ fún ìwádìí alágbára àti ìdàgbàsókè àwọn ìpinnu àti àwọn ètò tó ń gba èmi àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ àwọm enìyàn là káàkiri àgbáyé, pẹ̀lú àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè tó ń dágbàsókè.

English: And it has been shown that for every skilled African that returns home, nine new jobs are created in the formal and informal sectors.
Yoruba: Ó sì ti fi hàn pé fún gbogbo ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó ní ìmọ̀ọ́ṣe tó padà sílé, iṣẹ́ tuntun mẹ́sàn yóò di dídásílẹ̀ ní ẹ̀ka gbẹ̀fẹ́ àti àìgẹ̀fẹ́.

English: So as part of our program, therefore, to build a sustainable Africa together, we are leading a multi-initiative to develop the Congo Basin Institute, a permanent base where Africans can work in partnership with international researchers, but working out their own solutions to their own problems.
Yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ọ̀kan lára èto wa, fún ìdí èyí, láti kọ́ ilẹ̀-adúláwò alálòpẹ́ lápapọ̀, à ń léwájú àgbékalẹ̀-ọlọ́pọ̀ láti ṣe ìdàgbàsókè ilé-ẹ̀kọ Congo Basin, àyè aláìyípadà níbi tí àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lè ṣiṣẹ́ ní àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú àwọn oníṣẹ́-ìwádìí ilẹ̀-òkèèrè, ṣùgbọ́n tí wọn yóò ma wá ònà àbáyọ tiwọn sí àwọn ìṣòro wọn.

English: We are using our interdisciplinary approach to show how universities, NGOs and private business can partner in international development.
Yoruba: À ń lo ọnà ìmúṣe oríṣiríṣi ẹ̀ka láti ṣàfihan bí àwọn fásitì, àjọ tí kìí ṣe ti ìjọba àti àwọn òwò aládàni lè ní àjọṣepọ̀ nínú ìdàgbàsókè ilẹ̀-òkèèrè.

English: So instead of parachuting in experts from the West for short stays, we are building a permanent presence in Africa, a one-stop shop for logistics, housing and development of collaborative projects between Africans and international researchers.
Yoruba: Dípò gbígbé àwọn òjìnì láti ọ̀dọ̀ awọn aláwọ̀ funfun fún ìgbà díẹ̀, à ń pèse ìdúró aláìyípadà nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, ìsọ̀ kan ṣoṣo fún ohun-èlò, ilé-ìgbé àti ìdàgbàsókè àwọn iṣẹ́-àkànṣe alájọṣepọ̀ láàárín àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ àti àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí ilẹ̀ òkèèrè.

English: So this has allowed students like Michel to receive high-quality training in Africa.
Yoruba: Èyí ti jẹ́ kí àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ó gba ojúlówó ẹ̀kọ́ nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: Michel is currently working in our labs to investigate the effects of climate change on insects, for his PhD, and has already secured his post-doctorate fellowship that will enable him to stay on the continent.
Yoruba: Michel ń ṣiṣẹ́ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ ní àyè fún ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ wa láti ṣe ìwádìí àkóbá àyípadà ojú-ọjọ́ lára kòkòrò, fún oyè ọ̀mọ̀we rẹ̀, ó sì ti gba ìwé-ẹ̀rí oyè ọ̀mọ̀we rẹ̀ tí yóò fun ní àǹfààní láti dúró sí ẹkùn náà.

English: Also through our local help program, Dr. Gbenga Abiodun, a young Nigerian scientist, can work as a post-doctoral fellow with the Foundation for Professional Development in the University of Western Cape in South Africa and the University of California at the same time, investigating the effects of climate variability and change on malaria transmission in Africa.
Yoruba: Bákan náà nípasẹ̀ ètò ìrànwlọ́wọ́ agbègbe wa, Ọ̀mọ̀wé Gbenga Abiodun, ọ̀dọ́modé onímọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ ọmọ Nigeria, lè ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ọ̀mọ̀wé pẹ̀lú Ìdásílẹ̀ fún Ìdàgbàsókè Akọ́ṣẹ́mọṣẹ́ ní fásitì Western Cape ní orílẹ̀-ède South Africa àti fásitì California lásíkò kan náà, ṣíṣe ìwádìí àkóbá àìṣedédé ojú ọjọ́ àti àyípada lára àkóràn ibà nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: Indeed, Gbenga is currently developing models that will be used as an early warning system to predict malaria transmission in Africa.
Yoruba: Lóòótọ́, Gbenga ń ṣe àwòṣe tí wọn yóò lò gẹ́gẹ́ bi ètò ìkìlọ̀ ìpìlẹ̀ láti sọ àsọtẹ́lẹ̀ àkóràn ibà nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: So rather than exporting our best and brightest out of Africa, we are nurturing and supporting local talent in Africa.
Yoruba: Dípò ka máa gbé àwọn tó dára àtí àwọ́n ọlọpọlọ wa kúrò nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀, à ń rè a sì ń ṣe àtìlẹ́yìn ẹ̀bùn abẹ́lé nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: For example, like me, Dr. Eric Fokam was trained in the US.
Yoruba: Fún àpẹẹrẹ, bí èmi náà, orílẹ̀-ède US ni Ọ̀mọ̀wé Eric Fokan ti gba ìkọ́ni.

English: He returned home to Cameroon, but couldn't secure the necessary grants, and he found it incredibly challenging to practice and learn the science he knew he could.
Yoruba: Ó padà sílé ní Cameroon, ṣùgbọ́n kò rí owó ìrànwọ́ tó ṣe pàtàkì gbà, ó sì ríi gẹ́gẹ́ bi ìdojúkọ tó lágbára láti ṣe àti láti mọ ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ tó mọ̀ pé òún lè ṣe.

English: So when I met Eric, he was on the verge of returning to the US.
Yoruba: Nígbà tí mo pàde Eric, ó ń múra láti padà sí orílẹ̀-ède US ni.

English: But we convinced him to start collaborating with the Congo Basin Institute.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a yí ọkàn rẹ̀ padà láti bẹ̀rẹ àjọṣepọ̀ pẹ̀lú ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ Congo Basin.

English: Today, his lab in Buea has over half a dozen collaborative grants with researchers from the US and Europe supporting 14 graduate students, nine of them women, all carrying out groundbreaking research understanding biodiversity under climate change, human health and nutrition.
Yoruba: Lónìí, àyè ìṣèwádìí ọgbọ́n-ìjìlẹ̀ rẹ̀ ní Buea ní tó owó ìrànwọ́ àjọni mẹ́fà pẹ̀lú àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí láti orílẹ̀-ède US àti ilẹ̀ Europe tí wọ́n ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́-jáde 14, mẹ́sàn-án nínú wọn jẹ́ obìnrin, tí gbogbo wọn ń ṣe àwọn ìwádìí alágbára láti ní òye oríṣiríṣi ọ̀wọ́ lábẹ́ àyípadà ojú ọjọ́, ìlera ọmọ ènìyàn àti ohun tí ń fúnni ní okun.

English: So rather than buy into the ideas of Africa taking handouts, we are using our interdisciplinary approach to empower Africans to find their own solutions.
Yoruba: Dípò kí a gba èro kí ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ máa gba owó ìrànwọ́, à ń lo ònà ìmúṣe oríṣiríṣi-ẹ̀ka láti ró àwọn ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ lágbára láti wá ọ̀nà àbáyọ tiwọn.

English: Right now, we are working with local communities and students, a US entrepreneur, scientists from the US and Africa to find a way to sustainably grow ebony, the iconic African hardwood.
Yoruba: Lásíkò yìí, à ń ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn àwùjọ àti àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́, oníṣòwò US kan, àwọn onímọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ láti orílẹ̀-ède US àti ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ láti wá ọ̀nà láti gbin kanran alálòpẹ́, akọni igi-líle nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: Ebonies, like most African hardwood, are exploited for timber, but we know very little about their ecology, what disperses them, how they survive in our forest 80 to 200 years.
Yoruba: Àwọn kanran, bíi ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn igi-líle ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ, ni wọ́n ń lò fún gẹdú, ṣùgbọ́n díẹ̀ la mọ̀ nípa àjọṣepọ̀ wọn, nǹkan tó ń pín wọn ká, bí wọ́n ṣe ń yè nínú igbó wa fún ọgọ́rin sí igba ọdún.

English: This is Arvin, a young PhD student working in our labs, conducting what is turning out to be some cutting-edge tissue culture work.
Yoruba: Arvin rè é, ọdọ́mọdé akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ oyè ọ̀mọ̀wé t’ó ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní yàrá ìṣèwádìí ọgbọ́n-ìjìlẹ̀ wa, tó ń ṣe nǹkan tó ti di iṣẹ́ àṣà pádi-ààyè tó ń léwájú báyìí.

English: Arvin is holding in her hands the first ebony tree that was produced entirely from tissues.
Yoruba: Igi kanran àkọ́kọ́ tí wọ́n ṣẹ̀dá látara pádi-ààyè ni Arvin mú lọ́wọ́ yìí.

English: This is unique in Africa.
Yoruba: Ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ nìkan l’ó ní èyí.

English: We can now show that you can produce African timber from different plant tissues -- leaves, stems, roots -- in addition from generating them from seeds, which is a very difficult task.
Yoruba: A wá lè ṣe àfihàn pé ẹ lè hu àwọn igi gẹdú ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ látara pádi-ààyè oríṣiríṣi nǹkan ọ̀gbìn -- ewé, ìtí, gbòngbò -- ní àfikún sí ìdásílẹ̀ wọn látara èso, èyí tó jẹ́ iṣẹ́ t’ó le gidi gan-an.

English: So other students will take the varieties of ebony which Arvin identifies in our lab, graft them to produce saplings, and work with local communities to co-produce ebony with local fruit tree species in their various farms using our own tree farm approach, whereby we invite all the farmers to choose their own tree species they want in their farms.
Yoruba: Àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ t’ó kù máa mú oríṣìiríṣìi kanran tí Arvin tọ́ka rẹ̀ ní ile-ìṣèwádìí ọgbọ́n-ìjìlẹ̀ wa, lílọ́-ẹ̀ka-wọ́n-sínú-igi-mìíràn láti ṣẹ̀da àwọn igi kékeeké tuntun, kí wọ́n sì ṣiṣẹ́ pẹ̀lú àwọn agbègbè ìgbèríko láti jọ pèsè kanran pẹ̀lú àwọn igi eléso ọ̀wọ́ ọ̀tọ̀ ní àwọn oko wọn pẹ̀lú lílo ọ̀nà-ìmúṣe oko igi tiwa gangan, níbi tí a ti máa pe gbogbo àwọn àgbẹ̀ láti yan ọ̀wọ́ igi tiwọn tí wọ́n fẹ́ lórí oko wọn.

English: So in addition to the ebony, the species which the farmers choose themselves will be produced using our modern techniques and incorporated into their land-use systems, so that they start benefiting from these products while waiting for the ebony to mature.
Yoruba: Ní àfikún sí kanran, àwọn ẹ̀yà ọ̀wọ́ tí àwọn àgbẹ̀ yan fúnra wọn yóò di ṣíṣe pẹ̀lú lílo àwọn ọgbọ́n òde-òní wa a ó sì ṣàfikún rẹ̀ sínú èto lílo-ilẹ̀ wọn, kí wọ́n lè bẹ̀rẹ̀ sí í jẹ àǹfààní látara àwọn nǹkan wọ̀nyí nígbà tí wọ́n bá ń dúró de kanran náà láti dàgbà.

English: Today we are planting 15,000 ebony trees in Cameroon, and for the first time, ebony won't be harvested from the middle of a pristine forest.
Yoruba: Lónìí à ń gbin ẹgbẹ̀rún 15 igi kanran ní orílẹ̀-ède Cameroon, fún ìgbà àkọ́kọ́, wọn ò ní kórè igi kanran láti àárín gbùngbun igbó.

English: This is the model for our African hardwoods, and we are extending this to include sapele and bubinga, other highly prized hardwoods.
Yoruba: Àwòṣe fún àwọn igi-líle ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ wa rè é, a sì ń fa èyí lọ títí láti ṣàfikún igi gẹdú sápẹ́lẹ́ àti igi bubíńga, àwọn igi-líle mìíràn t’ó lówó lórí gidi gan-an.

English: So if these examples existed when I was 18, I would never have left, but because of initiatives by the Congo Basin Institute, I am coming back, but I'm not coming back alone.
Yoruba: Bí àwọn àpẹẹrẹ wọ̀nyí bá ti wà nígbà tí mo wà lọ́mọdún méjì-dín-lógún, mi ò ní kúrò rárá, ṣùgbọ́n nítorí ọgbọ́n àtinúdá ilé-ẹ̀kọ Agbègbè-adágúndò Congo, mò ń padà bọ̀, ṣùgbọ́n mi ò ní padà wá lémi nìkan.

English: I'm bringing with me Western scientists, entrepreneurs and students, the best science from the best universities in the world, to work and to live in Africa.
Yoruba: Mò ń kó àwọn onímọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ ènìyàn Aláwọ̀-funfun, àwọn olókòwò kékèèké àti àwọn akẹ́kọ̀ọ́, àwọn ìmọ̀-ìjìnlẹ̀ t’ó dára jù lo láti àwọn fásitì t’ó dárajù lágbàyé bọ̀ pẹ̀lú mi, láti ṣiṣẹ́ àti gbé nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: But we all need to scale up this local, powerful and empowering approach.
Yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n gbogbo wá nílò láti ṣe àfikún ọ̀nà-ìgbésẹ̀ agbègbè, alágbára àti arónilágbára yìí.

English: So far we have half a dozen universities and NGOs as partners.
Yoruba: Di àsìkò yìí a ti ní àwọn fásitì àti àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́-tí-kìí-ṣe-ti-ìjọba mẹ́fà gẹ́gẹ́ bí alájọṣe.

English: We are planning to build a green facility that will expand on our existing laboratory space and add more housing and conference facilities to promote a long-term disciplinary approach.
Yoruba: À ń gbèrò láti kọ́ àwọn ilé tí yóò dẹ́kun ipa búburú àyípadà ojú ọjọ́ tí yóò fẹ àwọn ilé ìṣèwádìí ọgbọ́n ìjìnlẹ̀ wa lójú tí yóò sì ṣe àfikún àwọn ilé-gbèé àti ohun-èlò àpérò láti ṣe ìgbédìde ọ̀nà-ìmúṣe ìbáwí ọlọ́jọ́ pípẹ́.

English: I want it to offer more opportunities to young African scholars, and would scale it up by leveraging the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture's existing network of 17 research stations across sub-Saharan Africa.
Yoruba: Mo fẹ́ kó fún àwọn ọ̀dọ́ ọmọwé nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní àǹfààní sí i, yóó sì ṣe ìgbéfúkẹ́ rẹ̀ sí i nípa títẹpẹlẹ mọ́ àǹfààní ìsopọ̀ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìwádìí 17 ti Ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ Ilẹ̀-òkèèrè ti Iṣẹ́-Àgbẹ̀ Agbègbè Ìgbóná-Oòrùn t’ó ti wà tẹ́lẹ̀ káàkiri Gúúsù-aṣálẹ̀ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀.

English: The tables are starting to turn and I hope they keep turning, to reach several African nations like Côte d'Ivoire, Tanzania and Senegal, among the top fastest growing economies that can attract several opportunities for private-sector investment.
Yoruba: Àwọn ìyípadà rere náà ti ń dé mo sì lérò pé wọn yóò tẹ̀síwájú, kí ó dé ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè Ilẹ̀-adúláwọ̀ bi Côte d'Ivoire, Tanzania àti Senegal, lára àwọn tí ìdágbàsókè ètò ọrọ̀-ajé wọ́n wà lókè ténté t’ó lè ṣe ìgbàmọ́ra àǹfààní tó pọ̀ fún ìdókòwò ẹ̀ka-aládàni.

English: We want to give more opportunities to African scholars, and I long to see a day when the most intelligent Africans will stay on this continent and receive high-quality education through initiatives like the Congo Basin Institute, and when that happens, Africa will be on the way to solving Africa's problems.
Yoruba: A fẹ́ fún àwọn ọ̀mọ̀wé nílẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ ní àǹfààní síi, mo sì ń fojú sọ́nà láti rí ọjọ́ kan tí ọmọ ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ tó lọ́pọlọ jù máa dúró sí ẹkùn náà láti gba ẹ̀tò-ẹ̀kọ́ tó jẹ́ ojúlówó nípasẹ̀ àgbékalẹ̀ bíi ilé-ẹ̀kọ Congo Basin, nígbà tí ìyẹn bá ṣẹlẹ̀, Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀ yóò wà lójú ọ̀nà láti yanjú àwọn ìṣòro Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

English: And in 50 years, I hope someone will be giving a TED Talk on how to stop the brain drain of Westerners leaving your homes to work and live in Africa.
Yoruba: Ní 50 ọdún sí àsìkò yìí, mo lérò wí pé ẹnìkan yóò ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ Ọ̀rọ̀ sísọ TED nípa ìfimọ ìgbọ́ngbẹ ọpọlọ ẹ̀yin ènìyàn Aláwọ̀-funfun tí ẹ̀ ń fi ilé yín sílẹ̀ láti lọ ṣiṣẹ́ àti gbé ní Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

English: Thank you.
Yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.
